description:
I can't get enough of this place! We ordered a delivery through GrubHub for the office a couple weeks ago and decided to order again because it was that good! They deliver fresh bread with the order which tastes like it's fresh out the oven. I ordered the Fresh Tomatoes and Cheese Pide with chicken which kind of reminded me of a calzone (but healthier) and tasted amazing! 

I also got the Combo Grill Plate and they are not stingy with their serving! I got a good amount of meat, lamb, and chicken. 

Update: I'm back, at the restaurant this time. Had to get the combo grill plate again and shared with my dad. Happy to say he loved it too! Service was good and quick. Definitely coming back!
author: Sofía G.

description:
We loved the food. 
It's amazing how delicious their food is. Amazing 
Thanks for making 4th of july amazing.
author: Brey A.

description: We always thought there might not be any vegetarian choices and didn't go here. The other day I checked the menu to see that they did have quite a few vegetarian recipes. Absolutely loved the pida bread and baba ganouj. I also had a spinach and cheese bread which was good. Chicken sheesh kebab was tasty too.
author: Sailaja B.

description:
The location is pretty sketchy but it's safe specially during the day. The restaurant is casual with authentic Turkish food. We ordered beef and lamb doner sandwich and Adana Kabab with a side of cacik. 

I've had better cacik before and this one was the most bland one. It needed a bit more salt and garlic. 

The doner Sandwich was juicy but the sauce just like the cacik needed a bit more flavor. 
 
Adana kabab was prepared well. The rice isn't gluten free as it has some added orzo in it so we substitute that with hummus.
author: Ghazal P.

description: We stopped in late in on a Monday night. Ordered a plate of hummus, falafel plate and chicken kebab plate. Everything was delicious and prepared quickly. We also ordered a bottle of red wine with our meal. Overall, it was a good experience and I would return.
author: Jay S.

description: Great Turkish food. This place is a must try for authentic Turkish food. Lahmacun and Iskender kebab was legit.
author: Madhu J.

description:
Great laumacun in Area, little bit too spicy though but still tastes like homemade.
Location is horrible of course, but it's a GO as pickup order.
author: Nima F.

description:
Mitra was our waitress, and we loved the way she interacted with us.( great service = 2 points)
Enjoyable restaurant ,
Fast costumer service,
Nice staff ,
Great food quality,
Big portions,
Original Turkish dishes and sandwiches,
Does not have a patio unfortunately.
Loved it
author: Atosa T.

description:
Absolutely incredible food and service!

Came in on a work lunch and we decided to order just about everything on the menu. We started with hummus and bread, and a spinach and cheese Pide. It was absolutely perfect. Thin flaky crust with perfectly prepared spinach inside. 

I ordered the Combo Donner plate. It has a nice verity of a few different meats, my favorite being the meatballs. I believe they were lamb. The Turkish tea was very strong and went well with our meal.

Of course we ordered dessert. The baklava was exactly as I was hoping it would be . The honey really was the best part of this flaky dessert. 

I have never had Turkish food before, and this place has set the bar exceptionally high. I hope you fall in love with this place as I have. The service alone was the kind stuff you only see in places where they care about what they cook. They take pride in their family traditions. It shows all the way.
author: Kat D.

description: Good food! Adana is delicious. Superb atmosphere. Portions on a smaller side though!
author: Nur U.

description: I really like this place. Everything is really good. We ordered Beyti , soup and cheese&sucuk pide. They were really delicious and servers were really nice. Thanks to our server Cazibe. If you want to eat really good turkish food with good price point here is the place!
author: Dilan U.

description:
I found A La Turca Restaurant on Yelp and as it had a solid four star rating I decided to try it for dinner a couple of days ago. I wanted to get something a little different than simple doner or shish kebabs that Turkish restaurants are known for. I had tried Iskender kabab at Anatolian Kitchen in Palo Alto sometime back so when I saw it on the menu here I decided to get that to-go ($15.25) via the online ordering app on Yelp.

A La Turca Restaurant is in the hood (Tenderloin) so after dodging half a dozen panhandlers I finally landed here after about 20 minutes of ordering to find my food ready to-go.

Iskender kebab is supposed to be slices of doner kabab on bread cubes topped with tomato sauce and served with yogurt. What I got seemed to have all the components plus an additional naan type of bread. The doner kabab was thinly sliced as expected. Unfortunately it did not taste like it had been freshly sliced off the spit. It seemed to be have been pre-sliced and then made to sit under a lamp which squeezed all the moisture out of it giving it a texture of cardboard. The tomato sauce also could not rescue this disaster. The best part of the dish was the yogurt which was fresh, creamy and seemed homemade. The naan type of bread was also dry and crumbly. It was definitely not fresh, nor had it been heated up before it was handed over to me.

Overall this was just bad when compared to the soft juicy doner topped with tomato sauce that I recollect eating in Anatolian Kitchen. Price-wise that was 15% more expensive but totally worth the extra cost. I'm not sure how this place deserves a four start rating but what I got certainly did not deserve a four star rating. My return visit is pretty doubtful.
author: Ahmad J.

description: This place is fantastic. Old school Turkish just i remember it in turkey. Love the lamb chops. Insane wine and beer prices. Never a line. It's an establishment. You only find Turkish people and people like me. ;)
author: Xiu L.

description: Favorite place in the TL. The Beyti Kebap, combo platter, hummus, and split pea soup are weekly staples in my diet. Oh, and the lamb doner wrap. And the best staff! Wish I could give more stars!
author: Jacqueline W.

description: The food here is great! I ordered a Combo Doner plate and loved how filling and yummy it was !
author: Antonia Z.

description: Wayyy to overpriced food. The restaurant inside is decent not too fancy. Depending on that, the prices are too high.
author: Mario L.

description: This is our go to friendly spot for authentic Turkish food. Their pide is on point and I love all of the combo (köfte, döner) plates along with rice and salad. Turkish tea is brewed on spot as well.
author: Chique M.

description: Delicious turkish food! We took the combo grill plate and the combination was very tasteful and rich. In addition, the restaurant has a nice and calm atmosphere and is held very properly. Also the decoration fits very well to the turkish cuisine.
author: Daniele D.

description:
I came back here today for another bowl of lentil soup and roasted eggplant salad. So unbelievably good. I feel that they deserve 5 stars, but I want to taste the kebabs (last time I had it was years ago!), I have a hunch they are amazing. 

Everything looks good and smells good too, and a separate mention to their bread, it's so silky and fluffy I just can't get enough of it! 

I will try to stay focused next visit and will order lamb kebab
author: Anelya S.

description:
A unique Turkish restaurant with some great dishes.

My friends and I have been eyeing interesting restaurants in San Francisco. A La Turca piqued our interests because there aren't very many Turkish restaurants. Excited and eager, we all decided to go on a Friday night.

I came with 3 other people on a Friday night at around 6 pm. The restaurant was rather empty to our pleasure so we quickly got seated.

The menu was large and vast so we had difficulty choosing what we wanted. Something that bothered me here was that our server came to ask us if we were ready way too many times within a short period. Normally I wouldn't be too irked by this, but considering the fact that the store was empty I didn't want to feel rushed.  However, when we wanted to pay for the bill and tried to grab the server's attention, it took much difficulty to do so.

My friends and I ended up ordering many dishes:
We got the Lahmacun(bread with delicious toppings on top), Combo Grilled Plate(Lamb/beef/chicken shishkabobs, and meat ball that comes with rice, salad, and pide bread), Lamb Beyti, Chicken & Mushroom Pide, Spinach & Cheese Gozleme, and Baklava.

The Lahmacun was very delicious. I thought this was one of their better dishes. It has a very unique flatbread texture with very seasoned toppings. The lahmacun had a great bite, and the taste was definitely there.
The Combo Grilled Plate was great. I thought the varying types of meat was fun. While they weren't unique, they were well cooked meats. The meats are very much different to shishkabob meats, but it was a good variety. 
The Lamb Beyti was amazing. I really loved this dish. This dish was composed of ground lambed wrapped up into their flatbread. The dish comes with yogurt and their special sauce(which is a tomato based). I thought this dish had no flaws, and I could not find anything to be unhappy about.
The Spinach & Cheese Gozleme was disappointing. I expected the flour consistency to be as good as all their other breads but the gozleme was boring. It tasted like a quesadilla and because of that I was sorely disappointed.
The Baklava was generic baklava. It was less sticky than most baklava (which I liked) but the size was extremely small.
Lastly, while we ordered the Mushroom & chicken Pide, we got the Potato & Cheese Pide instead. We tried to tell our server this, but the server stubbornly said we ordered mushroom, and would not accept any conversation regarding it. This frustrated me because I would understand if we wouldn't be able to get the order fixed, but there was no attempt to talk about this at all. The potato and Cheese pide was disappointing as well, but that's because I believe the potato with the pide was a strange texture combination. While I really liked the pide, combining it with the potato made it a dish I find hard to recommend.

Overall, in terms of the quality of food, A La Turca is a unique experience with many unique dishes, their Pide, Beyti, and Lahmacun especially. However, A La Turca is a rather pricey place, and while there are some gems, there are a lot of generic dishes as well. This experience of mine was difficult to recommend because of the poor customer service I received, but I would be willing to give it another shot.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
A great spot to get authentic home cooking interpreted with ingredients close to home. Just like stopping by your  
Turkish friend's grandma's house.
author: Dilek I.

description: I bought some bread from a La Turca and I found out that the price double up , never hear of that we make money by doubling the price, it doesn't work like that , there is a guide line how to raise the prices, as a consumer that mean don' t come back. By the way it is a new owner!
author: Bilal H.

description:
I stumbled by this restaurant and decided to check it out based upon the yelp rating. I got a doner sandwich and kenefe. 

The kenefe was great. I am Syrian and kenefe (we spell it kunafeh) is a treat that's hard to find. It's a cheese pastry soaked in syrup. What's not to love?

The reason this place is getting a low review is due to the sandwich. It was horrible. I actually threw it out, and it takes a lot for me to do that. I would assume it is better on the pide, but the lavash was bad. Lavash is already a bland, dry bread, and they did nothing to combat that. There was almost no tahini sauce, the lavash was too big for the sandwich, and there was very little meat. The sandwich was basically a double layer of lavash with lettuce inside. You can see in the picture there was one, maybe two, thin pieces of meat showing. With the size of the sandwich that was one bite per cross section. The actual components themselves were fine. I eat a lot of Mediterranean, and this was nothing exceptional. Still with that, the sandwich would be more than satisfying if it had more meat, more sauce, less bread, and less lettuce.
author: Jo B.

description:
We loved eating here. I had the salad A La Turca and it was very good.  I wish I could find the feta cheese that was on this salad!  It was more moist than what I find in the stores. This is the real deal when it comes to Turkish food.  

My boyfriend had the sampler platter that combined tasty morsels of steak, chicken as well as shavings of slow cooked lamb and chicken.  It was all cooked to perfection and I admit I ate most of his platter. Oops, I did it again.  Oh and the rice on the platter was perfect. I'm a big rice fan and cook rice all the time and I feel I know rice. That was good rice!

We also ordered the grape leaves which were perfect and delicious and the pita bread that came with the meal was served warm and fluffy and actually if our food hadn't come to fast we would have ordered the humus.  Actually I can't wait to go back just to order the humus! 

Also, the staff was super nice and attentive and we never had to wait much for anything which is rarely the case at that level of busyness.
author: Monica E.

description: Amazing! I love the traditional way they serve their food and how the restaurant is from the inside. The food tastes very good especially the iskender. I would recommend this place for everyone to try!
author: Yasmen L.

description:
I've been here twice now.  Both times I have really enjoyed it. It's a down home kind of place.  Everyone working there is super nice.  I brought my baby and they were super nice and accommodating.  I ordered the baba Ganoush and it was excellent it comes with freshly baked flat bread.  Got a salad it was a little flat, needed more salt and acid.  The combo plate was amazing, it had a little bit of all the meats.  The lamb, kofta, and chicken were super tasty.  Also ordered some sort of semolina coconut cake.  It was soaked in a light syrup and it was delicious.  
This place is great if you want a chill environment with good size portions for a bargain.
author: Krystal R.

description: Really good combo appetizer plate.  Everything is veg, and with the pide, fed two of us with some leftovers.  I particularly liked the eggplant salad.
author: Helen T.

description:
I LOVE this place, friendly people delicious food and you dont have to pay with an arm and a leg.

Highly recommended this place when my mom comes to visit SF she always wants to have dinner here at least once while she is here.

However i get the fact that we make reviews based on our own experience but sometimes i read stuff on here that makes me second guess if yelp is really that helpful... some people write reviews with the goal of hurting the business and ruining it reviews that are out of line completely ridiculous and stories made up, i would call for yelp users like me to be honest and have integrity and write your review based on facts so that more people who are reading reviews make the right decision. 

Ps the beef shish kebab is the bomb!
author: René A.

description:
The first time I went in to try a lamb doner sandwich.
In Europe I eat these at night and pay around $3.50.
This one was $9.50!?
I know all of San Fran food is overpriced, so I let that go.
As I waited for them to prepare I perused the place. 
The staff was really nice.
The place is clean.
The decor could be freshened up with lighting, paint and cultural stuff.
Then I noticed the Lacmush? pizza. I have a mental block on what it is called so forgive me.
It is thin crust with crushed veggies on top and was a great appetizer and transport for the other stuff, like a chip.
The meat spear thing was what I tried the second time I went. ($16.)
The salads are all fresh. 
The deli counter has good looking stuff in it.
This place rocks and should be experienced.
author: Dude Food G.

description:
No frills Turkish food. Adana kabob plate is flavorful though it would have been nice if it was a bit more spicy. 

Rice was premixed orzo so it was off limits for me and my gluten allergy but the humus was solid as well as the side salad. 

The side dish yogurt was also nice but not as flavorful as some of the other Turkish restaurants I've been to.
author: Dan P.

description:
I am always a bit nervous when ordering falafel because it is often super dry, but this falafel was great! Definitely on the moist side, with a nice crunchy outer layer. The platter comes with a basic salad and some delicious hummus as well! The rice was also super flavorful. The bread that comes along is really nice, kinda reminds me of the texture of a soft pretzel. 
My boyfriend ordered the combo platter and he thought it was great! 
We got baklava for dessert, and I was disappointed to find the bottom was extremely soggy. Other than that it still had awesome flavor.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Quite possibly one of the best Turkish restaurants I've been too--& I've visited my fair share in SoCal as well. Please don't be concerned about the safety inspection warning on Yelp. I've eaten here multiple times and never gotten slightly sick. The food was prepared very well and the staff was super nice!

We came on a Friday night around 8pm and the place wasn't too corwded. We were able to get a table with no reservation. Larger groups might benefit from a reservation for peak times. My friend and I ordered the following:

-Hummus ($5.50) w/ complimentary bread
-Doner Platter ($13.50)
-Chicken and Cheese Gozleme w/ added spinach ($8.00)

Everything was very good! I highly recommend getting the hummus as an app, and then going to the main course. The doner platter is amazing--the meat is so savory, but since it's so thin, make sure you eat it fast, or else it will get cold! I made the mistake of being too chatty and letting my doner get cold haha. The gozleme is like a *stuffed* quesadilla and they will let you combine toppings, so your not limited to the ones on the menu.

Love this spot! Please pay them a visit!
author: Vasiliy M.

description: I look forward to returning to this restaurant. I still remember the delicious lamb chops. I also liked the family atmosphere, and being able to see the cooks.
author: Kim O.

description: Great Mediterranean food! And Baklava is my favorite desert! Highly recommended..........
author: Mustafa A.

description: Taste was delicious! It's a real Turkish food, I gave four not five cuz their dish is small! They should add more food since it's not cheap at all! Sucuk and Cheese Gozleme cost $8.50 there are only 3 thin slices of it with just a little bit of sucuk and a very small a amount of salad! The exactly same plate in San Diego cost $5.70 and will be 5 slices of gozleme with either humus or salad from a top Turkish restaurant as well! Same for Beyti kepab that cost $16.25 but it's still small. In general, It worth the try as a visitor but for sure they need to increase the portion size since it's expensive and their sitting is not classy. Their customer service was very nice and their girl who took our order was very friendly and welcoming. Oh their yogurt drink is a must try specially if it's dinner.
author: Bana A.

description: Overpriced bread! Double the price from last week very disappointing they would raise prices to their loyal neighborhood customers.
author: harmony b.

description:
This place is delightful! Service was amazing and the food was even better. Normally, I would come up with ridiculous ways to say how awesome this place is, but instead I'm going to save us all time and just tell you to go eat here.

What we've tried to-date:
Lahmacun - kind of like a flatbread pizza, but WAY tastier
Mushroom & Cheese Gozleme - it's like a mushroom quesadilla, but the kind that puts all other quesadillas to shame. oh, and THAT CHEESE! sooooo good.
Hummus - pretty self explanatory, but it had this deliciously earthy taste that I can't describe very well, so just go order it.
Pide - it's like focaccia and pita bread had a baby. *swoon*
Doner Plate - all the delicious gyro meat on a plate, with buttery rice and salad
Grill Plate - all the delicious grilled meats (plus the meatball! OMFG the meatball!!!!!) on a plate, with buttery rice and salad.

Also, props to our waitress, who walked us through the menu. All the above items were her recommendations, and she pretty much nailed it.
author: Tori D.

description:
I just left the restaurent after I find out the item i buy from there and the price  double up , I understand some restaurent might increase the prices little bit for what ever reasons but double the price is telling me never come back to this place again ever or recommend it ,
Very disappointed . Of the new owner not too smart Decision
I
Miss the previous Owners the food was much better
author: Mawi T.

description: Best meal we had in San Francisco!  Generous servings of delicious halal food. We started with the hummus and had the lahmacun and chicken doner platter for lunch. I see other reviews complaining about the area but we had no issues with the location and even walked there instead of driving.
author: H A.

description:
Very pricey ............
They charge (the borek) for $ 5,80 without tax and basically it's not a borek ( just a turnover) 
We got a cold antep yogurtlu for 16,25 $ without yogurt loooooool 
Come on ! Just a star to don't be bad ............
author: Medi M.

description:
Good food, pricey but it's worth it. 
Very clean,  nice place. Good customer service 
All menus  good yamiii 
I recommended
author: Nadia H.

description: It was our first time being in San Francisco and this place was delicious! I've never had Turkish food before so I was intrigued by their food selection. I ordered the Chicken Beyti and my husband ordered the Lamb Doner. We read that the beyti was one of the items to get here and it was definitely amazing. We ordered our food to go through the yelp app and it was ready in no time. We loved how friendly the staff were and I recommend it :)
author: Ally L.

description:
Updated Review: This kinda pains me to write. Definitely read my previous review. I have been here probably 80 times. Mostly takeout. The food is very good, and the few Turkish people I know say it's as authentic as it gets in SF. 

The service is atrocious though. At least in my experiences here. Either the servers are incompetent at the job or there are systems in place here that is not conducive for efficient service. Or both. 

In my most recent visit I just had to get up and leave. I don't think I've ever done that before. As a waiter myself, I tend to have empathy for others in this industry. But these people seem to not have their act together. 

I used to come around once a month in their earlier years but now it's more infrequent. Their poor customer service for takeout and dine-in is the sole reason why.
author: Dash_Rendar _.

description:
The food is great if you steer away from sandwiches and get a proper platter.
Must try here:
Lentil Soup. (Yumm! the best in the city).
Baba Ganoush
Beyti Kabab.
Turkish tea.
author: Aziz A.

description: I ordered from here using eat24. As soon as it arrived, the fragrance of the freshly baked bread and the dessert kunefe filled through and built up my hunger. The pide bread, which I initially thought was pita, was something different from what I expected until I realized pita and pide bread are 2 different things. Pide bread was quite thick. While I liked the flavor of crusty bread, I found it too dry from inside while eating with hummus. I wonder if it would have been served with butter/olive oil if I ordered it at the restaurant. The hummus was okay. The kunefe was rich and delicious.
author: Tejashree M.

description: Awesome food, great service! Beyti kebap is good option. But no matter what you get, its good!
author: Ray W.

description: You give take out order, show up five minutes late and they prefer to serve your food to their buddies, which means you have to wait for another ten minutes. I see the food taken out of the to-go box and go to the table where the owner hangs out with his friends.
author: Kamil R.

description: I eat at alaturka every day and I love it , its clean and food is delicious,fresh tea and fresh of the oven Turkish desert ...my friend Ismail  go there to ...
author: Well's Intelligent T.

description: Loved the lentil soup. It comes with bread like in Turkey. Ordered combo kebab; it was very good. I got rice pudding as dessert... I am coming back tomorrow!
author: Fatih Y.

description: Good food and okay prices. Two for dinner with one hot appetizer, the gozleme (or Turkish "quesadilla"), and tea for dessert PLUS tip is $65. Beef shish kebab could be more tender and flavorful. Favorite part of dinner was the eggplant appetizer and the red cabbage on my salad. Rice was tasty but I needed more. On second thought, come here to eat light. I needed to ask for water each time, and you will be left sitting there with an empty glass. The wait staff are pleasant. Just don't try to stay too long.
author: Monika H.

description: I've been going to this spot over the past 12 years and it has been consistently solid in terms of food, service and prices. And you typically don't have to wait. I only give it five stars because that's the max, otherwise I'd give it more.
author: Jesse D.

description: Delicious food and great service. They made us feel home. Kunefe is what makes everything special at the end. Awesome!
author: Samir R.

description:
Not cheap imitation of Turkish Kitchen but real Turkish cousine! If you really wanna try some good Turkish kebab, try this one! I am highly satisfied! And true turkish hospitality they offer.

Kebabi efsane. İsletmeciler cana yakin. Hasili biz sevdik.
author: Beyza H.

description: Ordered from ubereats. Miniscule portions with the shish kabob plate 3 ounces of meat for 16 dollars. Not again.
author: Brendan Edwin C.

description: Tasty Turkish food, fresh, quick easy. Quiet place, Good service, nice lunch. Portions are not that big.
author: Nick B.

description: Their adana kebab and kebabs in general are pretty good, the main disappointment is the lack of salads as side dishes that comes with the food, but overall rather decent turkish food
author: Veranda H.

description: I had great food (shish kabbab and rice) and great service at this place. Food is reasonably priced. Portions are a bit small but overall the food is very good. The staff is nice and friendly. I told the girl I would wait for the food outside and she came and brought it to me to my car.
author: M D.

description: Great place for an authentic donner kebabs. Fresh and clean place unlike other Turkish restaurants in the area. Sumptuous and flavourful place to be tried in this area.
author: Vivek P.

description:
3.5 stars
Always friendly service and consistently good food. I always get the chicken kabob plate which comes with rice, salad, and soft, fluffy pita bread. 

I always get take out so I can't speak to the dining in experience. The price is around $16 for the kabob plate which I always thought was a bit high. Their case of desserts always looks amazing! Will have to try other dishes and dining in for a more accurate review.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Came in as a big group with families and really enjoyed 
Authentic meal , fresh food and great customer service!
Try the beyti kebab
author: Preeti K.

description: This place is not super fancy, but it is clean, cosy, not overpriced, and has great customer service. Most importantly, the food is very very delicious! Would highly recommend and definitely will return.
author: Arman B.

description:
Excellent food! The place was very busy and I know why :) the waitress apologised for the slow service and ordered free bread and tea at the end of the super. 
Will definitely come here again!
author: Edik B.

description: The food is so dry ! I couldn't feel the flavor ! Service is really slow ! They forgot to get us the tea too! Pricy for nothing ! I don't recommend at all!!!!
author: Zynab Z.

description: I was not expecting it to be this delicious. I had the Lamacun &  Iskendar kepab platter !
author: Zeeni N.

description: This restaurant has great fresh and tasty food, great service, and a great location.  It's not fancy or trendy.  It's just the real deal yummy and affordable Turkish food.  I love the hummus and babaganouj, and the pide bread they serve is so fresh and tasty.  I've had beef and chicken shish, both really tasty.  But my fave is the combo chicken and beef/lamb doner.  Can't say enough good about this place, I've been many times and I always leave satisfied.
author: Jessica I.

description: This place is a hidden little gem, on Geary Blvd in San Francisco, which for those that are not familiar with the area...can be a little uninviting. A La Turca gives you just what you need, when you need it. Although it is situated in a not-so-great part of the city, once inside, the ambiance completely changes. My husband and I arrived for a late lunch and were greeted right away to find a table. Our waiter was courteous, respectful, and not overly talkative, which was nice. We shared the Lamb Shish Kebap, with the feta cheese and spinach pastry dough appetizer--we topped it all off with some Turkish coffee of course, accompanied by a small slice of Baklava. Next time we will try the Kadayif (baked shredded phyllo dough with pistachios) YUM! We were thoroughly satisfied, as far as the service and the food. This is one of those "hole-in-the-wall" places that you're glad you tried.
author: Maria S.

description:
This is my new favorite Turkish restaurant in Bay Area! All other Turkish restaurants about money but this restaurant is about FOOD. I tried a few different things my favorites are cheese pide and Burma (dessert). Eat and feel like you're in Turkey! 
Good Job Guys! Thanks for great experience:)
author: Ecem P.

description:
There's not many Turkish places in the bay area and once I saw this I wanted to try it, really bad. 
I was greeted and welcomed very generously and was given water at the moment. 
It was a very relaxed atmosphere, the area is not the best but it's okay. The food tasted very fresh and tasty. I had the Turkish Tea and it was pleasant, I was told they have some variety types of tea on some days but Turkish Tea is very common.
I am content with the place and I'll come back for more tasty treats.
author: Nadav M.

description:
We just had lunch in A La Turca (Sat. Oct. 29@2pm).
We have been going to this resturant for the past several years about 3-4 times a month.
We've always had a great experience.
Today there was a different crew. The waitress was new and although was trying to be helpful, she didn't have a clue what she was doing.
The person preparing our food looked like the kitchen help that I normally see in the back.
The food was absolutely atrocious. I hope we don't get sick.
We have a very experienced palate but we aren't critical at all and realize everyone has a bad day.
But today's food was absolutely disgusting. 
Even the couple next to our table was complaining about their food.
I hope this is not a norm. Next time, before going in, I'll make sure our regular folks are there. If they are, I will let them know.

This is for the owner: don't take your customers for granted. No matter how long you are in business, you can lose it all in just a few months.
author: Ashour B.

description: The food is great but the main reason I keep going back to A La Turca Restaurant is Kunefe! :)
author: Dilan Z.

description:
It was the first time we've been in A la turca. We really liked it!
The portions are big enough and delicious.
Thanks.
author: Zeynep Miray N.

description: Ordered the iskender kebab and it was really good! I am originally from Turkey and visit Turkish restaurants when I travel and this place is definitely at the top! The service is also great with a friendly atmosphere inside.
author: Murat O.

description: This place was very tasteful. Probably as close to authentic Turkish food as I have come to in the states. I ordered the iskender which was great. My fiancé ordered Cheese Pide with Sucuk (a Turkish pizza) and was very pleased. Our server was also polite and did a great job. I would recommend this place.
author: Denise I.

description:
Just moved into the neighborhood and I finally gave this place a try. I had been missing Döner ever since I moved from Germany back to the states, and I knew that's exactly what I would order. I wasn't sure what expectations to have since I had not found anything close to Döner in Germany, but I went in with an open mind. 

And wow! It was amazing! The pita bread is perfect and the lamb is delicious and quality. I was not disappointed in the slightest, and I can't wait to try more options on the menu!
author: Megan F.

description:
Do not order Doner from this restaurant. It is the driest and worst Doner I ate in my life. 

I have been inside the restaurant a few times, it is mostly okay.
author: Jon O.

description: Food is decent but not authentic. I ordered the gozleme and it wasnt gozleme at all. Overall service was good and food came fast. I just wish I got what I expected.
author: Dilek D.

description:
Very tasty place! Nice decor and service.
My friend had the Antep  yogurtlu which was very tasty! We shared the lamb puff, very nice as well! I had the chicken liebeh so tasty
author: Rachida I.

description: A friend asked me to meet her here for lunch. I arrived before her and noticed the menu's were extremely dirty and sticky. I keep Clorox wipes in my purse and wiped down the menu's - and the wipe was black when I was done. Then I checked Yelp and noticed the poor sanitary rating! I left in a hurry. There is no excuse for not cleaning menu's that everyone touches, that's DISGUSTING. THEY ARE PAYING FOR GOOD REVIEWS, DON'T RISK YOUR HEALTH TO EAT HERE. I have posted pictures of the dirty menu and wipe!
author: Bridget M.

description:
Really great authentic Turkish food and these words go a long way. If you are craving shish or lamb kabob then I would highly recommend this restaurant and it's only a 7 min walk from union square. My wife and I walked it was worth it. Don't get sucked into the high-end fancy restaurants around union square. Make the walk or uber it, you will not be dissapointed. 

Hummus is good
Tabouleh is pretty good to, just order lemon amd add some salt on it and it's perfect
Rice is amazing
I had the combo platter and my wife ended up getting the lamb shish kabob - amaaaaaazing
author: Abdullah S.

description: This is an authentic Turkish restaurant. We ordered pide and lahmacun both of which was baked in their oven and it tasted like they were made from scratch. A little taste of home in San Francisco...
author: Jan Orhun A.

description: it's been awhile since i've been here but the lamb and baba ghanouj was delicious. for sure will be coming back for more!
author: Julla E.

description:
This is a nice Turkish Restaurant.  It is reasonably priced. They serve many items. Customer service is friendly and efficient.  It has a nice ambiance.

I tried their Turkish coffee. It was good and strong. A lot different than the coffee I get from my Keurig machine. Coffee was thick, aromatic, and not bitter. I did not need to add sugar to it to make it more palatable.

I tried the Lahmacun (looks like Turkish pizza). It was very good. It was light and tasty. Lamb Beef Doner Sandwich was also very good. The serving was large, the Doner meat was moist and tasty. The lettuce was fresh, and had the right amount of sauce.

The Kunefe was really delicious. It was baked with fine noodles and sweet cheese inside. It was slightly sweet and flakey.

I also had the Kiymali Borek. It is a pastry dough baked with sauteed ground meat. It looks like a Turkish Empanada. It was delicious. The pasty was flakey and buttery.

The Baba Ghanouj was good. It came with the house bread, which was warm and fresh. The Baba Ghanouj was tasty and had a subtle smokey flavor.

I really enjoy coming to this place. I look forward to trying out some more items.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: Me and my friend were there three days ago and I got Iskender and my friend got beyti. The both food were extremly delicious. The service was great. We enjoyed a lot. Also I forgot my credit card there. When I led them know they mailed it to me (to New York) without any question. That's why they deserve 5 Stars! Highly recommended.
author: Furkan O.

description:
This place is pretty bomb.  If you never had Turkish food, this is the best restaurant to try this cuisine. Came here a while back for a birthday party and made reservations so we got seated with no problems. They have a separate seating area on top for a big party which is were we sat. The wait staff was also Turkish so you know the place will be legit.

Everything we had was simply amazing. The sauces, the meat, the breads and the rice were so flavorful. The meat dishes look delicious as well and they serve good portions. When we were all done with dinner, the waiter came with deserts for the entire table for free. 

The only downside is that the area is kinda sketchy. Lock your cars!
author: Juan F.

description:
Delicious! We had a catered lunch from A La Turca Restaurant at work and that is what first brought me to love this place. It's close by the office and the food is fresh, fast and very flavorful. 

Their combination appetizer of Hummus, Baba Ghanouj, Ezme, Eggplant Salad, Cacik and Stuffed Grape Leaves was delicious. It is served with the house made pita bread. This was a good appetizer for the whole table and everyone got to try all of the different items.

We went in a couple weeks ago for a work luncheon before the holiday and I ordered the Combo Doner Platter which came with chicken and beef doner thinly sliced; served with salad and rice. The spicy hot chili sauce they have is a nice addition. 

Love the food and will be back to try more dishes on the menu.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
I visited A la Turca many years ago when I worked nearby. Since we had a concert to attend nearby, I suggested that we stop by for some Turkish cuisine for dinner.  Upon arriving, the waitress promptly seated us.  A loaf of pide bread.  It was a thick, bread that had a doughy texture.  Topped with white and black sesame seeds, the bread was warm, soft and tasty.
 
After checking out the menu, we ordered:
 
Pide bread came with our selected items.  It was a thick, bread that had a doughy texture.  Topped with white and black sesame seeds, the bread was warm, soft and tasty. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-la-turca-restaurant-san-francisco?select=4Ugc0x70WBsgbeBFRujxaA)
 
Lentil Soup - red lentils with rice, carrots, onions, potatoes, zucchini, celery and spices. It had a nice consistency and was tasty. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-la-turca-restaurant-san-francisco?select=4uG1JWDk6T4IZZfHvCXfDw)
 
Spinach & cheese Gozleme - sautéed spinach with mixed cheese between flat bread. Brought back memories of our first experience with Gozleme during our recent trip to Turkey.  We call it a Turkish quesadilla.  The spinach was nicely seasoned.  Very good. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-la-turca-restaurant-san-francisco?select=mcY89y3nqpq3krJJSm6iHQ)
 
Donner Platter -  slices of vertically roasted ground lamb and beef with rice and salad.  The slices of lamb/beef were nicely seasoned and very tasty. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-la-turca-restaurant-san-francisco?select=AMI7a0_R_CSqpEqMDrdzjQ)
 
Food brought back memories of meals we had in Turkey.  Delicious and service was friendly.  Hope to be back soon, if I get a craving for Turkish food.
author: Al L.

description: Met a friend for lunch at this great little cafe. We arrived at 11:30 on Thursday and were the only customers. The crowd picked up pretty quickly after that. The lady in charge is a women of few words but she was very nice to us. She brought us fresh bread twice and was honest enough about the portion sizes on the menu, so we did not end up ordering extra. We picked the appetizer combo and the mushroom/feta bread. Both were awesome. The dolma in the combo plate was the best I ever had. The hummus and tabouleh were great too. For dessert we tried one of the pastries displayed at the counter - I don't remember the name but it was divine!!!! I would love to come back again and try more items. They have a lot of vegan friendly options on the menu.
author: Meghna G.

description: Portions were ok (lentil soup was small tho) but it tasted very mediocre to me. Not sure what Turkish food tastes like tbh as I've never really had Turkish before but this was very bland and didn't taste unique at all. I had the Chicken Iskendar (I think?) And it basically tasted like chicken and cubes of bread splashed with tomato sauce and cooked for a bit... Nothing spectacular. The lentil soup was ok, not great at first but you kinda grow to like it towards the end. It tasted alright and filled both me and my husband but not something I would crave. Idk I don't think I'll be back here but would like to get good Turkish food elsewhere to change my mind on this cuisine.
author: Trisha D.

description:
This is probably the tenth time I've been to A La Turca. It has been the best Turkish restaurant in the bay area for some time. However, over time, I recognized an obvious drop in quality. 

During my last visit, lahmacun was burnt, rice pilaf was sticky, waitress had a bad attitude, and worse, people smoked inside. I take one star for each. All of these issues could be solved by the owner. I hope they can get their stars back next time.
author: Tim K.

description: This place is one of my neighborhood go-to's. From the outside, it's totally unassuming--honestly it looks kinda like a sloppy diner joint from the exterior. But, hey, don't judge a book by its cover. Because inside it is a gem. There's a beautiful city mural (my friend said it's of Istanbul) on the wall inside, and the atmosphere is nice. Their salad-- so affordable, ample serving size, and fresh (ask for no craisons, if you're not into those). Their pides (like a calzone, minus the pizza sauce) are delicious. I always ask for extra cooked spinach added into mine. Yum.
author: Hannah J.

description:
Get the rice pudding.  It's super tasty. 

Everything else I would say was solid but not amazing. Honestly mostly because I wanted more spice or other flavors. The base of everything is very good, and the pide bread is solid, but I wasn't dying to have more of anything because all the dishes were a bit bland.  But with some hot sauce, different story.
author: Amjad S.

description: They have a great selection of dishes that are fresh and delicious. Their prices are reasonable and their staff is attentive and friendly. Their hummus and eggplant salad are very tasty. Definitely recommend checking them out.
author: Steven K.

description: Amazing Turkish food with great service. Pide and beyti are strongly recommended. Location is also good, only 5 min walk to clubs and union square.
author: Ilker D.

description: I have experienced my fair share of Turkish restaurants and this is by far my favorite. From the staff to the chef. The food is prepared with love and passion. It is authentic Turkish food unlike others I have been to in the past. I have tried many things on the menu and you can't go wrong. They are all delicious. Some of my favorites are the Doner and Chicken Doner. The cold appetizers and chicken Sandwich are wonderful too. While the ingredients are simple the flavor is on point. Even though living 45 minutes away A La Turca is worth the drive!!! Give a try. Something for everyone. Oh and lastly I should mention the hand created desserts which are so tasty and wonderful without being over powering on the sugar. They are just right and I highly recommend them too!! Truly explore the menu everything is good!!! Can't wait to get back to eat here again!!
author: Holly U.

description: Where do I start, the food here is fantastic. I got the lamb shish kebab, and it was So good. The lamb was juicy and flavorful, and the rice and salad sides that came with it was also really good. I felt like the hummus was a little too mild, but over all the food was great. 10/10 would recommend.
author: Kara R.

description: For locals or travelers, you're missing out on a Frisco treasure if you don't stop into the delightful and quaint Ala Turca. I come to the Bay area from time to time on business and look for great ethnic cuisine. Ala Turca does not disappoint. From the crisp and flaky pastry appetizers to the delicious entrees of lamb, chicken and beef, you will leave full and your wallet intact. The prices are far from San Francisco  expectations and the kind and attentive service had me wondering if I was really on Geary street.  I was too full to try the desserts, but other reviews say they're great.
author: Chris B.

description: Four of celebrated Alicia's birthday with lunch today- sharing the combo cold appetizer plate and the combo grill platter - both excellent and delicious!  The kunafe dessert is always a highlight and a favorite.  We had a splendid time!
author: Geri S.

description:
Unexpectedly good meal. We got tired of waiting at the long line at Les Ros Thai (even at 9:30 pm on a Wednesday!) and ended up walking to A La Turca.

Got the:
* Chicken Beyeni - 5/5. Delicious. Buttery. Tastes a bit like a cheesy lasagna with large chunks of chicken breasts rolled into it. But looks more like chicken wrapped in tortilla covered in yogurt and tomato (?) sauce. With what seems to be hot liquid butter then poured over. Generous portion.
* Gozleme with Spinach and Cheese - 4/5. Two large thin pitas with a thin layer of spinach and cheese sandwiched between them. I appreciate the fact that it wasn't overwhelmingly cheesy and there was a good amount of spinach in here. Had a nice crunch to the pitas.
* Boregi - 4/5. Buttery puff pastry with spinach and cheese. A bit more heavy on the cheese ratio than the Gozleme but also really good. Who doesn't love a buttery puff pastry. Two small halves that come with a tomato and lettuce salad in olive oil. 

Also:
* Hummus - 4/5 they thought we ordered it and gave it to us on the house. Fresh and delicious, but not sure why it's marked as "spicy" on their online menu.
* Complimentary Bread - Pretty good. Very airy with a thick crust.
author: Sylvia L.

description: I started with warm bread and thick humus. The combo doner plate was very filling. The lamb was dry, the potatoes were slightly warm, the vegetables were fresh, and the rice was slightly glutinous.
author: James S.

description: The falafel here was very tasty. Flavorful and moist.
author: Jayne I.

description: Really living up to the expectations from yelp reviews. Very good service and the food soooo good. You have a lot for your money.
author: Jean N.

description: This place is packed at dinner time - even on a weekday.  I was there in the afternoon and it was pretty quiet though.  The service was real good and the food was excellent.  I only come to The City a few times a year but I will definitely eat here again.
author: Linda L.

description:
It was my first time trying Turkish food and I must say that this place did not disappoint!

Their Lamb Beyti is a must get!  Flooded with delicious garlic yogurt sauce and lavash filled with minced lamb, this plate is for the lamb lovers and sauce lovers!

As for their Chicken Iskender, the spiced up Chicken pieces tasted great. Eat it with their side yogurt and grilled, crispy, breaded semi-stuffing that was on the bottom of the chicken, then it is amazing!

I like how they have spices on the side - just in case you want to add more spices to your plate!

Don't expect fancy dining here, but a family-owned, low-key kind of restaurant.  The waiter takes awhile to warm up to you and was after all helpful.

A La Turca recommended!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Many years ago a serious "Foodie" took me to A La Turca for dinner. I have been back several times. I noticed they had a sign outside that stated they were under new management . The Turkish family that had opened the restaurant sold it. Outside, it looks the same except for the new management sign...but as soon as I walked in I knew it was very different. They didn't have all the placemats and other little things that were actually Turkish...I loved to go for a meal and watch Turkish Wheel of Fortune on the dust encrusted old "Big Screen" TV. I'm easily entertained...the waitress came to our table in a timely manner-with ice water! This, unfortunately, is where I realized that it was more than managers that left....God bless 'em, an Asian family bought the place so it was hard to ask questions regarding some of the menu items. My dinning partner that night had never eaten there or any Turkish restaurant so she did have questions...she tried but the waitress didn't communicate well with my friend. I live here and have lived here for 80% of my life so I understand all the different accents we have going on here. NOW...the important part, the food was very, very good. I ordered the chicken salad because I wasn't sure what was going to happen. It was way more than I could eat. Excellent! It came with a basket of fresh warm bread. My friend ordered something that our waitress could only say..."Like quesadilla...yes, like that" Whatever...well, it was fantastic and again, there was a lot of really good food. CHEAP...this place is so inexpensive, it makes me wonder why everybody charges so much? I mean it, we were out of there with a good tip under $30.00!  That's not normal though...one chicken salad does not make a meal...for some people. It was clean, great service, excellent value. It's just not as Turkish as it once was.
author: Rodney M.

description: This place is a gem! I've come her a few times with my Armenian friends to enjoy delicious food, much like what we grew up with. If you're not sure what to get, go with the sujuk pide. You won't regret it.
author: Allegra G.

description: The best "lamb kebab" in San Francisco! Portion size was perfect, service was great!!!
author: Galia R.

description: Wow!  Just wow!  Had their grill combo and loved every bite. I didn't lick the plate clean but that was only because I didn't want judgmental looks. The baklava was a little bit underwhelming. After the amazing food I expected it to melt in my mouth. It was very good but not as good as the other food. I'll be coming back!!
author: Jeff D.

description: Food was underwhelming lacks Chicken seasoning and flair. $45 bill but worth $20, i cant see how this place has 4 stars. Tye only thing that had somewhat of a flavor was the rice. I had to go get some gelato just to make myself feel better.
author: Adam S.

description: Super clean, with a great mural of the bay. Restrooms are very nice. Small but spacious. Food was amazing.
author: S S.

description: Having eaten in Turkey, I'd say this place is definitely anglicised. We got the Lahmacun app and got it with lavash bread as they were out of pide bread. I can definitely say I've had better as it wasn't very spicy and average. We then the adana kabab combo and the spinach and cheese gozleme. The kababs were delicious, but the gozlemes lacked flavour.
author: Ashmita V.

description: We been going to this place again and again. Great food with lovely presentations. Beef dishes are the best. I liked chicken Bayte with creamy sauce yogurt on the top. My favorite  drink is Ayran is delicious and after food Turkish coffee is must. People are very nice and Thank God next door parking garage place we feel very safe and convenient. Love to go back again.
author: Annie A.

description: I come here for the pides, combo platter, and tea. The Turkish tv going in the background, makes me feel connected to my 1/4 Turkish side!
author: Bobbi L.

description:
I am from L.A, visiting S.F., and when I saw that there was a Turkish restaurant near by I went. 

First of, the restaurant is located in a rough neighborhood. I did not feel safe walking down the street with my two little kids. 

Secondly, the owner did not seem very friendly, and the waitress was a-ok. Because I am Turkish, generally I make a lot of effort to try find and eat at authentic Turkish restaurants no matter how far they are. I like to believe that I am supporting my community. We are generally very friendly and welcoming people. When we meet a fellow Turk, we talk to them.  My kids were all excited to go to a "Turkish restaurant" and meet "Turkish people" but the staff and the owner (I am guessing the man I saw was the owner), seemed indifferent. But whatever, this is not that big of a deal that it would effect my decision to come back or not. 

Now, for the food... I tried iskender kebab, and sucuklu-kasarli pide. The pide was good. In fact, bread related anything seemed good. They brought over some brick oven heated bread with butter and that was absolutely delicious! However, the iskender kebap was less than mediocre. It was way too soupy. The chef had put way too much of the red tomato sauce on top of the dish. and instead of having grilled tomato and grilled spicy jalepeno pepper like you would traditionally on such a plate, there was one measly tiny pickle jalapeño sitting on top of the soupy dish, oh, and a black pitted olive next to it. 

Since I come from Bursa, which is the heart of Turkey that makes the Iskender Kebap dish, I am a bit of a connoisseur when it comes to this dish. Even though I wasn't expecting it to be at the same standard, this dish was definitely less than mediocre with presentation and taste.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Awesome food! Really cute interior - murals on the wall were very interesting to look at. Would come back!

- falafel platter
- forgot the appetizer name...
author: Beatriz G.

description:
A La Turca was a busy joint at dinner time. The 'Loin is its habitat, and has a feel of: a deli (deserts and some dish ingredients on display in a glass case)  / family run / try to remain true to authentic Turkish cuisine (although the cuisine varies quite a bit depending on the region in the homeland). A wide cultural swath of diners: tourists staying at the cheap hotels in the 'Loin, family's representing various ethnic heritages, wild eyed single diners.  

Super service, although it is is that varietal that needs to be summoned to take a request; the server was super responsive once a request was made. 

Alhambra Apartments sits across the street from A La Turca. Looking as though it was transported from Granada in Spain, it is an unexpected architectural treasure:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alhambra

http://www.sfaa.org/0708shurell.html

The food was good. Tasty but not over seasoned or over salted. Pida (bread) seemed to be a day (or more) old. Some of the dishes at our table:

Cacik (appetizer) $5.50 Yogurt with cucumber, mint, dill, and garlic.Cucumbers were pretty scarce.

Doner (platter dinner both the chicken and lamb version) $13.50 sliced ground lamb and beef (or chicken); served with rice, salad, and pide bread. Tasty. The lamb was a bit dry, but maybe it is meant to be doused in the yogurt sauce. The chicken was good and tender. 

Patlican Biber Kizartma $6.00 Deep-fried eggplant and green peppers served with red tomato sauce, garlic yogurt, and pide bread. Great/
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Cool little restaurant in the midst of sf downtown. 

This was my first time trying Turkish food so I wanted to go a little easy. Also, since I was ordering for one, I wanted to go a little easy. The doner dish was recommended to me by the gentleman behind me in line but I decided to order the Turkish pizza (I forgot the authentic name of the dish). It came with one naan cut into for pieces with ground beef on top and some tomato sauce. It also had a small side of salad. I took my meal to go and enjoyed it very much. The naan was soft and the beef was well seasoned. Next time I will definitely try the doner and Turkish tea. 

I recommend walking to this restaurant as there is not much parking near by. They also have lots of sweets in the glass cabinets which looked very tempting.  The lady who helped me was very sweet.
author: Rubab M.

description:
I was in this area for a sponsored party at a nearby bar and realized after a couple of drinks that I was in urgent need for dinner. There were a few Asian places and pizza-by-the-slice counter stores but figured a Turkish meal would be a treat. This place seems authentic and family owned.

I ate at a table by myself, which was fine. I was traveling on business.

I ordered cheese pide and chicken shish. Both were delicious. The pide is a french roll basically with melted cheese inside. Can't go wrong there. It was delicious but I only ate about half because it was filling. The chicken, side salad and white rice were excellent.

Fortunately, I still had room for dessert so had a baklava. It was like no other baklava I've had before -- large, moist and sweet. I almost went for the pistachio equivalent but stayed with what I knew. I could imagine the genie from Aladdin asking if I wanted a little more baklava but I only had one.

This restaurant is truly a Turkish delight and I'm glad I chose to have a dinner on a business trip here.
author: Eric W.

description: A La Turca is amazing!  I use them for catering for my office and my coworkers love the food. Nesip is just wonderful.  He is so helpful when I am planning the menu and working with him is a pleasure.  Plenty of gluten free and vegan options as well.  If you haven't tried A La Turca, I highly recommend them!
author: Keri C.

description:
I went to this place couple days ago,Actually I love Turkish food, But here the price was really expensive,and the portion was too small compare to the price, Service was too bad, our waitress didn't even smile, she was stressed out forgetting kinda small things like "Fork and Knife"
This was my first and last my experience at the restaurant "A LA Turkish!!!
author: Adilet C.

description: As someone from Turkey, it's tough to review Turkish restaurants. I go to this place when I crave for lahmacun (a thin pizza like dish - beef + lamb on a thin tough). It was good but not sufficiently salty and spicy. They also cut the lahmacun into small pieces which cools it too fast and you can't wrap salad in it. I still liked it and would go back. My friend liked the iskender as well although the gyro meet was a bit too thick... I also wish they had a better dessert selection. They only have dough-based, very sweet desserts. It would be nice to find the milk-based, lighter desserts such as kazandibi, muhallebi, etc.
author: Elif B.

description: Not sure if it is a glitch, I hope so. But we came for early dinner last week. It was a new server (I have not seen before). She hardly smiled, was pushy, and the food did not taste that fresh. The whole family wasn't happy. Even that we stayed in SFO for a few days, and I would have typically went more than once in one trip, we did not go back. We will think twice before going there for our next trip. I don't want to ruin my memory of their old good Turkish food.
author: Mohamed E.

description: Hands down the best and most fresh Turkish food around! I've been driving an hour for years to eat here. From the soups, to salads, kabobs and desserts, it's the most authentic. Not to mention great customer service!
author: Mitra K.

description:
This restaurant is located inTenderloin.
I had for lunch at 13:00 with my husband on Sunday, but we didn't need to make a reservation.

(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Atmosphere+++:
There were beautiful painted on the wall in the restaurant.
Pretty flowers were arranged on tables.

Service++:
Pretty kind and friendly. Workers are so nice. 

Value++:
Reasonable
_________________
Food

The served bread was a little warm and delicious.

Chicken Betyi +++:
This dish which was a beautiful decorated was chicken wrapped over  mild tomato sauce and yogurt sauce. The taste was so nice and healthy.
 
Comb Doner +++: 
The Lamb didnn't smell and the taste was light. I like it that rice of a side dish was so chewy.   
.
It was so nice that I want to go to this restaurant for dinner next time!
author: Hiromi S.

description: The food is good but the receptionist girl doesn't care about customer service and who ever she likes she gave them food has no respect for customers. She told me my good be ready in 15 but here I'm waiting more then 35 minutes and nothing is ready.
author: James J.

description: Modest setting but terrific Turkish food.  Excellent service. We went on a Thursday night... Had 3 fabulous main dishes:  Beyti Kebap - ground lamb in a flat bread served with special sauce and yoghurt;  the Combo Grill Plate; and the Spinach and Cheese Gozleme.  We also had:   Cacik - yoghurt with cucumber, mint, dill and garlic; and Piyaz - white bean, green bell pepper, onion, etc. All superb. The Beyti Kebap was incredible.
author: Laurence D.

description:
First time amazing!
Second time felt ok!
But it is a great place to try Turkish food with decent price! Highly recommend!
author: Shijia L.

description:
Food wise, this is my favorite Turkish restaurant in the bay area. Although, I would probably take my date to another Turkish restaurant (Tuba and Pera have nicer interior and better drinks for instance), when I am craving for some Turkish goodness, A La Turca is always the address. 

This is one of those places that you need to know what you should (and should not) order. For example their Cacik was probably the worst I have ever had in my life. I felt like I was drinking mayo so not sure what exactly was in it. I could only take a spoon and left the rest.

My favorites dishes: Cheese and Sucuk Pide, Lentil Soup, Baba Ghanouj, Lahmacun, Gozlemes. The platters are okay but those are pretty on par with other Turkish restaurants. As a dessert, Burma is divine and Baklava is pretty decent.

They also deliver for a reasonable fee so easier to check 'em out.
author: Gokhan T.

description: It's like a fun Turkish diner filled with Turkish people. The desserts are totally delicious, especially the one with sweet melty cheese. So good!
author: Andrew K.

description:
A la Turca is delicious. I don't remember why I had bookmarked this place to try, but I'm glad I did. There's so much good food in this neighborhood, but it helps to know where to go. 

I came in wanting something warm and simple and light, so I opted for the lentil soup and the appetizer plate with hummus, baba ghanoush, etc. Amazing. Lentil soup was super homey and comforting, light. It's made of lentil, onions, carrot, zucchini, maybe a little bit of rice, and all pureed. I've been back three separate times and each time I get the soup. I've since read that this lentil soup is a home comfort food for Turks. Maybe sort of like chicken noodle soup for Americans. Anyway, I totally get it. It's delish and makes whatever turmoil I'm going through okay.

The hummus and baba ghanoush are also great. My friend-who-is-married-to-an-Israeli says hummus and baba ghanoush are sometimes made with mayo, and that this one has mayo. Makes it super creamy, rich. (The Chinese word "nong" comes to mind, which means rich/strong/earthy in flavor and smell, very concentrated)

The guy next to me said the rice is good. I tried meat and rice my third time, as did my friends. A+ all around.

Don't take a word I'm saying seriously, because I don't want this place to get too packed!
author: C L.

description: Wonderful service, lovely ambiance, and delicious food. My table and I shared an excellent plate of tasty hummus with warm bread. I ate a great doner with cheese and lamb that was very filling. The bread was also made in house, well seasoned, and fluffy. The baklava was sweet and flaky, just how it should be! Washing it all down with a cup of Turkish coffee was just superb.
author: Jen A.

description: We're Turkish and we want to support Turkish restaurants in the city. We wanted some foods from there half an hour ago. It was the smallest lahmacun and pide I've ever eaten. I'm still hungry.
author: Elife K.

description:
Amazing food 
Awesome people 
Great hospitality 
Just love it
author: Dilgesh A.

description:
The food was very mouth-watering. I ordered a shish kebab with rice on the sides and a rack of lamb, and it's DEFINITELY better than you average Turkish restaurant. 

The location however, is probably where you wouldn't want to be at, but that's okay. It's better in the daytime when it's a lot safer to go and buy your food. 

Overall, I'd rate this restaurant 10/10 and it deserves a very good rating for the food and the customer service they have. Keep running, A La Turca!
author: Yuuki T.

description: I stopped to have lunch here two weeks ago. Asked to sit outside and was seated. The waiter and I exchanged glances for fifteen minutes until it dawned on him that he should give me a menu. I waited another fifteen minutes until he decided to take my order. Have you ever noticed how bad the service can be when a restaurant is empty? I left and will never return.
author: Carolyn G.

description: I just moved back to SF and since I haven't had a chance to buy groceries, I ordered from here. The food is so good and they give you huge portions. The Lahmacun is tasty, the pita bread is so good and fresh, and the combo Doner platter was delicious. I even had enough left over for lunch the next day. It's so good to be back in a city that has delicious food options. This place is definitely going to be on my go-to list from now on.
author: Joda L.

description: Yuuumm yumm!  Çok iyi :) Very good restaurant. Delicious food and nice atmosphere. Turkish food is my weakness. I longed for Lahmacun and here i found it, it's remind me about amazing time in Istanbul. I don't like this neighborhood (that's why 4****)... otherwise I would be here every day ;)
author: Emilia K.

description:
A nice Turkish restaurant tucked away in the corner of the Tenderloin. Its located across the street from Dominos. They have fresh lamb and chicken doner/gyro, not the frozen Kronos garbage most places falsely advertise. 

Their sandwiches are $8 and extremely filling whether its doner or falafel you will be satisfied. For $6 + you can get it with rice, I do think they can add a bit more rice to the entree but maybe its the SF in them. They have great tea and baklava as well.
author: Daanyaal K.

description: I usually will take anything i can take when it comes to turkish food but this place was just a no. The doner meat was overcooked, reheated, and crunchy. The menus and stuff were dirty. No, just no. Daphnes will even beat this place as an "authentic" turkish restaurant.
author: Melissa K.

description:
Get for an appetizer:  PATLICAN BIBER KIZARTMA- Fried eggplant and green pepper served with red house sauce garlic and yogurt. Super tasty. 

I followed it up with a lamp doner ( rolled in  crispy Turkish flat bread). You can use the leftover sauce from the first dish on it.
author: Ben Y.

description: Well before I start evaluating the food first I need to say that I am Turkish and I have tired all these food at their original places. The ground beef pide was so delicious and it was the first time I have had it in U.S. As most of the restaurants don't serve it. It definitely met my expectation and I enjoyed it a lot. We also ordered Iskender which was okay. I found it a little rich in spices and I am not a big fan of spices. Overall, I enjoyed the dinner and I can tell that they have good Turkish food.
author: Elif K.

description:
I have been to A La Turca too many times that I have already lost count. I found this place about a year ago when I wanted Kanafeh. I love A La Turca! All of their staff is really nice and helpful! 

This place is such a cute restaurant, I like the art displayed on the wall, the mural is beautiful.

As far as food goes I usually order Lamb Beyti, Kanafeh, Turkish Coffee, and hot Tea. These items are delicious! I have tried all of their appetizers and all of them have also been really tasty. 

...as far as the Kanafeh goes A La Turca has THE BEST KANAFEH! I have tried Kanafeh in many restaurants and have not been as delicious as A La Turca's. My sister who is a health freak will break her strict diet to have a whole Kanafeh!

I highly recommend A La Turca for their great service, staff, ambiance, and food!
author: Alondra J.

description:
Went with my hubby and our two kids for early dinner. 
Place is easy to find but you can't say the same for parking in the area. We had to make few turns around to find a parking spot and it was Sunday !
We entered the place and we smelled the aroma of freshly backed bread. We were seated promptly and menus were provided by our very friendly server. 
The kids got so excited and wanted to eat right the way so after a quick glance at the menu we ordered. 
The food is typical Turkish food, full of flavor and not too heavy. 
So we got :
Lamb and beef gyro plate with French fries. 3* -the meat was little dry and fries is too thick for my daughter liking 
Chicken gyro plate with rice pilaf -5* well cooked and perfectly seasoned 
Alexander kebab 4* the tomato sauce was very flavorful but meat again was on the dry site. 
Lahmadjun  5* just like when I eat it in istanbul. 
We also got fresh Turkish tea and delicious rice pudding for dessert. 
I will go again try their fresh simit and few other items on the menu.
author: Diana G.

description:
Was starving & walking along Geary I decided to try A La Turca Restaurant - a Turkish restaurant that was open Sun 3/25/12 for lunch.

Stuff I saw that I should have gotten: lentil soup - looked good; Eggplant dip - I love dip!

FREE homemade bread (2 big pcs) - which it came with some kind of sauce or something

I got instead Chicken Doner Platter $9 - scoop of rice, lots of little chicken pieces (a bit dry), salad, small container of yogurt dressing.  Just ok, nothing special.

A. got a green bean/minced meat lunch special $7 - I thought it was just ok.

Credit cards minimum $10.  Our total with tax, before tip, was $17.63.

Separate bathrooms in the back.
author: Ann L.

description:
I stopped into A La Turca yesterday with the intent of loading up on some hummus and lentil soup in an attempt to stay away from carbs, which I have been over-indulging in all holiday break.

The staff helping me quickly assembled some hummus for me, some grilled eggplant dish, a serving of lentil soup, and then I noticed that they even put in two heaving sizes of pide bread for me. I winced at the sight of the bread. It looked incredible. But the point of my visit here was to avoid bread and starches.

I grabbed my bundle of A La Turca goodness and began walking back to the office. I could feel the heat of the bread inside it's paper bag encasing. I was adamant about not eating it though. Nope. I would stick to the hummus, soup, and eggplant, and leave the bread for someone else.

As soon as I arrived in the office I tried some of the soup. It was sadly a disappointment. It was watery and lacked flavor. I moved onto the hummus. It was fantastic with great flavor. The grilled eggplant was also quite good - but very oily and rich and I had trouble stomaching it. I stuck to the hummus and dipped carrots hungrily into it.

But that bread...

That bread still called to me. I made a deal with myself to just try a little of it. I broke it off. It was thick and doughy and still warm. Divine. I took a bite of it. It was incredible. Topped lightly with sesame seeds and bursting with softness. I couldn't help myself. I ate both servings of it with fervor. And then sat back down in my office chair looking at the crumbs around me.

A La Turca isn't exactly going to be doing your waistline any favors. Most of their non-meat dishes are full of cheese and bread. But if you're OK with that - then by all means come here and go big. All of their pies are baked fresh on premises - as is their bread. I can't recommend their lentil soup - but everything else is worth a try.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: I love Turkish food and this restaurant was such a disappoitment, we came 4 for early dinner. Started with the restroom ... Bad ... Probably had to walk away after seeing the restroom condition. Plates were dirty and had to ask to replace. All four main plates  we took were bad ... The only thing that was eatable was the bread and the appetizer platter ... Now I need to deal with terrible heartburns.
author: Yolanda S.

description: Food is amazing. Service was very good. Been here several times. Really like the quality of the meat and bread. Would recommend my friends and family come here especially on Saturday!
author: Bentley D.

description:
Let me start by saying that I adore Turkish cooking. That said, my meal at Ala Turka was just average, and quite frankly, disappointing. I ordered a meze sampler which was probably the best thing I ate. While the bread was not piping hot, I enjoyed most of the meze offerings particularly the eggplant salad, hummus, and cacik. I ordered the lentil soup which was too thick and lacking in seasoning. Additionally, the texture was gritting and not smooth as I have had at other restaurants. My entree was Iskender kebap. The bread cubes should have been buttery and fresh. Instead they were cut too small, burnt and not very buttery. The doner meat was lacking seasoning as was the tomato sauce on top. The best thing on the plate was the yogurt.

While it was not my favorite meal, it was also not the worst thing I have ever eaten. It was edible but just completely underwhelming. I will likely not return and would not recommend it to my friends or colleagues.
author: Lina L.

description: This restaurant locates on a big street and it is easy to find and park. When you enter in the restaurant , they will give you some homemade bread. There are a lot of Turkish painting on the wall and the restaurant plays turkish TV shows. It makes you feel  like in the Turkey. Talking about food, I will recommend you have to try a series combo like soup plus plates and tea. The food is really fresh and worth the price. The service is really cool because you can whisper to call waiters like a true turkish! It is a good place for not only turkish who wants to recall the flavor of hometown but also tourists who want to try exotic food!
author: Pin Chun C.

description: This restaurant is an absolute gem. Great environment; very cozy and comfortable seating. Everything I've tried here is delicious. Best baba ghanouj I've ever had! The pita bread is warm and fresh and the Turkish tea is delightful. For the prices, this place is completely worth it.
author: Kaylee V.

description:
Ordered the lamb doner / shvarma and it was pretty bad. The meat didn't look like real pieces of meat, more like some artificial purée.
The service wasn't great either, had to wait for 20 minutes for them take my check with the credit card (ultimately just went to the cashier not to waste any more time)
author: Ivan B.

description:
I can't tell if it's multiple trips to Istanbul that have raised my bar on Turkish food, or if A La Turca's just slipped quality-wise recently, but my dinner here was positively mediocre. Two of the three dishes we tried (lahmacun, lentil soup) were woefully under seasoned.

I was decently pleased with the İskender kebap but overall, the best part of the meal was the warm, fresh bread.
author: Miriam W.

description: Food is amazing. The service isn't the best but I think it's just the lady that took my order. She wasn't friendly at all. But if none of that matters to you then the food is great and cheap.
author: Moawia E.

description:
I love Turkey. The savoriness. The dark skin. I especially like it with giblets and green beans with a can of cream of mushroom soup on top. Oh wait...you mean the country. Yeah, I love the country, too, and their food. Just call me a whirling dervish... just not a nervous nellie. I've been wanting to come here for ages, so I finally convinced Jamie W. to take the overpacked 38 Geary to the heart of the Tenderloin to give this family-run place a try. It looks like what you'd expect... kinda like a big luncheonette deli with a big animated mural of Turkey on the long side wall.

Menu items are quite traditional at least from my recollections of Istanbul restaurants. Execution feels very home-style like you're at a Turkish relative's house if you have Turkish relatives. I don't so I actually don't know what I'm talking about, and it wouldn't be the first time. Anyway, we started with a couple of appetizers. First up was the $4.25 Lahmacun, two mini-turnovers that look like spanikopita only with ground lamb and green peppers, tomato, onion and spices (see photo). Tasty though it's hard to go wrong with filo dough. Next was marginally disappointing, the $4.95 Kiymali Borek, which I was hoping would be like the roadside Turkish lamb pizza you can get at bus stops along the Turquoise Coast (see photo).

No such luck - it was just pastry wedges, a little overcooked, with ground meat, onions and spices slathered on top. Entrees continued the lamb theme, as well as the hit-and-miss average. Mine was quite good and relatively straightforward, the $11.75 Lamb Shish Kebab Platter, which is strictly cubes of roasted leg of lamb, marinated with spices, and served with their house rice, a side salad and a yogurt sauce (see photo). Delicious and unadorned. Jamie ordered the $11.25 Beyti Kebap Platter, another lamb dish, ground but wrapped in lavash and served with a yogurt sauce (see photo). It was just a fancied-up shawarma and not a very satisfying one at that.

We did love the desserts. Jamie ordered the $4.25 serving of Baklava, very sweet but genuinely irresistible. I went with rest-home bland and loved it... the $4.95 Sutlac, a little crock of rice pudding heavy on the milk and baked in he oven to produce a nice hard topping. Our bottom-line verdict is that we liked it, didn't love it. I think they do a good job serving up the platters of authentic food, but I have to admit it wasn't all that distinctive in flavor as I think back on the meal. Oh well, let me go back to my whirling...

FOOD - 3 stars...authentic, home-style Turkish fare, a bit hit-and-miss but great desserts
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...love the mural, pretty casual
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...efficient for sure, not that warm
TOTAL  - 3 stars...I still love turkey...and Turkey
author: Ed U.

description:
This place is great!  I eat there every week before a class I'm taking nearby.  The neighborhood is, well, it's the tenderloin.  But great good, great service, great value

Foods I've enjoyed
Lamb shops (super yummy)
Chicken kebab
Babaganoush
author: Kevin F.

description:
Good, solid, but nothing special
On the other hand, right value for the money (not overpriced)
author: Sergei B.

description:
I was so excited to try this place before heading to a show at the Regency with friends. But, it ended up not meeting expectations. The baba was really bland, though the bread it comes with is very thick and tasty. The combo kebab plate was also underwhelming, with not as much meat as I would have expected.

My friends ordered the sandwiches, which are really wraps, and they are HUGE so I would try that instead.
author: Amy Y.
