description:
This place is a little oasis in the abyss of the T.L. The food is amazing and freshly 
prepared accompanied by homemade pide and a comforting ambiance. I cannot recommend it enough!
author: Theresa M.

description: Don't patronize this restaurant!!! Although the food was tasty this is not a safe place to eat. My daughter and I had dinner here before attending the theater because she wanted Turkish food and it was close by. That night she got food poisoning! I had read that there were issues with cleanliness so I had my doubts about eating here. She had ordered the Iskender kebab. Well they were confirmed when she told me she got sick. They should be reported to the health department!
author: Felicia K.

description: A real step down from my last visit.  The bread that came with my soup was over warmed and hot. The lamb chops were cut thin and not a $20 plate.  Disappointed.
author: Phyllis M.

description:
Overall that was a damn fine meal. 

I went with the lamb kebab which was perfect. The spices were right, the rice was tasty the vegetables fresh. Damn good food overall. 

My only qualms with this place is that I feel like for what you pay you get a little less than you should vs. other Turkish/Mediterranean/Persian places in the area. Also at one point we began to fill a bit rushed as they have limited seating and I know they wanted us out to sit additional customers.
author: Jared P.

description: If you're expecting good food this isn't your place I ordered 4 donar Sandwich for pick up with my friends , the meat was so dry and old and sandwich bread was very old and bad(like stone). once we got home, my stomach began to feel uneasy and nauseous . I was quite shocked to see this place serve food of such low quality. This will probably be my first and last time visiting this restaurant.
author: Sean R.

description:
This place is a neighborhood gem.  I want to say it's family owned, and anytime we have come in there, someone's making something with love.

They bake the desserts fresh in the morning, we've been blessed enough to come in when they come fresh out of the oven.

Come take a seat any time day or night, the food is delicious.  I love the lentil soup, it has a hint of mint which gives it a crisp taste.  I'm a simple charred meat kind of gal so the lamb chops are my favorite.  It comes with this rice that doesn't make any sense delicious.  Then finish off with a turkish coffee and something from the assorted baklava-style desserts.  We like the rolled pistachio one, and they don't skimp on the pistachio either!

That's pretty much my meal there, this pretty much can feed 2 people so I either share or just take home for later.

The people watching is so fun.  There are lots of locals, hangry party goers, tourists.  If it's nice enough you can even enjoy your coffee outside on a bistro set.
author: Isa H.

description:
I'd give 4.5 stars.  I would have preferred to been approached at least one more time, after the main course was severed, asked how the food was and if they could get us anything else.

I loved the special yogurt sauce.  I actually had to ask for more sauce to finish my plate.  Ordered #65, #33, #17 appetizer.
author: K K.

description: I am sorry but this spot is not good. I ate here often several years back, but my recent visit was disappointing. Service was forced & awkward, the iskender kebab I ordered tasted all wrong - like jarred italian tomato sauce & bland.
author: S. R.

description:
Love that there is so many vegetarian options

+ EZME- Crushed roasted red and green bell pepper, tomato,
onion, parsley. Very refreshing and mildly spicy! 

+ HUMMUS - Garbanzo beans puree with garlic lemon juice,
tahini and spices. Not to bad, not gritty at all. Nice and smooth and creamy

+LENTIL SOUP- Red lentils with rice, carrots, onion, potato and spices. Yum!!!! Their lentil soup is abbbsolutely delicious! They give you a slice of lemon as well to squeeze on top. Very refreshing!! If I am are sick this is my type of perfect homemade comfort food!

+ PATLICAN BIBER KIZARTMA- Fried eggplant and green pepper served with
red house sauce garlic and yogurt. Very nice and crunchy, not soggy!

+CHICKEN DONER- Marinated chicken roasted in front of vertical spit fire and sliced. I am a pescetarian and my boyfriend usually gets this dish. The flavors are delicious!!!! I always just have a small bite so I can at least have some of that awesome sauce!

+ FALAFEL PLATTER- Served with humus, tahini sauce and salad. Their falafel is perfectly crispy, moist inside and never dry. That garlic sauce dip is KILLER! And that spicy chili sauce is to die for!

I havent tried any of the desserts yet

Conclusion: This place is absoooolutely delicious at a reasonable price. However, I noticed that they raised their prices since the last time I was there about 2 months or so ago. The chicken donner originally was around 9.75-$10 when we first tried this place and the appetizers were $4.99 or so. Awesome deal, right? Well, now the donor is around 14.75 and the appetizers are 5.75.  Prices are still within reason but if they raise their prices one more time we might have to find another Turkish restaurant. Especially since its in the TL and serving mostly vegetarian food that is made with cheap ingredients.  I would have given Turca 5 stars, but with that price hike I could only give em 4.
author: Julia D.

description:
Last night was my first time there and I am also somewhat unfamiliar with the cuisine. But this is such a friendly family-run place I felt right at home. They seemed thrilled to explain the menu to a newbie. 

And the food was awesome! Flavorful and interesting. Even the rice is incredible. How do they do it? Prices seemed quite reasonable to me. $30 for two hungry people and we left food on our plates because we had stuffed ourselves silly. Then we sat and talked for an hour which seemed de rigueur. 

Wow! Add this to my favorites short-list!
author: Bruce B.

description:
Very disappointed, bland tast, they are very expensive.
Took our order wrong. Poor communication with server. Ask for chicken brought us Lamb. Asked for straw they said they don't have any. Asked for extra rice. We didn't get that at all.
author: Hefty G.

description: The food was amazing! We enjoyed every bite!! I had the chicken doner and it was delicious!! Portions are huge and keep well for the next day or later that day. :)
author: Maira S.

description:
Chicken Beyti is delicious. The sauce is to die for. It was heaven! And then the rice pudding... OMG! 
Huge portions- easily two meals for the beyti. The rice pudding to go serves at least two people. 
The service is friendly and the exact right speed. The tea is delicious too. Price is very reasonable for the quantity and quality of food. Oh yeah the bread! The bread is all baked fresh and is sort of like the optimum fluffy chewy pizza crust, in a Turkish kind of way. Perfect. 
I don't eat lamb, but I'm told their Lamb Beyti is phenomenal too.
author: Dana W.

description: I've been to a la turca at least ten times over the last 6 years and must say it's one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. The fresh bread they serve is just as good as it gets in any restaurant. I would almost home back exclusively for their lentil soup, which goes very well with the awesome fresh bread they serve. The staff is Turkish,so this place must be authentic, I think. Price to value ratio is also great, so what else can you ask for. Definitely recommend this place to anyone on yelp.
author: Herman R.

description:
Chicken and Cheese Gozleme
Sauteed chicken with feta and mozzarella.
Very Good
There was more bread than I thought we were going to eat - but the bread was thin and very tasty - and we froze some for later!
The three different salads that came with our order - the salads were made with different kinds of vegetables - good salads - I think the salads were the best part of our order because I love salads late at night. 
My husband loves Baklava - I ordered a piece for him and he said it was the best he ever had - the piece I noticed was larger than what you would normally get.
author: Andrrs B.

description:
First time here for dine in,,,, warm welcome from server Diana,,,nice first impression,,,I was offered a warm Turkish style black tea.
     I am pure vegetarian,so I was suggested to try gozleme ( tomato and cheese) ,,with revani cake as dessert on last,,,,,,, 
     So good experience,,,,, anyone should try this place,,,,
  tnx for the second cup of red tea before I leave,,,,,
author: Feroz C.

description:
Pretty solid Turkish food. Fast and efficient service for lunch on a Sunday. We had Sigara Boregi pastry filled with feta for appetizer which was good. Also the Havuc Kizartmasi.. it's fried carrots and even though it was cooked well and tasted good, prob could've skipped due to it being very simple. 
For main dish, I had the Lamb Sish Kebab, very good taste and nice size, wish it was bigger though.. Pricey at $16. Partner had the Iskender Kebap which was yummy and very big!  
This place is always packed in the evenings and does not look much from the outside.. we walk by it all the time since we live in the neighborhood. Glad we tried it and will come back.
author: Vol T.

description: Staff was great, very friendly. The food was regretfully lackluster. My lamb kebab was burned. Not caramelized, charred or "flame kissed". Just hard little black nuggets. The rice had way too much butter(margarine) in it. As did my friends iskendar kebap. Mint tea was great.
author: hd r.

description: I've been twice. The first time was with my boyfriend. He ordered chicken shish and I had potato and cheese pide. Both were delish, plus the manager gave him a side of yogurt and me dessert on the house. This time I hosted a group dinner there. The manager was very accommodating; I had made a reservation for many, but he didn't mind that not all showed up. He also gave us separate checks, which was helpful with a large crowd. The restaurant gave us a lot of food, whether we ordered appetizers, entrees, or desserts. My one complaint is some of my chicken shish was a little gristly and inedible. Otherwise, the food was very delicious, varied, and the staff friendly and helpful.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Best turkish food I've had in the city! Very reasonable prices and there's never a wait for a table. Highly recommend the lentil soup and beef shish kebab.
author: Griffin D.

description:
One word: beyti. 

Two words: so good.

There are two different beytis offered at A La Turca: 

1) Beyti Kebap for $15.75, which is: Ground lamb wrapped in flat bread; served with special sauce, yogurt, rice, and salad.
2) Chicken Beyti for $14.50, which is: Chicken breast wrapped in flat bread with a touch of red sauce, yogurt, and butter. Served with rice and salad.

The Beyti Kebap is a lot better - the gaminess of the lamb is offset by the flat bread wrap as well as the yogurt, while the chicken can be slightly overwhelmed by all the mild factors.

Another delicoius try is the Combo Doner for $13.75: Chicken, beef, and lamb doner thinly sliced; served with salad, rice, and pide bread. This is actually a great deal of food on a sizeable platter and is enough for two (or more, if sharing other dishes)

USEFUL: Pide bread = Pita Bread. Kebap = Kebob
author: Joshua L.

description:
How to be a Cheap Date:

1) Choose a restaurant in the Tenderloin.
2) Don't order alcohol.
3) Order one dish only.  
4) Chew gum after your finishing your entree so you don't feen for dessert (which pads up the bill).
5) Talk about the Chanel Quilted Lambskin Single Flap Handbag that you've been eyeing at Saks.

Oppsie. Hey, I said "cheap date" ok? Didn't say anything about being a cheap gf...

Before my Yelp days, I frequented A La Turca when I needed a kofte, doner, and sish fix. I liked it enough to come here a handful of times especially when two can leave stuffed for less than $30. 

Mr. NSS never had Turkish food before and not wanting him to blow a gasket over the dinner bill, I thought A La Turca would be a good place to bring him. 

A La Turca is just as I remembered it, cobble stone entry way, an open kitchen with vertical spits, earthy toned décor, and a somewhat cozy dining room. 

We started with the Kiymali Borek ($4.95) which is like a Turkish empanada filled with ground beef, onion and spices. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=vkynJm-9v8XlNWnZZGJCxg#I_7wQteuJoh0I5v1tWpRJg Mediocre at best, the beef filling was both scant and dry. The dry pastry shell lacked a delicate flakiness. One of my favorite Turkish dishes is the Lamb Beyti ($11.25) which is ground lamb wrapped in lavash and then topped with garlic yogurt. Not here. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=vkynJm-9v8XlNWnZZGJCxg#glfQSYWyOsojumIMdogbtw Like a horrific aftermath of a gangbang (sorry, I just had to), the beyti was severely over-sauced with yogurt sauce making the lavash incredibly wet and soggy on the bottom. The Combo Grill Meat Platter ($13.50) "used to" be my go-to dish at A La Turca. Keywords: "used to". http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=vkynJm-9v8XlNWnZZGJCxg#4EzU1IzD3oOaGn27J4GW_A The lamb sish (lamb cubes), kofte (lamb & beef patty), doner (shaved ground lamb and beef) & beef sish (beef cubes) were all very well-seasoned and flavorful, BUT they were ALL overcooked and dry. The doner was the worst of the quad and had the texture of shoe leather. 

Service is pleasant as you would expect from a family-owned restaurant. We were one of three customers on a Monday night so the food came out fairly quickly but the times I've visited when it was busy, food service was very slow. 

If you need a Turkish fix, go to Troya in Inner Richmond (my review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/troya-san-francisco#hrid:z2rd1mAYwRonuYfJdLRfHQ) and NOT the one in Pac Heights (my review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/troya-fillmore-san-francisco#hrid:XROisJ5mSrOCzn5QfBPMvg). 

Mr. NSS: "You must have come to A La Turca before you became expensive." 

Me: "Excuse me... what did YOU just call me?!?!"

*Cricket Cricket*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This place was bomb.  If you never had Turkish food, I would say you would soon fall in love.  We came here for a birthday party and made reservations a week in advance.  They have a separate seating area on top for a big party.  The waiter was a very friendly man who was Turkish himself.  Right there makes the restaurant that much better.  Sorry, but I can't really go for a place that isn't owned by the ethnicity, just doesn't make sense.  

I ordered the Lamb Beyti.  It looks like a burrito and it tastes 10x better.  It has good sauce, good meat, good everything.  The meat dishes look delicious as well and they serve good portions.  I shared my dish with the gf and we were both full.  When we were all done with dinner, the waiter came with deserts for the entire table for free.  It was very nice of him and something like that I would want to come back for.  Will be visiting here again. 

FYI: I didn't drive here, but don't forget it is in the Tenderloins.
author: Justin Y.

description:
Love that they deliver! Hate the steep service charge on top of delivery charge. Orders come with single (very large) bready pita. When you order the hummus or yogurt dip, it doesn't not include pita.
Meat was cooked perfectly as requested at delivery. Delivery was fast too. Yay! Delicious Turkish food delivered?! Get out of here! Just don't forget to save up for a couple of months for the service charge!
author: Piper W.

description: The doner meat combo was delicious and filling, the rice was very flavorful, and the bread was chewy and tasty.
author: Patrick M.

description: Food was AMAZING, I wrote 2 reviews that's how strong I felt about the quality of food!
author: James E.

description:
I've been eating here for years but it never occurred to me to review it here. Tonight, however, I had a great experience due to the courtesy of a man named Ayhan who made my takeout order special and kept my Turkish cup full of hot tea while I waited.  He was lovely and personal and I'm pretty sure he made sure my large order had some extra bread for my houseguest.  The food was delicious and speedy, and the cook (who I think has been there forever) was sure to sling me a smile as he always does. 
Thank you for hanging through all the neighbourhood changes, guys. You're always busy so I think things are going great!
author: Drew B.

description: My friend was on a business trip to SF and we decided to hang out. While searching for a place to eat, we decided to go for Turkish food and based on the Yelp review we chose this place. We were seated right away. Since I never had Turkish food before, I started out with bunch of questions on the menu. The waiter was very patient and explained in depth what the dishes consist of.  It didn't take us that long to get our food, but I was  disappointed with my order. I had something with beef and the meat was super dry and flavorless. The only thing I enjoyed from my plate was the salad. My husband had something similar to mine with chicken and had the same issue.
author: Fereen A.

description: The food is amazing i v been there 2 times and i will go there again ask for juan the cooker he  is a magicien!
author: Belhasen A.

description: I like this resturant they have middle eastern food like shish kabab and sweet food like konafa ,the staff friendly ;))
author: Ahmed A.

description: Great service, delicious food. Went there hungry and left satisfied. This was my second time eating at A La Turca. The first time was on Thanksgiving. My husband, sister, sisters boyfriend and I were hungry and wanted a late night snack. We called A La Turca and they were closing in less than five minutes. They stayed open late so that we could pick up our order of lahmacun. We brought it back to my husband and I's hotel room and the four of us grubbed. It was delish. I went back home to Tahoe and I couldn't get A La Turca  out of my mind. I am back in the city and my sister and I went and dined at A La Turca for dinner. Service was great and the food was amazing. We ordered the Lahmacun again, Sigara Boregi a side of Cacik and left a little room for dessert, kunefe and tea. All super yummy. I will be back.
author: Dema S.

description:
The food was not memorable from my last visit long long time ago (pre-Yelp days). But then again, I didn't have my trusty friend along like I did this time. My friend Al W dines here quite often and has a few favorite dishes.

Chicken Beyti (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=vkynJm-9v8XlNWnZZGJCxg): One of his favorites. On the menu, it didn't sound like much. Chicken wrapped in lavish bread with yogurt and butter. But when the dish arrived, wowee looked so delicious! The plate filled with the chicken wrap and a generous amount of yogurt in the middle. A+ for presentation! Taste-wise, the chicken and the red sauce had tons of flavors. The yogurt added a slight tang and a great temperature contrast to the hot wrap. Yummy!

Doner & Mozzarella Pide (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=71zn4Sdw2xJ_noq6PflogQ): I ordered the lamb doner pie. The lamb was prepared by spit-roasting, then sliced and baked with cheese in the dough. The result? A delicious stuffed pie! The lamb was not at all gamey. Just the right amount of mozzarella so the lamb was not lost in the dish. Love the use of black and white sesame seeds. Toasty flavors and crunchy texture!

Their complimentary bread was awesome too! Straight from the oven. Hot and delicious! =D
author: Marti L.

description:
This place is great. 

Went for lunch.

The Hummus and fresh Pite Bread is amazing. 
The Lentil Soup was excellent. 
The Doner sandwich on Pite Bread was huge and tasty, so step up from the Lavash wrap. 

I will definitely go back.
author: Mike L.

description:
Pretty dang authentic Turkish food!

We were walking to Union Square and my stomach started a very loud symphony. At that exact moment, we were standing in front of this place, so I decided that it's a sign I must eat here. 

We ordered the tripe soup $4.95 and the chicken gyro $5.95. Now, I was just in ate my way through Turkey several months ago, and I have to say this place is extremely authentic. They even have the pistachio twisted Baklava, which I've never seen anywhere in the US. The warm fresh pita bread with olive oil was so good, I ate 2 large pieces even tho I'm on the low carb diet. 

Great ambience, friendly service, good prices = Happy Dani.
author: Dani S.

description: Awesome again. If you can hang in the TL then this is the place. Delicious food, fresh and tasty. God portions and very friendly staff. Try the sampler appetizers ti get the full effect
author: Matt A.

description: I have three people now who found they love Turkish food after being very skeptical that they would find anything they like on the menu... my two sons and my best friend. This is the place my parents and I enjoy whenever we can get to the city. It is as authentic as the food we ate in southern Turkey when I was a child. Also, my best friend, on her visit there with me, was treated to a dessert free of charge and delicious it was! I will take others any time :)
author: Leisa H.

description: Have eaten here several times, the food is quite good and reasonably priced. a very casual place. Love the pide bread. I have not been to Turkey , but have tried Turkish food various places around (Spain, Netherlands, various other places in US) and this seems to be authentic based on what I have seen.. They sell Turkish beer, which is good too!  Turkish music videos on the TV.. Turkish women are so beautiful!  Very good desserts!  try the burma. at $5 it is a little pricey, but a lot of work goes into making that dessert.
author: Mark N.

description:
What can I say about this place. My boyfriend took me here and I was skeptical at first...which quickly changed. The service is good. The food AMAZING. 

I had the lamb kabob that comes with rice and a salad. It is my favorite thing here on the menu. The price is good for the amount of food that you receive. I would also recommend having it with the Turkish tea (if you like tea). 

We have had other things on the menu that are just ok - but like most places in SF they do one thing really well. This place it is the kabob's and rice. If you are in the mood for that - go here - you won't be disappointed. 

We have come back several times and the service and the food are consistently good.
author: Apryl H.

description:
The doner sandwiches are terrible. And the service seems to have gotten worse since i first dined here. The waiters and waitresses seem to forget which tables they were attending too and are not even responsive to  eye contact by customers. Very unprofessional...

A month later:

And now the owner seems to be harassing me for this review using the "F" word.
author: Ramoun M.

description:
Whoa! Really good turkish food. 
We had spinach & cheese pide and lamb dish. Both were excellent! I'm usually not a bread eater.. but it was really good with the plate. Nothing fancy about the restaurant or the food, but it felt like a family-run business. I would come back for those dishes!
author: Sue K.

description:
I love this place

i have been coming for more than 5years and this place had the best Turkish food that i know of in sf. The food here is always fresh and taste amazingly time i come here i almost order the same thing.

the Lentil soup, with their home made bread that smells amazing.  i also get the Turkish tea that is always made fresh. i order the Turkish version of the calzon with cheese and fresh tomatoes and the BBQ chicken kebab's that have the right amount of marinate on it
author: Seaera T.

description:
i passed by this place every week and had no idea that it even existed!  

one day, i decided to hop on a bus and ta-daaaa!  saw a la turca right out the window...quickly pulled out my phone, yelped, and bookmarked it.

the next day...we were here!  we have never experienced turkish food and couldn't wait to try it.  first off, i have to say that the service is super friendly.  the lady assisted us in making decisions since we were clueless.  

wifey and i decided to try the chicken beyti...chicken wrapped in lavash bread with yummy red sauce, yogurt, and butter.  wifey and i almost had to duke it out for the last piece...it was perfect...wouldn't change anything about it. 

we also tried the combo doner...thinly sliced chicken, beef, and lamb doner served with rice and salad.  i'm not a lamb person but i have to say that this stuff was addicting.  the tzaziki sauce was the perfect touch for all 3 meats.  we also had a yummy warm bread basket to start off with.  the doner was good...but next time, i've got to try the pide which is a calzone type looking thing.

there's always room for dessert!  we tried the sutlac...rice, milk, and sugar...baked in the oven...a really yummy rice pudding topped with pistachios...you can't go wrong with this dessert...a must order every single time we go there!

i saw that there was a specials menu once you walk in...i'd probably order something off of that sometime...it looked intriguing.  

oh, and the place filled up pretty quickly on a weekday...looked like a bunch of regulars...and almost every table ordered the combo appetizer plate...just looked like a lot for the two of us.  haha.

what an awesome turkish food experience...we don't have much to compare it too...all i know is...that my tastebuds were super happy.  good stuff!!!
author: Jen W.

description: Well evwrytime I visit SF , i hit there for turkish food. Average quality but affordible. Can take  little facelifting. Geary St may be funny watch out..
author: Mehmet A.

description: Good food with reasonable price! Love chicken Shish with house-made bread.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
If I could give them unlimited stars, I wouldn't. Because this place has no need for it. They know they are good! They got their things together!

I've probably been there over hundred times but they always make feel happy. Super delicious, mouthwatering, good quality turkish/Mediterranean food and just very very very kind people! The man who runs this place is extremely professional and knows his cooking and how to run a biz!

I'm overwhelmed by this restaurants delicious food, helpful and kind people who run the place, and just the atmosphere man!

I left my heart in Ala Turca!
author: Aselle N.

description:
oh beyti kebab, my newest discovery and crush. you are so tasty. Especially here where you are probably better than hayes and kebab. for the uninitiated, beyti is some kofta kebab (ground lamb+beef) wrapped in lavash bread covered in tomato sauce and yogurt and chopped up. it's amazing.

I like the appetizer bread they give here is pretty tasty as well.
author: Misha T.

description:
I googled best cheap eats in SF and an article by 7x7 popped up.  A La Turca was at the top of their list and it was Turkish, a cuisine I've always wanted to try. I ordered what 7x7 recommended, the Beyti Kabap and the Sucuk Pides. I had no idea what a pides was so I was happy to learn that it was cheesey goodness wrapped in the right amount of soft fluffy dough. The pides I order also had little bits of meat sausage in it. For the meat, I was expecting a different texture than a meat stick that's been slice into little pieces and mixed into the cheese. Still good.  

My Beyti Kabap was very good and plentiful.  Ground lamb mixed rolled in dough with a heaping of delicious yogurt. I think this dish was meant to be shared but piggy me at the whole thing. I also got some delicious bread to go with my meal. It came in two halves and I only had room to finish one. When I asked for a bag to take the other half home, the waiter brought out a bag with more bread in it to add to the slice I already had.  That was a nice surprise.  A bigger surprise came at the end of the meal when the waiter brought out this delicious cake that was soaked in honey. SO GOOD!!!

I also wanted to add that I ordered the Turkish Coffee because I've never had it before.  It came in a little espresso cup and had a dark sludge at the bottom. I didn't know what to do with the sludge so I left it in the cup.  When the waiter came by to pick up my coffee, he looked at the sludge and said, "What? You don't want your future to be told?" Seriously, it was a weird moment. I didn't know what to say or do so I just smiled and he just laughed. 

Overall, it was a wonderful meal and I can't wait to go back and share this place with my husband.
author: Aimey T.

description:
I been coming to this place quite a bit and it's seriously it's always a welcoming place the prices are super reasonable and the staff is always friendly and attentive. When I go there I always get a side order of  Baba ghanoush dish and it's the best I've ever had its seasoned right and the constancy is perfect, the bread is another delicious thing they make there it's made right at the restaurant and I've had a few times rolls that where fresh out of the oven BOMB!! My other dish I recommend is the pides there delicious. 

Overall my  experience at A La Turka had always been great highly recommended.
author: Josh R.

description:
Favorite mediterranean place in the TL.

Combo platter for the appetizer can feed 4, massive and super flavorful choices to dip the warm housemade pita bread. (Cacik was my favorite,Eggplant salad was the bf's choice- wonderful smokey flavor)

Shared the Lahmacun (almost like pizza style), super thin crust, crisp. 

Main course, I had a Pide, chicken and mushroom. Not very exciting, but simple and delicious. the bread itself if just perfect.

And I am trying to figure out the name for the dish my bf ordered. He loves asking the servers what they like and this chick was awesome enough to point at her three favorites. Hate it when you ask, and their suggestion "everything is good here"..
this was lamb, wrapped in pastry dough, tomato sauce around and yogurt. it was absolutely devine. 

For dessert, we asked her to pick that out for us, and got the Kadayik, Shredded phyllo dough with pistachios. I secretly wanted to try that, so #win on my part. it was crisp and sweet, and a damn good dessert.
author: Abigail W.

description: While not as good as the food I very much enjoyed while in Istanbul, this place is pretty good. I could live on red lentil soup alone and thankfully this place does not fall short! The kabobs and pides have also been good each time. This place also got some major points with me when they had manti as a special one night. I think they could greatly improve their salad dressings, or serve grilled vegetables like most Turkish restaurants. The price is also very reasonable.
author: Kelsey S.

description: Ate here on a recent visit. I had the lamb kebabs which were outstanding. Everyone in our party of four raved about their meals which came with a small salad and rice on the plate. A basket of a delicious flatbread was served as well. Service was prompt and friendly and prices were reasonable.
author: Doug P.

description:
Guest Contributor:  The Wife
"Last night I went into the city with a friend of mine, to see the ballet. We were looking for a reasonably priced place to eat dinner beforehand, and although A La Turca's online menu does not have prices, we decided to give it a try.
 
Boy, were we not disappointed! We arrived just at 6 PM, as on street parking becomes available. The place was nearly empty at that time, although it had filled up almost completely by the time we finished our meal.
 
The waiter who greeted us was friendly, and spent quite a bit of time chatting with us about his favorite dishes, and helping us decide what to order.
 
We ended up deciding to share a few items. Our meal began with the dolmas - stuffed grape leaves. They were tender and lemony, with just the right amount of seasoning. We also received a basket of pide - fluffy bread with just a light sprinkle of sesame and black nigella seeds for interest.
 
When our entrees arrived, we decided to eat half from the plate in front of us, and switch. I thought my friend was going to change her mind, after taking a bite of her chicken Iskender. Unbelievably tender chicken from a spit, in a lovely spiced tomato and yogurt sauce, on top of cubes of pide, which soaked up the sauce and became delightfully soft and chewy. The Iskender was served with cacik, a yogurt sauce that complemented it perfectly.
 
My own dish was the chicken shish kebap, and I was not disappointed either. Fluffy white rice, flavorful in that wonderfully buttery way that rice can be. Beautifully seasoned and grilled cubes of chicken breast, along with a side of yogurt sauce that again complemented the chicken. And a light salad of lettuce and red cabbage that added some crunch and refreshment to the dish.
 
The only complaint I have is that our waiter did not take a drink order for us. We had to ask for water from another server. He made up for it, however, by bringing us complimentary glasses of tea with sugar lumps on the side, as we were finishing our meal.
 
Again for dessert, we decided to share. I ordered the sutlac, a rich and creamy baked rice pudding that was topped with crushed pistachios. Not too sweet, and absolutely delightful. My friend ordered the burma , a pinwheel of phyllo dough with honey and pistachios that was absolutely out of this world.
 
A La Turca is definitely worth a try - it's even worth a drive into the city from wherever you reside. I'll definitely be returning."
author: Bob K.

description: This is a review for delivery. We love this place. But since they deliver portions and quality has gone way down. We won't order from them anymore.
author: Carpe D.

description:
I'm a fan. 

I love eating on the cheap in the TL. I love getting boozey and stumbling across a tasty little family owned ethnic restaurant to eat on the cheap in the TL. 

I am pretty happy with my stumble upon this one. Restaurant was quaint, with Turkish murals on the walls, a deli counter and sit down service. Server was friendly and fast, portions were good sized and prices decent. 

Sigara Boregi $6.00: Deep fried pastry filled with feta cheese and parsley-freaking delicious with a tasty dipping sauce to boot, would def order again!

Falafel Platter $13.50: Served with hummus, tahini sauce and salad-also freaking delicious---the fried falafel hunks had a lot of flavor & texture and were not dry at all, the spicey red sauce, hummus and tahini that accompanied then were also wins. The salad  was more of a garnish--that got hoovered up too! I could do with this dish being a little cheaper but am happy with it overall. 

Baklava $5.00 Phyllo dough with walnut and syrup. Standard with nice amount of honey smothering it.
author: Cec D.

description: Went here for lunch on my quest to try food all over the Tenderloin. Mediterranean food was the call of the day and this quiet place was just the ticket. Started with the Baba Ghanouj: Grilled eggplant puree, tahini, yogurt, garlic and olive oil and served with some amazing bread. It was delicious. Also ordered an appetizer of Kiymali Borek: Pastry dough baked with sauteed ground meat. It came with two pieces and some salad and that crust was so flaky good and the filling seasoned very nicely. For my main course I had the Combo Doner: Chicken, beef and lamb doner thinly-sliced. Served with salad and rice. A lot of food came out and all out it incredible. The main course had so much meat on it, grilled and spiced well. The rice was also very good. It was an amazing main course but left no room for dessert. This place seemed like another independently owned and run establishment and the service was personal and friendly. Recommend it highly and I'll want to come back and try more of their dishes.
author: Roger M.

description: Last night I had a poor experience at a nearby wine bar. I hated the service and left  feeling one hundred dollars poorer and starving. I walked into this place and it was like a warm hug. DELICIOUS food, super friendly people, fairly priced. A night that was disappointing totally got turned around.
author: Shvonne A.

description:
Christmas Eve after nutcracker, on the way back to our union square hotel, a gentleman with a cute dog sitting at A La Turca spoke to us "they have great food!", so there we go sitting at a table exploring their menu.  It is our first time ever!  We ordered doner and Falfaler (spelling) thanks to the help from a near by couple.  Rice pudding and chai with the help of two other group of people.  Our experience is very unique.  Food is definitely  great!  

We will come back again.
author: Angela Z.

description:
I like the food here. Its a nice little social place. The service was fine when we went to dine here and the atmosphere was a-ok. It's gotten a little pricey but what place hasnt . At least the portions havent gone down with the prices gone up.We ordered the Doner and the equivalent of a spinach pie. All very tasty
Location isnt the greatest - in the heart of tenderloin...so you can watch drug deals and assorted weirdos walking around while waiting for your food. 
It's worth going back there despite the location, 
Recommended for the food and amusement of seeing San Franciscos lowest forms of life walking around the area
author: David S.

description: Food and prices were reasonable. Best part of the meal were the baskets of oven fresh bread they kept bringing us and the Turkish Coffee I had after the meal!
author: Parker D.

description:
Good thing there was a 30 min wait on a Saturday night because my dinner party ran about 30 mins late.  We were seated by a delightful waiter who made us feel right at home even though they were busy.

The pide was heaven and I would come back just for that.  We all enjoyed our meals and I think you can't go wrong with anything here although my bf thought his falafel sandwhich was a little dry and had to add some yogurt.

A bottle of wine, 3 beers, 2 apps, and 4 entrees later we walked about paying about $100.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
My family have been coming to this restaurant for more than 10 years.  Great tasty Turkish food. 

Lentil Soup
Lamb Shish Kebab
Chicken Shish Kebab

Highly recommended!
author: Wan T.

description: Desserts are really good. Doner was pretty good although the meat may remind you of processed sausage. Chicken mushroom pide was little plain. Surprisingly the bread is really good.
author: Munkhtur E.

description: One of the true gems of the neighborhood. So happy to have this restaurant just a block from my apartment. Lots of healthy, delicious options. Excellent, friendly service. Keep up the good work, A La Turca!
author: Johnny W.

description:
I'm shocked at a few of the poor reviews to this place.  For the price - you really cant beat the quality of the food.  Very well seasoned dishes - great heaps of it (very tasty left overs!), really nice owners and staff!

Now if location is very important....meeeh....
author: Marc J.

description: Good lord this place is good. They literally bake bread in front of you and take it directly from the oven to your table. Get the lentil soup.
author: Caroline J.

description:
Fantastic dining experience. The only thing better than the food was the top notch service. I took my girlfriend here for her birthday and they went out of the way to make her and our experience feel special! 

I would love to dine here again and again!
author: Imran S.

description:
Great Dinner in the cities Middle East countries!!!

We were not fan of Turkish food. But after reading a lot of good comment we visited here few times. All the time we left this place with atotal satisfaction. Service is pretty good and most of the staffs are from Turkey and very much well mannered.

At last time we ordered some different items all were delicious.

I just say about:

Chicken Kebab: Very good, fantastic. Excellent dish I have I have I ever met.

Chicken Shawerma: also greatest one and so much enjoyable, with rice and salad.

Overall perfect Mediterranean taste. hope come back here many times. Going to be fan of it...
author: Bridget G.

description:
I hesitate to give a low rating because our waiter was so nice. The cook too. So, disclaimer: the staff is really nice! 

It may also be my own fault, for what I ordered: the chicken kebab lunch special. It's just, nothing tasted like anything. Sure, there was chicken (dry, flavorless), hummus, some kind of dill sauce, red onion, lettuce and tomato, but I swear that it barely tasted like these things. Where are the spices that Turkish cuisine is famous for? The wrap was also thin and plain. I've had better kebabs in Oxford from a cart, and from places in Regensburg. Really. Regensburg. 

Perhaps try another place. Other reviews seem to also mention the underseasoned-ness. Good luck.
author: Diane Y.

description:
Food was delicious!... believe I had the combo.  It was busy and we still got in, seated, and served like clockwork.  
Can't wait to go back ;-)
author: Christopher N.

description:
This place is great! the neighborhood is shit but the food is delicious.

Highly recommend the Lamb Beyti: Ground lamb wrapped in lavash topped w/ garlic yogurt & hot butter mmmm :-)
author: Ilya Movshovich M.

description:
Wow, another great meal at A La Turca!

I've been coming here for about 8 years now and it's still as great as ever.  I had the Chicken Shish Kebap, which was great - cubed chicken breast that was grilled until tender...it was well-seasoned and still moist, which was awesome.  It arrived with some great rice and a side salad.  As always, I ordered the Hummus, which was great - definitely one of the better hummus recipes I've ever had.

The great thing about most of the food here is that it's very health, especially when you compare it to most other restaurant foods: many items are grilled as opposed to being fried or cooked with a ton of oil/butter/fat and most items are served with fresh or grilled vegetables.
author: Ken G.

description: Filling and cheap.  Four stars just for that.  But the fifth is missing becuase the service was a bit off.  it was hard to find our waitress so we just asked another waiter. nalso they messed up by forgetting to bring one of our platters we ordered - the waitress probably forgot to key it in.   but it made the cheap bill even cheaper.
author: Daniel Y.

description: Loved this place! The personnel is really nice. We came 20 minutes before closing and stayed long after hours. They did not only freed us, but were sincerely friendly. Their lamb beyti is the best :)
author: Olesya S.

description:
Very good Turkish restaurant. I like Turkish food and I can tell clearly that this was one of the finest Turkish restaurants I have ever enjoyed. 

My wife and I walked to this place after reading the positive reviews on yelp, and we strengthen these reviews because both the food and the service were great. We ordered in two occasions the following dishes: 

- Chicken Shish Kebab: Very tasty and pleasant. My wife liked it very much and it was really an excellent choice. The dish has also rice and salad and both of them were truly way delicious!!!!
- Chicken Shawerma: May be not of the greatest one or even on my top list, but still has a good taste. I gave it 4/5.
- Hommos: Good and delicious. Not the greatest but still tasty!!
- Cheese & Potatoes Dough: Very tasty and delicious. It melts into your mouth with the soft bread they baked it with. 


The overall result is five out five ... I recommend it strongly to those who love Mediterranean food.
author: Trojan M.

description:
Another restaurant from the neighborhood where I worked that I would frequent all the time for either lunch, dinner, or just to grab dessert. 

I love the wait staff here- very efficient. The food is consistently good and also very affordable considering how much food you get! You could eat here for under $15 and feel stuffed! Sometimes I'll just show up and get the lentil soup and a salad, but all of the pides and platters I've had have been incredible. ****ALSO- the sutlac is absolutely divine! That along with a Turkish coffee will make my day. This is one of the best Turkish restaurants I've ever been to and I can't wait to go again.
author: Daniel F.

description:
The Baba Ganoush was the star, the best we've ever had. Chicken Doner was very tasty. Adana Kebap was not so good. The service was good and friendly. The Turkish white wine was delicious and well priced.

Will definitely return and try other dishes.
author: TopCat W.

description:
I also googled the 7x7 article and thought the restaurant looked interesting.  Don't let the exterior and neighborhood fool you -- the food is delicious and the staff is warm and efficient.  

We had the fried carrots which were simple, but addicting.  We shared a pide with beef sausage and a beyti with chicken and mushroom.  The portions are large and we ended up taking leftovers home (which were just as good the next day).

We'll definitely be back!

Note:  Make a reservation, by 7:00, most of the tables were taken.
author: Lisa F.

description:
This is generally a very good Turkish restaurant downtown.  Although not up to real Turkish food in Turkey, it is still at least on par with any other Turkish place I've been to in the Bay Area.

Rice, tavuk and doner kebaps are great, side salads are generally really good.  Iskender kebap is pretty good, better than many I've had here but certainly not even close to the real thing in Turkey.  Coban salatasi (cucumber, tomato, feta/beyaz penir) is not great, being too oily and the vegetables not very good quality (a common problem compared to the salads in Turkey, which always seem to be made with wonderfully fresh, ripe ingredients).  Tea is good, they have Efes, and some desserts are good, too, like the sutlac (rice pudding), and baklava.
author: Wulfstan C.

description:
I was driving by this restaurant on the way to the theater and mentioned to some friends we need to check it out. The next day, we walked in.

It is three weeks later and this is at least my third visit. The food here is solid, the place is pretty clean and the service is no-nonsense.

I can pretty much recommend anything on the menu. The Beyti is delicious, whether you order the chicken or the lamb. The Pide are something close to a open-face calzone with delicious fillings, and the hummus with fresh baked bread is very tasty.

What makes A La Turca special are the breads. All the breads are freshly made in their oven and come out piping hot. The vertical roasted lamb is full of great flavor as is the chicken.

We tried nearly all the desserts yesterday and every one of them were delicious. You can walk up to the counter to check them out and ask any questions.

The plates are quite large and the prices are dirt cheap. You will not leave here hungry. I really hope they keep delivering such high quality food.
author: William R.

description: Great tea, gave us free refills!! Tried the kadayif for the first time. Very delicious flaky baked dough!
author: Yash M.

description:
Wonderful food! Tried the gözleme, falafel wrap and cacik (cucumber/dill/yogurt sauce), and it was all wonderful. The baklava was not my favorite but I would have it again.

I was disappointed that you could only have Turkish wine by the bottle.

Overall, a great place with delicious food and great service!
author: Katie N.

description:
YUMMMMM.
Firstly, the service was really good. The waitress was actually turkish, and chatted pleasantly with my parents about their trip there. 
As a collective, we had the lentil soup, the combo platter, a combo wrap and the beef and lamb wrap.
Loved it all! The wraps are HUGE (think Chipotle burrito) and I was more than full by the time I completed it. The hummus inside was in perfect proportion to the meat and veggies, and there was no need for a side of dipping sauce (like at most places). 
The combo came with rice, if you prefer that to bread.
The complimentary bread basket was heavenly! Fluffy, warm, and delicious. We didn't leave a crumb in that basket.
And the lentil soup was a hearty blend of flavors and went perfectly with the bread. 

Reasonable prices and good food! I highly recommend this place.

PS, I'm middle-eastern and found this place to be quite legit.
author: Sally E.

description:
One word: COCKROACHES. 

But before we proceed, let's start from the beginning, shall we?

We dined at A La Turca to celebrate a birthday party. So, we ordered the works. Appetizers, breads, salads, those Turkish panini things. 

The food was average. And, oddly enough, I have to say it's because it was just so bland. Not a common observation made in a middle eastern restaurant. 

OK, here's where things got fun. I go to the bathroom, and mid-stream, a gigantic cockroach scurries around my feet. 

I FREAKED OUT.  

I prematurely wrap things up and head out to our table. Two minutes hardly pass before I hear a shrilling cry coming from a friend at our table. 

ANOTHER COCKROACH.

This time, the cockroach won. It crawled up her pants leaving her with little to do but smash it! SMASH. IT.

So, while our friend busily piled off roach better from under her pants, I informed the waitress that we encountered two cockroaches and that we were really, very, upset. 

She goes, "Oh no, I would be upset too."

That's it. No apologies. No attempt to convince us to come back. No word from the manager. 

So, unless you want a "high protein" meal, avoid this disgusting place.
author: Sharon V.

description:
After visiting Turkey, I generally find it hard to rate Turkish restaurants highly in the US, so biases aside, here we go.

[meat plates]
The meat platters are pretty good, but I'd prefer the beef ones over the chicken ones.  Pretty close to what you would get in Turkey.

[pides]
Oh man.. these don't even come CLOSE to an authentic pide.   A pide is like a turkish pizza where the dough is thinner and is often cooked in some type of wood or charcoal oven.  I can understand they don't have that, but their dough is too thick.
author: Dan Q.

description:
My favorite time of the year is during the long cold winter months and being at the receiving end of invitations to a dinner gathering.  I usually whip up a nice thick baked pasta dish or brownies.

However, on nights where there is not enough time to do anything, much less spend an hour or more belaboring in the kitchen, A La Turca has delivered me many a time when the dinner had a fusion theme.
We elected for the Combo Platter, comprised of eggplant salad, grape leaves, hummus, ezme, and piyaz.  Enough for several people to nibble from and differentiate from like/dislike and of course, for that one guest, vegetarian.  For the meat lover in myself, I had to ensure the survival of my stability during long moments of witty repartee, so the Combo Doner (a large dish of chicken, lamb, and beef doner) usually is successful in satisfying the straying fingers roaming the spread across the kitchen counters.

Dining in this slightly enlarged hole in the wall would afford you a serving of lavash bread.  In the event one is on the run, there is a Russian market on Clement and on the cusp of the Outer Richmond that carries lavash, as well as other condiments that would prove necessary if the host runs short of foodstuff.

Inexpensive (our tab was less than $30), a quick pick up (call your order in and double park out front while your date runs in) and boom, your invitational courtesies have been met.
author: Miika M.

description: Everything is so delicious here! Try the eggplant and lamb lavish wrap! Would definitely come back again!
author: Tu Anh D.

description: Worst service ever. Waited for 30 min to take our order then they lost it. So we had to wait another hour and no food. When we asked the waiter about our order she said she lost it. Never there again! As a middle eastern it's the worst food and service to experience.
author: N E.

description:
ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! Best restaurant I've been to in San Francisco. The ambiance in this restaurant is chill- relaxing. Very Turkish. I love being in a comfortable environment and enjoying my food (they also have a tv with the basketball game if you need some entertainment while you eat) For appetizer I had hummus with bread and feta cheese. Completely amazing. For dinner I had a combination grill - chicken doner and lamb doner. It was literally amazing. The sauce they have is phenomenal. It came with rice and salad too. If you're not extra hungry you can even share it with someone because it comes in a good sized portion (literally a whole plate full). And it wasn't ridiculously priced like a lot of restaurants we've been to in San Francisco. 
The staff was awesome- very attentive and very friendly! I would definitely recommend this place and would definitely come back here next time I visit San Fran!
author: El V.

description:
I know a guy who is from Turkey. He has a really sad story. As an ethinic minority, he had to flee his homeland when his sibling, a political officeholder, was taken in by police and murdered. My friend is now in the States, alone with no family as a political refugee. The point being is that he is Turkish and also loves a la Turca.

Five stars for the baba ghanoush. Also their rice, pides (cheese and potato) and hummus were SO delicious! And the puffy bread that they serve with the food is to die for. It is puffy and soft and perfect.

The doner was definitely tasty, but the kebabs the other table ordered looked so much more delicious, it definitely made us feel our order fell short. We still scarfed it down with no problem. 

I thought the turkish tea was only so-so. this being my only experience with turkish tea, I found the aftertaste a little bitter and the tea not very flavorful otherwise. Perhaps it's just a matter of me not being able to appreciate good turkish tea.

I will be back again. And again. And again. It's the TL, so I wouldn't be surprised if they sprinkled crack in that shit.
author: Jess C.

description:
Surprisingly good basic Turkish cafe in the Tenderloin.  They have a lot of Turkish street food standards, like gozleme, which I don't really see elsewhere, even at La Troya.  If only they had manti, they'd be perfect.

A little more than usual Tenderloin pricing -- $15 to $25 per person before you get out the door for dinner -- but worth it.
author: Josh B.

description:
I've had Turkish only once before at Turkish Kitchen in Berkeley and that was almost a year ago.  Still, my taste buds hardly ever forget good food.  I'm writing this review weeks after my visit, but I can tell you that even the barista at my local Starbucks here in SoCal is raving about this place.

My husband and I went to meet with a friend.  Parking was a bit of a hassle at 7pm on a Saturday night, but hey it's the city and it's expected.  Upon our arrival, we were greeted by the host/server who was really nice.  I remember her pretty almond shaped eyes.  *ahem*

When my friend finally arrived 20 minutes later ;), we ordered Turkish tea and stuffed grape leaves.  Yum, what a great way to start things off.  We ordered a combo doner platter and a spanakli borek (spanakopita if you are familiar with Greek food). We conversed, we ate, we watched the Turkish television channel, and we left happy. These folks know what they are doing.  My friend has been coming here for years.
And I'm ready to go back again.  How much is a cheap flight to Frisco?
author: Elle A.

description:
Went over next door from the Ha Ra bar for a quick bite. I got a Chicken Shawarma and a Rice pudding.

The Rice pudding was excellent and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

The Chicken Shawarma on the other hand was pedestrian and lacked the flavours one have come to expect from such a wrap. I have tasted much better elsewhere. But it was still decent.
author: Umesh T.

description:
I had this place on my yelp queue for quite a while and was very excited to actually try it out. The boyfriend and I were starving when we ordered so we got quite a few items. We started with the eggplant salad, then shared the spicy beef sausage and cheese pide, chicken and cheese gozleme, and lastly, the beyti kebap. 

The eggplant salad was decent, but something was missing. I've had much better at Moroccan or other Mediterranean places. Maybe I'm just not used to the Turkish version of the appetizer, but I wasn't impressed. 

The beyti kebap, which is ground lamb wrapped in lavash bread served
with special sauce and yogurt, came next. There was a layer of oil floating on the dish and it didn't look like olive oil. The dish tasted OK, the meat wasn't all that flavorful nor tender and the bread wasn't very soft. The sauces were pretty decent though.

The pide and gozleme came next. The gozleme is a glorified quesadilla. It was good, but like the beyti kebap, on the oily side. The pide turned out to be a pizza roll. The spicy sausage was basically pepperoni cubes and I ended up picking them out because I didn't like it. 

I have to say that I was vastly disappointed in the place. I thought Mediterranean food is suppose to be healthy and light but this place use a really heavy hand with the food. Maybe they used low quality meat and cheeses that essentially produced a lot of oil. The best part of the meal, hands down, was the free bread that came with dinner. That was the only item of leftovers that I took home. Hm, I wonder if they just sell the bread...
author: Alice W.

description:
Service was a little strange, but the food was pretty good. Our server was very friendly. 

The eggplant salad was not good. Nobody at the table liked it. The Iskender kebap was very good.
author: Monika M.

description:
the falafel and baklava - fantastic
i liked the lentil soup initially, but now i think the mint flavor's too high.
excellent service, friendly people, clean place.
good presentation as well!
author: Namrata J.

description: Its my second time in this restaurant, It Is a Good turkish restaurant And the prices are okay too for being in the city ! Ps: They have the best bread And They are fast :)
author: Sanoushka P.

description: After my boyfriend and I went to Turkey, we were totally craving Turkish food. So we checked out three restaurants and this by far was the most authentic that we found. A good sign was that most of the people sitting there were Middle Eastern. And the owners and wait staff were Turkish. My boyfriend had the beef entree and WOW the beef was so tender and deliciously spiced. I had the lamb and beef wrap/sandwich and that was really good as well.
author: Susan A.

description:
This place is awesome on the taste buds.

I first took my girlfriend here on her birthday. She just recently broke into the Turkish Food craze and I found this on here. We came in and were treated so well by the whole staff, it felt very comforting. I strongly recommend the Chicken Beyti and their Hummus. SOOOOOOOO GOOD!

Thanks guys.
author: Mike O.

description:
Horrible experience. Well...I shall start with the food. I ordered tripe soup to begin with based on the head waiter's recommendation. After that, a lovely waitress (she is from Switzerland I guess) came to take our orders. I told her that I had ordered tripe soup but she said they don't serve it, and they only serve lentil soup. Obviously, she had no idea what's on the menu for the day. My friends and I went on ordering our entrees. I ordered the Doner plate. The tripe soup was cold and tasteless.  I sent it back. The waitress did not ask me why or what the problem was. She was just interested if I had some so that she'd charge me for it. Sensing this by her looks, I said that I would pay for it but I wanted lentil soup. The lentil soup had average Middle Eastern taste, not Turkish at all. The Doner plate had plenty of meat and rice, yet I had way better doner at places that are not even Turkish. So this place, even though its name is A La Turca, does not serve neither Turkish lentil soup nor Turkish doner. 

The service: I know the culture of tipping and I know how little waiters make on tips. I had just left a %30 tip at a great restaurant yesterday. Here, I left a pretty mean tip. When I walked over to hand the check myself(!) and get my takeouts (which no one cared to bring to me); I told the waitress that I wish I would leave more but that we didn't enjoy the food at all. I was trying to be nice actually, I did not want to comment on her service. She responded "Sir, this is not an excuse". Although, I sympathize and understand where she is coming from, if she needs an excuse, I actually could give a handful. She didn't know what's on the menu, she brought a cold soup (which is easy to notice), she didn't ask how our meal was, she clearly avoided us. Not that I need an excuse to leave a bad tip, the service was not even average. I've had waitresses literally asking how my meal is for 2-4 times. So, service is not good and don't care to play nice.

They treated us tea, which was appropriate and necessary for a Turkish restaurant. 

Pretty disappointed. I am sure the manager (or head waiter) and the waitresses had better days, but today was not one of them.
author: Cagil A.

description:
I got this from Jenna F. who got this from her boyfriend's friend who is actually Turkish. I think. 

I had the chicken shish platter. SO GOOD.

SO MUCH BETTER than Gyro King in MOST aspects- for $5, you can get a huge shish burrito, for .95 cents more an order of fries, and for .55 cents more, a soda. Yeah. Enough fuel for the whole day for $6.50. During finals I will be hitting this baby like its a pinata. 

BUT- and this is a big but- their bread didn't really do it for me. Sad.
author: Emily D.

description:
Baba ganoush with pide was the highlight for us - lentil soup was decent. We were seated upstairs so the service was a bit slow but it was New Year's Eve so it was understandable they were short staffed and/or crowded. Friendly staff and good service.
Chicken shish kebab - alright. The rice was good - cooked in butter I presume. 
Falafel sandwich - will not recommend. Falafel was hard and over cooked.
author: Lakshmi V.

description:
We came here on our last night in San Francisco since we had a Turkish guy in group.  First, we were delighted to see that the food and beverages are rather cheap compared to other establishments in town.

We started with Turkish red wine and Ephes Beer, which is not easy to find.

We then had a Turkish pizza, Shepard Salad, and an mix of dips such as hummus, yogurt, garbanzo beans, etc.  All were excellent.  For the main course I had the doner kabab plate which was also very good.  We finished off with a strong dose of Turkish coffee.

We were there for a while and the place filled up.  Surprisingly there was only one server who did an amazing job keeping up given the crowd.  Needless to say we left full and satisfied which is the way is should be.
author: Zach P.

description:
Appetizers are tasty. The 6 dish Combo Appetizers is worth the price.

I find the dinner meat to be bland, but lamb and beef are well seasoned.
author: Anthony H.

description: Don't know where to start, very very dissapointimg. It's not Turkish food, it's not real doner. And extremely expensive for price-performance. I am sorry for the reputation of Turkish food they represent. They use the wordt quality meat add spice to get rid of the bad smell and call it a spicy doner. They better make low quality meatballs with that meat. Even the rice is so bad, maybe cooked days ago. Never again.
author: Charlotte H.

description:
Food was a about 3. Kind of bland, gave me decent heart burn... I know good middle eastern food, unfortunately not amazing here. But it all looks and sounds awesome. 
&
Service was really great
&
Prices are totally reasonable
author: Derek B.

description:
I came here for lunch today with a business partner, and it was rather good! The meat was spiced nicely (I think it tastes rather like seasoned taco meat, but I suppose is is the traditional gyro seasoning), and the pita bread with my sandwich was really quite tasty.

I thought it was a tad expensive, but I'm going to give them an extra star for letting me drink my soda without complaining. Great food, will be back soon.
author: Stevie D.

description:
I have walked past this several times and been wanting to check it out! 
I fantasize about "meat on the stick" in general and that gets me all the time. 

I talked briefly with the employee and apparently most of the employees are Turkish also. good sign. =) 

So I went with the lamb plate dish (#51 I think), appetizer- those puff pastries with spinach and cheese, some baklava for dessert, and my wife went with this Greek salad. Oh and the bread was the bomb. It's super thick and goes great with the meat and sauce. I washed all that down with the Turkish tea (mix of peppermint and black tea). All that was $30 out the door. 

I had no complaints about this place. This is definitely going to be one of my spots.
author: Rob Y.

description:
I came here about a year ago and it was excellent from memory so I decided why not come here again to revisit this restaurant. I came about three days ago and the restaurant was empty since it was only 4PM. The waiter sat us and he promptly got us drinks.
Now a la turca has a great atmosphere, got a TV with a Turkish channel really makes the place feel really authentic. Kinda makes me want to dance with the music. 
We ordered the spinach and feta pastry along with the flat bread with ground beef, tomatoes and onions for the appetizer. The spinach pastry was hot and fresh. The flat bread was also like a thin crispy pizza without the cheese but the taste really blended the ingredients really well.

Now for the main dish which was the chicken beyti . Came in chicken breast pieces wrapped in crispy tortilla covered in red sauce and yogurt. Let me tell you, when you bite into this, you might let out a little moan because of how good it is. Don't worry that's perfectly normal. 

Also we did order the iskender beef which was covered in yogurt sauce as well. Kind of like thin beef slices. The beef was good but the chicken beyti was far superior in my opinion. What we also ordered was chicken donor which was a nice surprise. It came cooked with several spices and it was really moist and tasteful. Really surprised on how that chicken came on perfectly.

And for the last act was dessert of course. Ordered a kind of pudding
It was rice, sugar and milk. Simple yet a delicate dish with kinda chilled . Great to cap off the dishes served earlier. 

Great place to go to be introduced to Turkish food and you will not be disappointed, who knows you might even dance with the Turkish music on your way out.
author: Jason H.

description: We tried a plate with appetizers (babaganoush, hummus) and a plate of kebabs (lamb, chicken, kofta). Good prices and delicious food. The service is good.
author: Kate V.

description:
Just ran over here for a quick lunch (I work a few blocks down Geary St). I ordered ahead and they had it ready when I arrived--still hot and fresh! 

The lamb gyro I got was great, though next time I will probably order it on the lavash bread instead of the pita--they toast the pita so it's more like a crispy sandwich (still good just not what I was expecting).

Also...the fries are amazing. Like so good. They have the magic touch. I was shoveling them down like a madwoman :)
author: Kristen F.

description:
Very Beautiful Lunch!

I definitely recommend this place for lunch. I recommend it for dinner too, but it's sooooo busy that lunch is a better way to relax and enjoy it. Well, at least if you're like me. After a lifetime in and around the food service business, I have it engrained in my brain that I need to get the table ready for the next customers. The girl that introduced me to the place is not someone who has that problem, so if you ever waited for me to get out of your seat, blame her. I'm not with her anymore, so, well, I'm just saying. 

I walked out of this place smiling from ear to ear, with a little left over from my meat and egg oven creation, I think it was number 48 on the menu IDK (kind of runs along the lines of a Calzone, but different) and half of my Bulva. The prices are pretty decent too considering this is a full service meal where staff are making sure everything is done to excellence. I'm in love.
author: Marc R.

description:
As a person of Turkish decent Turkish food in many cities in the United States. When I stumbled across A La Turca during my trip to San Fran I found one of the better Turkish restaurants I have been to in quite some time.

I took three Turkish food virgins with me and we ordered several dishes, including Sarmi, Mezes and several different Kebabs. The Kebab platter that has all types of meats was nicely done and prepared just right, my rice and salad however was bland and left a bit to be desired.

The Ayran(yogurt Drink) was A-MAZ-ING served old world style in copper cups and cold, I admit I had 3!!!! the desert was Rice pudding and Kunefe and where properly done, I can't say enough about the menu. 

I would have given a perfect had the rice and salad been better but all in all a wonderful treat nestled in a side street you might just walk past. If you are smart however you will give it a shot!!!
author: Imran K.

description:
This place is super close to S's apartment in the TL, which made it convenient. It had come recommended by one of his co-workers, so we made a trip for a weekday dinner.

We walked in and weren't completely sure how things worked. People were seated at tables, but other people were at the counter ordering food. Do we order then sit down? Do we just take a table?

Ultimately, we realized seating is fairly casual so we just grabbed a table, and the waitress brought us menus. We ordered the baba ganoush, beef shish, and combo grill. S also ordered a turkish tea to drink, but it never arrived...

When the food came, it was all great. I really liked the lamb that came as a part of my dish, and the rice was flavorful. The bread served with the baba ganoush was also warm and refilled without being asked for.

I decided to go for 3 stars because the food was good, but the service was just not up to par. There were three people who were serving as waiters/busboys, and they didn't have set tables so oftentimes, they would ask people for their orders when they had already ordered or would ask if they wanted the check when the table hadn't even received their food yet. It was a bit of a mess. Not to mention they didn't bring us the tea that we had ordered. 

The end of the meal was just as confusing as the beginning. Some people were getting up to go to the counter to pay, others were waiting for their check at their tables. Only because we were ready to go did S decide to just head to the counter to pay. 

Next time, we might just get the food to go in order to avoid the service.
author: Alison C.

description:
Our party had:
Doner & mozarella pide (3/5)
Lamb shank (4/5)
Doner sandwich (3/5)

Pide had feta cheese in it which is not how it's made traditionally. The crust was perfect, though.
Daily special (fries, doner wrap and drink) is actually a good deal.
author: Bugra O.

description: This is my favorite Turkish restaurant in SF. So fresh and everything tastes homemade. The kofta is delicious and the rice pudding is the best in the city. Sorry Loving Cup. A must try if you haven't been. The staff is amazingly friendly and hospitable.
author: Nikki T.

description:
My 50th birthday was approaching. I'm pretty low key when it comes to birthdays, but I HAD to mark turning 50. I wanted to have a nice long meal with friends and decided to invite 6 of my buds out to dinner. But it needed to be some place within my budget, easy to get a reservation for 7, could share plates and  could hear ourselves talk. A La Turka was perfect!

7 people, two bottles of wine, plenty of food and the bill with tax and tip was $225.

I knew the food would be delish, as I had eaten here maybe 6 times before over the years. This time was my favorite experience because I got to sample so may dishes.
author: Bob J.

description:
A La Turca is a diamond in the rough.  The food is good and it is reasonably priced.  There was nothing pretentious about the restaurant whatsoever, and is intended for casual dining.

They have an open kitchen, which I always appreciate.  Several of their dishes require baking in a large oven, which makes for a comfortably warm dining area.  Consider visiting on a chilly San Francisco night.

If you've never had Turkish tea before, try it - it is tasty.

Look for the specials written on a white board by the kitchen.  The staff may neglect to mention them.

They also have the best Baklava I have ever tried - super moist, yet all of the many many layers of flaky phyllo stayed in tact.

The bathrooms were nice and clean.

I left the restaurant feeling very satisfied for having a quiet, unpretentious, tasty, and reasonably priced meal.
author: Erica K.

description: I'll hand it to fellow Yelpers and Foursquare users that the lahmacun appetizer was good (like a cheese-less, THIN, thin-crust pizza), but for all the rave reviews about their bread, I really wasn't that impressed.  It reminded me of Chinese sesame dinner rolls - except they weren't as salty and chewy (and delicious).  And maybe the accolades for the rice pudding were given prior to the inception of Loving Cup, but that wasn't so great either.  The kadayif, however, was surprisingly the best out of everything we ordered.  Crispy yet chewy, light, and tasty.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I have been to this place twice. I was initially brought here by a Turkish friend. The place is a bit hidden in the middle of the tenderloin. The ambiance is cozy and decorated with detail. 

The first time I ordered an appetizer, the Lahmacun, and this dish that I am now forgetting the name... ? It was sort of a ground beef quesadilla. Quite tasty. I also got to taste the big combo dish with lamb, beef, chicken and rice... and Yum!!!! I am ordering it next time. No doubt.

I highly recommend the Turkish tea, it is not your regular black tea...it is better. I also tried the "ayran" (sp?) and it was exquisite, but not my 'cup of tea.' My friend told me it is good for digestion... I say, "no thanks." 

And then, the wonderful and amazing, Kunefe. OMG!!!! It is heaven on earth. (5 stars).... delicious!!!!!!! It is a must try dessert.
author: Monique T.

description: We have just been back after... I guess a couple of years. It is still as it was or even better. We have had several dishes, a couple of appetizers, main dishes and desserts. Everything was excellent. The people super-nice, no fuss at all to get a table, no annoying hipsters neither among the waiters nor among the customers. Always a very pleasant dinner! :)))
author: Luca R.

description:
We ordered take out from A La Turca on a weeknight. Overall, it was okay. 

We got the Falafel Platter which was fine and the Beyti Kebap Platter (lamb wrapped in lavash bread with yogurt sauce). It was tasty, but a little too heavy. It kind of tasted like a pasta dish. The bread was soft and wrapped around the lamb like a manicotti almost. I needed about half of the amount that we got. 

It was worth trying, and not a bad experience - but not an immediate favorite for sure.
author: Alden Q.

description:
If I could give this place 0 stars i would because of the despicable, insulting, ignorant, childish, bitchy waitresses. The food is wonderful. The Turkish beer is great.  The decor, charming. 

So here's what happened. My Turkish friend swears by this place and wanted to take me to dinner here the other night. We call ahead to see if they are busy (this is at 9:00PM precisely. The waitress (who I will call waitress 1, she is shorter with a short haircut with curly light brown hair) answers the phone and tells my friend that they are closing at 9:30PM because there are no customers. My friend tells her that we want to come in and will be there before 9:30.  Waitress 1 puts up a rude fight but says that if we get there before 9:30 we can eat. We race over there and are in the door by 9:20. When we come in the girl gets a snide smile on her face and says they are doing to-go only. After some persistance, and mentioning she had said we could eat as long as we came in before 9:30, she allows us to sit down. We order 2 beers and something my friend said in Turkish that sounded like "Chicken bay-eece" I don't know what it was called on the menu but anyway it was good. Waitress one goes over to waitress 2  (a taller girl with her top two center teeth chipped and long black hair in a low ponytail with really crunchy tight curls)and they stare at us and talk bitchily about us and even go over to their only customer's table, a young male, and talk about us to him. He loudly responded "I wouldn't do that" so obviously trying to say he wouldn't have insisted on dining if they were trying to close. An old man came in around 9:40 and they turned him away which was really sad. Anyway long story short the 2 waitresses come over and get in this catty fight with us and waitress 1 keeps saying they had to close because of a graduation in the back then starts telling us we are "inexceptable". My friend said she thought the girl was trying to say "renovation" not graduation. The whole thing is stupid anyway because on the phone she had said they were closing because of lack of business which again didn't make sense because there was a customer in the restaurant. So out of nowhere waitress 2 yells that they were in fact having pest control. Greeat.... But the ridiculous thing was waitress 1 started getting so bitchy and confrontational that waitress 2 had to tell her in Turkish to go away. So then waitress 2 started tellign us they didn;t want to lose their jobs and all of this other nonsense and we told them we didn;t want them to lose their jobs either we just wanted to dine in peace. the funniest part is, if we had been seated right away and allowed to eat without them coming over and having a 10 minute fight with us, we would have been out of there by 9:45. Nevertheless we left only a couple minutes after 10PM. 

I think waitress 1 should pick a different profession and waitress 2 needs to resort to the type of attitude she took on once she got scared for her job before the condescending BS she pulled off the get telling us the reason they were staring at us is because we were her customers and she needed to be sure we were happy with the bitchiest most sarcastic tone and facial expression ever. Oh! and waitress 1 even admitted to having been glaring at me the whole time, when I asked her why she had been doing that she said it was because our behavior was inexceptable. GREAT customer service!!!  Doesn't even have the brain to deny having glared at us lol.
author: Emma H.

description: Just got a screw in my rice here, standards clearly slipping....needs a food safety inspection. Worst bit the owner wouldn't even take the rice of the check!
author: Peter K.

description: The best Turkish food in the city! Great portions, good price, loving the wall decor. If you in the mood for some authentic Turkish food this is a spot for you to come! Their bread is amazing, fresh hot and delicious! Its a hard spot to find parking, but you won't regret!
author: Sofia K.

description:
