I love going to this place. Whenever I was I'm in town I have to come here! The chicken doner is amazing! Best turkish food I've ever had. Great location as well. 

The food is not expensive and I've got all my friends to be fans of this place.
author: Jarrell P.

description:
The food is as good as everyone says.  We had the beyti and adana kebab (two different forms of lamb).  The beyti had individual pieces of lamb wrapped in lavash and was my favorite!  They also had baklava and other pastries which I was too full try, but definitely on my to do list for next time. 

A La Turca is very casual.  You can order at the counter and take food to go or sit down and have a more leisurely meal. The decorations offer a taste of middle eastern culture from the decorative plates hanging on the walls to the Turkish music videos playing on TV and the massive mural on your left as you walk in.  

Come here if you are lazy on a Tuesday night and don't want to cook.  It's a quick and worthwhile stop with plenty of seating if you want to bring a handful of friends with you.
author: Kimya P.

description:
My friend from Turkey says that this is the best Turkish restaurant in the city, but its still not the BEST Turkish food. For some reason SF lacks many Turkish restaurants.However, my experience here was pleasant. We called in our order and picked it up. We got:

- eggplant salad - good
- ALATURCA SALAD - very good salad, nothing specail, comes pretty big
- LAMB BEEF DONER - I was not the biggest fan of the meat, it came with salad and a lot of rice
- rice pudding - GREAT!
- BAKLAVA - Really good

also, our order came with very large pieces of bread. I had no idea. They really good, fresh kinda like focaccia. The service was a little slow, but the staff was very nice. The gentlemen who rung me up ran around looking for another plastic fork. 

I wish we had sat down to eat. The place is cute. Warm and homey feeling. I would recommend it you want to try Turkish food.


-JF
author: Jenna F.

description: Iskander lamb is incredible. Tender soft beef and lamb. Hot bread and grape leaves are delicious!!!!!! I highly recommend this especially for Eurasian tourist, great taste of something familiar.
author: Kamila N.

description:
I didn't expect to get Italian and Mexican food at a Turkish restaurant in the TL that broadcasts Turkish TV. Alas, that's what I got.

I had the lahmacun (#13, "thin dough topped with ground meat, green pepper, tomato, onion, parsley and spices") (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=awqWu0PE2yjcGBQvE7iROA), doner (#51, "roasted and sliced ground lamb and beef") (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?userid=5bmpGbzPd-gfcUl6o5j7FQ), and tripe soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=EDWVZOKoPsTXwY1pSKcakw). The LAHMACUN was good, but looked and tasted exactly like a very thin crust PIZZA without cheese. The DONER was cold and dry though. I liked the TRIPE SOUP. It was a little creamy and they give you some type of vinegar to add some aciditiy, but the best adjective for the way it tastes is, well, tripe-y, so it was a good thing I like tripe!

My vegetarian friend ordered a spinach and cheese gozleme (#46, "flat bread filled with veggies/meat"), but a CHICKEN & CHEESE GOZLEME came instead (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=tpToJMvX2xhH9hk8s_cdQw). So, they gave it to us on the house along with some hummus (free food for me! Woot woot!) and they remade her order. The gozlemes weren't bad, but nothing special - especially since they are basically QUESADILLAS! 

Two other friends got the BEYTI KEBAP (#56, "ground lamb wrapped in lavash bread served with special sauce and yogurt") (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=-QNpqdqUu3Gl4nDVyDELkQ) and BEEF SHISH KEBAP (#55) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2PRgMkqX2dRrcuaJEi_1Rg?select=b4fIlMoEoh6JPnkOO4ot7w). Both were tasty and were the most "Turkish" dishes at our table.
author: Steph L.

description: Worst food I have ever had, after Denny's!!! I am really sorry to say that, but I would not recommend this place to any of my friend. We were four and there around 6pm. We ordered soup, Iskender, Gozleme with cheese and meat! I ordered soup and there was smth strange with it! Because in the soup there was rope!!! Iskender's meat was dry and cold, it had no taste. They even got the money from me for the soup with rope!!! Never go back!
author: Angela K.

description: Very much enjoyed the food and service here. Fresh tasting and good portions, definitely a good value for the price. The kofti plate had been my favorite so far.
author: Donny S.

description: My hubby and I tried A La Turca for the first time for lunch yesterday. My review is based on the excellent Turkish red lentil soup I had there and the wonderful warm fluffy homemade bread. I had this kind of soup at one other place in Notting Hill London and loved it so much I hated to leave London, because where would I ever get it again. I could hardly tell the difference and am so happy to have a "go to" place for this soup. I also had their red pepper appetizer (ezme) and it was good, though not as good as the same dish in London. My hubby had the tripe soup (a special) and he didn't like it (he usually loves tripe).
author: Barbara S.

description:
I was craving Turkish cuisine last night so we decided to head to A La Turca.  We had not had any Turkish food since our return from our trip to Turkey last June and we knew this place would satisfy our craving.  

We started with the appetizer sampler plate which included Piyaz, a creamy white bean salad; Cacik, a yogurt cucumber dip; Ezme, a roasted pepper spread, baba ghanoush, hummus, dolmas, and Turkish sesame bread.  We should have stopped there since this appetizer portion was huge but we couldn't pass up the Pide, a delicious type of pizza.  We had one with ground meat, onions, peppers and egg and the other was a simpler but equally delicious feta and tomato.  Both included a green salad.  The service at A La Turca is friendly and efficient and Turkish music videos play on the big screen TV while you dine.  If you feel like having a shot of Turkish culture, this is a great place to dine and you can get out of there for under $15 per person.
author: Ralph C.

description: Great food. The lamb chops, chicken kabob and chicken beyti are some of the excellent items on the menu. Do not miss the Ayran yogurt drink. Simply delicious. And great hosts!
author: Gopi V.

description: Excellent doner, fantastic breathtaking rice pudding, breat as good as in Istanbul, two types Pida and Lavash, both made there, and fantastic veggie appetizer combo. the interior is less than cheery, otherwise, fantastic.  I wish i lived in SF i would be back this week.
author: Thulasi O.

description:
I usually get my fix at Basil Leaf but I'd give this place a try. I ordered a lamb kebab and my friend ordered the falafel. 


I love my stuff drenched in yogurt! the falafel was tasty but the again if it wasn't for the yogurt, i thought it was dry.

The lamb though was exquisite. Moist and soft(i got it cooked medium rare). 

The joint itself was nothing special, but for some reason it made me feel like i was in an Italian families home, maybe the decor??? 
The waitress was nice, very quiet. I'd definitely come back. 

YAY for A LA TURCA
author: Tam T.

description:
The most bizarre combination of occasionally incredible food and humorously bad service I've ever experienced.  Hungry for something from the generally middle east / central Asia geographical area, we walked in on a Sunday afternoon.  Seeing it was about 95 degrees inside and 75 outside on the sidewalk (albeit with three patrons smoking right by the entrance and the prospect of of visits from from the street people around there) we opted for the outside option.  We let the manager know we were outside and they told us they'd send someone out.  The waitress nodded.  About 15 minutes later without seeing any staff, I walked in and grabbed a menu myself.  After another 15 waitressless minutes, I walked in and ordered directly from the chef who seemed sympathetic.   "10 minutes" he said.  We knew from the Yelp highlights that the chicken beyti was popular as were the "pides" though there were like ten choices of those.  So we asked for a recommendation and the counter person said "You like meat? then definitely get sujuk and cheese."  Another 15-20 minutes later the food came out.  So until this point they're rockin about 0.5 stars.  But then, the PIDE, THAT SUJUK AND CHEESE PIDE. HFS it was money.  Rich, fresh, hot, toasty, just a bit of spice, just enough cheese to balance the bread.  Perfect.  

Yes, the chicken beyti looked cool with the colorful sauces on it, but that was pretty much it: a hottie with nothing inside worth dealing with.

Anyway, we got out of there pretty soon after.  Going by previous experience, we didn't wait for the check, just walked up to the register to pay it. Maybe they just had a rough staffing day, who knows. The three visits we enjoyed from street people (including one pretty rough flower vendor) definitely added some variety to the meal, but it's not for everyone.  Once the weather cools off, it'll be worth sitting inside where you might get better (ok, any) service.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Had one of the most Horrible experience here, so much so that I'll never be coming back here and won't be recommending this place to anyone. 

Food was very very mediocre, there's pretty much very little flavor compared to some of the other Turkish restaurant (and I've had a lot of them)

The service of of the worst I've experience, only came in for a take out, but one of the waiter and chef kept "hitting" on me asking me if I wanted to "work here" and all sort of personal question. Seriously !?! Very disappointed, why would I ever want to go back here now ? No thank you, I'll take my business and my friends elsewhere.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
My Husband is Turkish, so I have started to develop pretty high standards for Turkish food, and this is one of our favorite local stops. 

We always start with the Sigara Beregi- basically deep fried feta cheese, can you really go wrong with that?! so good. 

I usually get the Iskender Kebap, which is cut up meat in tomato sauce over cubes of bread with yogurt to dip in. The last time I was there the meet was a little over done, but still had great flavors. 

You must try the Kunefe for dessert!!
author: Lauren S.

description: Still very good. Was just back last week and the meats were excellent as was the hummus and fresh baked bread. Yum.
author: Thadd L.

description: A little disappointing since the Yelp reviews are good.  I ordered the lamb beef doner sandwich.  It was a sizable wrap, but it was dry and the meat was not flavorful at all.  I only ate half my wrap.  The mister ordered the falafel sandwich and it tasted better, but definitely not the best falafel I've had.  Our friend ordered the A La Turca salad and it looked ok.  We ordered the baba ghanouj to share, which we ate with the bread; this I enjoyed and would've just had it as my entire lunch.  I've had food in Turkey, and this place doesn't even come close.
author: Thi D.

description:
So amazingly delicious! Had the spinach and cheese pide which was more than enough for one person. Also got baba ganoush to go and it was a huge hit. Possibly the best baba ganoush I've ever had...
Service was very pleasant and despite the sketchy location, I can't wait to go back for more.
author: Carla B.

description: Some dishes are hit or miss but I really liked the Iskender. The rice pudding for dessert is the best thing ever
author: Ivy S.

description:
a good value and nice surprise embedded in the heart the tenderloin.

food is consistently impressive, expertly seasoned and prepared and all around generous. starters, mains and desserts all offer something special (tips hat to the sweet cheese dessert).

appropriate for dates or groups. my only regret is not having tried it sooner!
author: danicka h.

description:
I really didn't know what to expect. This place is right in the exciting part of the tenderloin, sharing a block with numerous slummy apartments and a XXX theater. On the walk from O'Farrell, there was some sort of barbecue/yard sale and a hobo with breadlocks (dreadlocks in the shape of a large loaf of bread) was shouting obscenities that reverberated around the block.

But, this place really surprised me. The interior is lovely, especially considering the size and what a lot of other area restaurants would do with the space. Very attentive sit-down service greeted us immediately and took excellent care of us the entire time.

For a starter we got the hummus plate, which came with an awesome and very fresh homemade bread (and came with a bread refill). My omni brother got a doner sampler plate which even made my mouth water. I hardly knew what to do - the vegetarian options are plentiful, especially if you do dairy. I wound up getting a cheese pide, which kind of reminded me of a calzone. Awesome! I can't wait to go back and try some of the other selections.
author: James T.

description:
Visit 1. Very impressive! Fresh, tasty food. We ordered 4 items, 3 of which I didn't recognize. The fourth was a combo doner plate. Everything was very good. They are light on seasoning some items, but I'm fine with that and turned my attention to the overall freshness and flavor. There are another half-dozen menu items I want to try during future visits.

I liked the atmosphere. Large mural of Turkish scenery on 1 wall, a TV showing Turkish TV, quietly, on one wall, open kitchen with a case displaying the skewered meats and prepared salads. Friendly, attentive service.

Visit 1 hooked me, and I'll be back for sure.
author: Greg J.

description:
I desperately want to go back to Turkey after eating here. Definitely returning to A La Turca.

 Just hope I don't almost step in human poo a block away like I did last time.
author: I Like Food, Food Taste Good ..

description: Stopped in by happenstance for lunch and was pleasantly surprised.  I had a wonderful chicken dish with great Turkish tea.  Service was top notch.  I'm sure to try again next time I'm in the area.
author: Bennet K.

description:
I  can not believe they have approval from the health department.
Food was barely warm with yesterday's leftover taste. I can not believe the price they charge  for the garbage they serve. They had some creepy looking people hanging around. I think they were associated with the restaurant. I should avoid this place, because they had only two table was occupied at lunch time. I would not even give one star but it is not an option.
author: Benjamin B.

description: Excellent food!  Will make a point to come here every time I'm in SF!  Service wasn't the best but the food more than made up for it.
author: Tammy H.

description: lamb beyti was phenomenal and filling. they don't seem to care how long you sit. I haven't been able to resist the rice pudding for dessert yet. kind service
author: Dena D.

description: So thankful This place is less than two blocks away from my place. Appetizers are great, baba ghanouj, cacik, ispanakli... So amazing! Had the lamb shish as well. Excellent place, and the waitress was so nice :) one of my favorite in the hood. One of the best parts is the warm bread they give you for the cakic (yoghurt sauce).
author: Alexandra V.

description:
You'd think that after spending 1.5 weeks in Turkey, I'd be tired of Turkish food. But, here I was at A La Turca, less than 1 week after returning from Istanbul, craving Turkish food. Armed with the 4 Turkish phrases i knew, I was ready to be transported back to Istanbul.

We started off the meal with piyaz (white beans, parsley, red and green pepper, onion) and lentil soup. The seasoning of the piyaz was fine, but the white beans were a bit underdone for my preference.  The lentil soup was really good. The lentils, rice, carrots, onion, potato and spices combined to create a savory, thick combination that surpassed many of the lentil soups I had in Turkey. 

I had the grilled kofte plate (ground meat with seasoning and spices made into patties and grilled.) Sadly, this kofte was nothing like the tender, juicy meatball sausage/patties that I had at local koftecerias in Istanbul. The kofte was strangely tough and I struggled to finish half.

The saving grace of the meal was the combo doner plate.  While the beef and lamb doner seemed a bit overdone, the chicken was delicious, perfectly cooked and seasoned.  I noted that this chicken was better than most chicken I had in Turkey.  

We ended the meal with Turkish coffee and Kunefe (Baked kadayif with sweet cheese). The kunefe was excellent: slightly sweet, gooey from the cheese, and crunchy from the baked noodles. 

While I was severely disappointed from the kofte and piyaz, the lentil soup, chicken doner, turkish coffee and kunefe made up for the meal. 

A La Turca, tesekkur ederim (thank you) for the delicious food and friendly service. I will definitely be returning whenever I have a craving for Turkish food.
author: Monelle A.

description: This is my new favorite restaurant in the city. The food was amazing, fresh and not greasy. It took awhile to get the food but when you're waiting for fresh made falafel it's not that hard to wait. The bread they give you with your food is also really really delicious. I had the falafel platter...yumm!
author: Cassy R.

description:
I went here on a Saturday night with a group of people and the service was quick and the seating easy, no wait what so ever. This is the only place that I have eaten "Turkish Cuisine" so I have nothing to compare it to but I'm a fan. 

I had eaten before we went out so I wasn't too hungry so I had an appetizer called Ispanakli Borek. This pastry dough appetizer is baked with feta cheese and spinach. It's light and was just the right amount.

I look forward to going back soon.
author: Justin S.

description: Oh my wonderfulness!! A very nice place for traditional Turkish food.
author: Ethan S.

description:
I recommend only one thing: the beef doner sandwich on the pide bread. don't waste your time with the lavash bread, stick with the pide. It is delicious! The chicken doner is good too. Haven't tried anything else.

OH, you can follow the sandwich up with the rice pudding for dessert. It tastes like cinnamon toast crunch. Really. 

I find that the entree plates are small and kind of expensive for what you get, but the sandwich is the biggest bang for your buck. It is humongous for 7 or 8 bucks. 

People are nice enough, and the place is clean.
author: Sarah A.

description:
I live right in the neighborhood and A La Turca has become one of my usual spots. Whether you're in the TL or not it is worth stopping in. Great prices, delicious food! One of my favourites has to be the pides and the pide bread in general-definitely ask them to bring you some bread! The spices on the table are essential as well-yum!

Good amount of vegetarian options!! I can usually mix it up a bit, even though I almost always get either the spinach and feta or tomato and feta pide. The food is always fresh and of quality ingredients. Great prices as well!! Love this local spot!
author: Brighid F.

description: Awesome food, atmosphere, and service.  I got the chicken platter and had plenty of leftovers!
author: Sara B.

description:
Came here with two girl friends of mine on New Year's Day. I had really good Turkish in New York so I wanted some more. When we arrived around 5:30ish the place was about a little less than half capacity. They stuck us at a tiny table. We ordered

Cacik - yogurt with cucumber, mint, dill, and garlic 
Comes with bread but not enough bread. You HAVE to ask for more. We were unable to finish this. It is pretty good though. We used it for our other dishes as well as with the bread.

Hummus - garbanzo beans puree with garlic, lemon juice, tahini, and spices.
Not bad but I am not a huge fan of hummus. Comes with two black olives.

Iskender Kebap - doner kebab (lamb) in special tomato sauce over cubed bread served with butter and yogurt.
We didn't finish this. The tomato sauce in my opinion is not special. It taste like those tomato sauce you get from a jar. 

Potatoes and Cheese Gozleme - flat bread filled with baked potato mixed with cheese. Looks like a quesadilla.
This was very starchy and super filling. Not bad.

Grilled meat combo.
I think this was our favorite. We completely finished it except for the salad part. I loved the rice. I wish there was more rice. 

Baklava. - dessert. Pretty good. I like.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Maybe my expectations were too high, but I found the food inconsistent and the menu limited.  While they have plenty of meat and veggie pastries and kebabs, they don't have much else.  It would be nice to see Turkish rice dishes, pasta dishes and stews.  

Things started out well with the basket of warm, soft bread and the combo platter of meze/cold appetizers: eggplant salad, yogurt, hummus, dolmas, white bean salad and roasted red pepper salad.  

* Mushroom and cheese gozleme ($6.25): Described as a grilled flat bread, it was very thin and resembled a tortilla.  The sliced mushrooms seemed to be the canned variety.  It was like a flavorless quesadilla.  They should add some herbs.  Very disappointing.  

* Kavurmali & Cheese Pides ($8.50):  This was like a calzone - a soft, thick doughy baked turnover filled with melted cheese, lamb cubes, red pepper and onions - rather tasty 

We also had a borek which is another savory pie but with a thin, buttery, flaky baked shell.  Each rectangular borek is quite small and flat.  We received 2 for $4.95.  It was fine, nothing too special.

* Combo grill meat platter ($13.50) with lamb shis, kofte, doner and beef shis, fluffy rice, green salad and yogurt.  I wasn't too impressed with any of the meat.  The flavor was just okay and some pieces were dry.

I think the complimentary bread was the best part of the meal, followed by the pides.  Every dish came with a side salad, which seemed odd.

The atmosphere is lively and casual and the restaurant is smack dab in middle of the Tenderloin.  Would I brave the Tenderloin again for their food?  I think not.
author: Lolia S.

description: Excellent food and great service from this family owned restaurant. Highly recommend their homemade Pide bread.
author: Mayo M.

description:
The food was great, so why the 2 star review? Well, let me explain.

My group of 7 came into the restaurant and were seated at a long table near the door. I got excited when talking to some of my friends and knocked my water all over the table. The waiter man came quickly to clean it and refill my water.

Looking at the menu, everything looked foreign to me. I don't have any idea what Turkish food will be like, so I just picked the chicken beyti, as recommended by the waiter. 

No regrets with the food. The chicken beyti was great! My friend exclaimed, "it tastes like a Hot Pocket!" I'm not sure I completely agree with her in that regard. The beyti is a wrap with chicken on the inside and a large portion of yogurt sauce and some red sauce for dipping. The shell of the wrap was nice and crispy, and all of the sauces were excellent with it. I was thoroughly satisfied with my meal.

My friend and I decided that we also wanted to try some Turkish coffee and dessert. So we went up to the register and asked for some coffee and a recommendation for dessert. We asked the younger lady for some baklava and 2 coffees. We stood around for a little bit, and then asked if we would be paying now or with the rest of our bill. When she realized that we weren't walk-in customers, and that we had been eating at a table for the past half hour, she got angry because she had already put the baklava in a to-go box and not a plate. The waiter who had been serving us for the evening told us to go ahead and have a seat and he'll bring out our dessert and coffee. The coffee came cutely in a little cup, and was bitter in a way that doesn't make you scrunch up your face while drinking. There was a thick layer of grain powder at the bottom of the cup. My friend and I realized afterward that we were supposed to stir it first. The baklava was moist, oozing out honey with each bite. I found it quite enjoyable.

The bill came, and our table paid. We sat around and talked for maybe 10 minutes. And then this older Turkish woman with short black hair and a red apron comes over and says, "You guys want anything else? If not, please leave. There's no room here, it's cramped in here." My friends and I looked around the restaurant. No one waiting at the door. At least 5 tables open for more customers. And yet she wanted us to leave? We got up and left, and that was it.

While the first impression was great, I was left with a sour impression of the establishment. That last impression of the woman kicking us out is enough to keep me from coming back here ever!
author: Emily T.

description: What a great place.  I spent a month in Turkey, and ever since have been looking for a good Iskender Kebob.  I plan on making many trips back!
author: Harry B.

description:
Update from four to five stars.  Here's why.

Food is as good as ever, up a notch or two since my last visit.  Every single dish was spot on, from white beans to lamb shank to phylo concoction.  The ayran (salty yogurt) was thin enough to serve as a drink, but had a substantial and pleasant flavor like a dish - lays down the gauntlet for the local Indian restaurants to step up their lassi.  

Although unappealing and a little scary from the sidewalk (folk art pastoral murals of the homeland framed by stone walls is so 1970s), once you get in, the atmosphere is really cool - comforting...  The staff is very personable, real people and they're nice.  The menu is fairly extensive.  If you're only casually acquainted with Mediterranean cuisine, kebabs and hummus and such, you'll find lots of new things, and variants on what you know.

Being incredibly inexpensive is a big plus - it's priced only slightly above fast food: $8-11 for some of the main meals, $5 for desserts, $14 for a 6-salad appetizer plate for 2 (that could really be 4), each one better than the other.  And this is for sit down full service food at fine dining quality for taste and presentation.  Also, it's relatively healthy.  Things are a lot lighter than I'm used to.  Hummus was light on the tahini, the eggplant dip had none.

It's a good go to place that you could make into a regular hangout.
author: Gil S.

description:
I lived in Turkey for a little over a year. I was married to a Turkish man for many, many years. I've had Turkish food from many Turkish restaurants and in peoples homes while there. A La Turca is solid. It's not great like the food back in Turkey is great - that's just impossible. 

That said, I was happy with my experience here tonight. I've eaten here many times before but this was my first experience since I started eating meat again. My guest for the evening was my very handsome 12 year old kid. 

Menu:

Patlican Biber Kizartmasi and Lahmacun as appetizers. I liked the Kizartma quite a bit. The Lahmacun was alright in my book but it wasn't something I would write home about. I think next time I might just get a regular pide. 

Adana and doner kebabs. Both were delicious.We each had a cup of ayran and topped off our meal by sharing a bowl of sutlac. Our bill for the meal, with tip, was $54.00. 

I really liked the Adana kebab but I had always been told it's a spicy kebab. Their Adana kebab, while flavorful, was definitely not spicy. There's a strong chance it's been made a bit milder for American palates. I give their chef credit for serving meat that seems perfectly cooked. Their pilav is pretty darn good, too. 

I would like their red cabbage on the salad to be a bit more like the pickled red cabbage that's served in Turkey. It may sound like an odd criticism but Turkish style pickled red cabbage is sublime. 

All in all I am a happy camper. I'll be back to try some yummy stuff with the kiddo. It's a fun way to spend a Saturday evening and it's good for him to enjoy the food of his father's culture. The service here is good, too! Especially if you speak a few words of Turkish. :) 

Cootz OUT! 

({})
author: Cooter T.

description: I hadn't been here since moving from the Hood a couple of years ago. Went with friends who'd never been. A La Turca was just as good as I remembered. The food is so fresh and delicious, nicely presented and reasonably priced. The dolmas are the best I've eaten outside of Chicago. Salad that accompanies the entrees is crisp and good with housemade dressing. Rice pudding is exquisite. Turkish coffee done right rounds out the experience.
author: stephan k.

description:
I had the chicken mushroom doner, and it was great. Almost like a sort of little sandwich, savory and filling while feeling lean and tender. The bread they brought as an appetizer was great too, so crispy, we kept eating it before we got our meal.

Very good service as well. Split our bills from memory. I would definitely go here again.
author: Ned D.

description:
I was a part of Emily T.'s party (she posted below me). Like she said, GREAT food!! I'd probably rate it a 4, but the rest..... meh. Let me share my experience.

As I said before, good food - at least what I ordered. I had the lamb shish kebab and it was delicious. Price wasn't too bad. My friend had the eggplant salad.. I wouldn't recommend that. Looked like purple apple sauce haha but he said it wasn't too bad.

The waiter was kind and accommodating, but he seemed to be the only one. The rest of the staff kind of stood in the bad watching everyone and talking amongst themselves. Not sure if they even did anything productive while I was there. There was a large group of people next to us when we first got there and they were having a good time, but their kids were running amuck. I know it's not the establishment's fault, but they could have said something and asked the parents to keep their kids quieter. I guess this is just indicative of the crowd that normally goes there? Shortly afterwards there were maybe 4 or 5 kids left and some adults. None of them were actually at a table and the kids were crowded up against me and my party. They were loud, rude, SITTING ON MY COAT that I had put down next to me on the bench, and actually were staring at us! Kind of like the workers, but more blatantly. Again, not the establishments fault.. but indicative of the crowd that goes there. --- Yet another reason to add to my list of why I stay away from places in the tenderloin area.

After paying the bill, within five minutes a lady came up and said we needed to leave if we weren't going to buy anything else. Umm.. there was no crowd, plenty of empty tables, and yet we weren't welcome there anymore.. Practically saying "thank you for your money - now get out." Wow.
author: Brad Y.

description: Grubbed some Manti here this past sunday. Didn't taste super fresh and the flavor of the meat stuffing was unremarkable. The 'sauce' was a watery, oily, yogurty blend with some dried herbs sprinkled on top. Nothing great. Perhaps I'll come back to try some lamb.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Great prices, good food, and I love that this is a Turkish place that is vegetarian-friendly.  The gozleme I had was fabulous (feta cheese and tomato) and my date (ok, my husband) had a mushroom pide.  Both were delicious.  The fresh bread that comes with the baba ganouj was worth a trip to the restaurant by itself.

Also really enjoyed the yogurt drink, which I had never tried before.  Not too sweet and just the right amount of sour.
author: Liz S.

description:
A La Turca is an unexpected find in the Tenderloin. After coming here a couple times, I think it's safe to say that I'm a big fan! I have to admit that I usually order the grilled meat combo plate & force my boyfriend to get something else so that I can try something new (HAHA). So, while the grilled meat combo is for sure awesome, w/ tender grilled chunks of meat, doner and that delicious lamb meatball, some of the other dishes can be a hit or miss. 

We didn't really like the special pasta dish, sigara boregi (feta cheese eggroll), or lahmacun (thin dough layered with a thin layer of meat). The beyti & pides are good, but my favorite items are from the griddle (except for the donner, which can be a little dry). I don't think I even mentioned the best part of the griddle dishes -- the tasty buttery rice pilaf that's served with it! So fatty & tasty, I can eat it forever!
author: Ruby H.

description: BEST TASTING TEA EVER!!! Kebab meals always fill you up just right. Very relaxed atmosphere and excellent service with a smile. Can't ask for more.
author: Hector M.

description:
Ummm, this place is ridiculously tasty! After eating here, I wanted to move to Turkey. Or move into the restaurant...

I highly recommend getting the appetizer sampler so you can taste their delicious white bean salad, baba ganoush, tzatziki, etc. They serve this insane bread called pide, and it's pipping hot. 

Bottom line--go to A La Turca--your taste buds will thank you.
author: Lindsay U.

description:
Hooray for random ethnic restaurants found through yelp!

Gf and I were wandering around the area and referred to trusty ol Yelp to find us a good dinner.  A La Turca came up and I finished my beefy meal very impressed.  For a Turkish food noob like me, I went with the combo meat plate.  I honestly wasn't able to tell which was which, but they all tasted great and were spiced really well.  The salad, rice, and yogurt sauce that came with it was definitely welcome too.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I was really happy to eat some Turkish food, but It was very disappointment restaurant. We ordered lentil soup, lahmacun, and Adana kebab. 

Soup was good, but we had to wait for bread. They brought to bread like 5 minutes after the soup.

Lahmacun was not great, but not bad. I think it was okay if we think we are in USA.

Anada Kebab was horrible. It was burnt. We could not finish all. It was the worst one i had.

It was interesting that random people were getting into kitchen(There was a lady.) You cannot do that it is a restaurant. Health is a important issue.
author: Hasan Y.

description: great lamb doner and kebob, friendly owner.
author: Long C.

description:
For persecutive: I've eaten a lot of Turkish food, so I am a bit ore picky in this area than others might be. :-)  I would give it 3.5 stars if given the option. 

I have gone here twice within days and had 2 different experiences.

The bread is amazingly awesome.  yummm.  So delicious when hot.  I haven't had better bread in other Turkish restaurants yet.  I havent tried them all yet though ;-) 

The turkish tea was good - not overcooked and bitter. 

Other than that, the food was simply good. They are the only place in town that I have found that has Lahmacun (which is basically a turkish version of flatbread pizza.  I like much more meat on the top, but it was definitely something that was enjoyable. We also tried the gozleme & pide (also not something easy to find in SF Turkish restaurants  - they are Turkish versions of a calzone or empanada), as well as a variety of meats & appetizers. 

The first experience was one that was very good in terms of flavor & service.  The guy waiting on us was very attentive.  The second time the food was ok & the service was not great.  The woman was nice, but not attentive enough and we had to wave her down (when she was paying attention) in order to get service & ultimately the check.  Oh, and it wasn't a matter of being busy - she had less tables than the previous waiter did when I had come in last.  

So - this is a hit or miss place.  I would go again when in the area.
author: N A.

description: Had the ezme and heytai kebap. Both really excellent. Small menu, friendly service. Definite upgrade to union square places.
author: Oliver R.

description:
A La Turca has been around now for some years.  There was a contender or two to deal with, but they've all melted away.  The gyros are lovely, the staff are polite, yet friendly--despite having to deal with the occasional colorful character that wanders in.--I believe there's a standing lunch special of a $5 gyro wrap too.

Love their baclava & you can see that they make their own savory and sweet pastries, as well as the breads. 

While I consider it a tasty work lunch treat, I can see that it would make for a nice dinner place as well.
author: Rebecca R.

description: Delicious Turkish food often served by beautiful Turkish women. Vegetarian-friendly. Anchors are pretty cheap, too. I love this place!
author: Ethan J.

description: Looks sketch from the outside, but inside it's a warm and welcoming family-style restaurant. My friend and I couldn't decide on what to pick from the menu so we ended up sharing the combo appetizer platter and the combo meat platter, as well as some kadayif (think baklava shredded wheat) for dessert. There was enough food to feed another person for sure especially with the basket of fresh bread provided. We left full and satisfied with plenty of leftovers to take home.
author: Elaine W.

description: I was there once, and the food was ok. I've tried borek and lamb wrap, and (coming from a country where we eat turkish food on a daily basis), I'd say the food is 3/5. Service was good, friendly and fast.
author: Igor P.

description: Don't know where to begin. Love all the food from entree to desserts. Love love the Turkish coffee. Favorites are the kofte plate & any donner plate.  The desserts are yum!  The cheese bread is a great starter along with the simple but delicious salad.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I'll admit it, I'm into appearances.  So when I was driving around (and around, and around) looking for parking near here before I met the lovely and talented Katie for dinner, I was a little dubious about this place.  

Well, you can't judge a restaurant by it's façade, nor the random vagrants roaming the streets near it.  The inside is very homey, and the food is AMAZING.  Great hummus, and our shared entrees were also fantastic.  The waitress was very sweet, on top of things without being too intrusive.  

What keeps it from warranting 5 stars?  I don't like the smell of B.O. in the afternoon in the bathroom.
author: Pam S.

description:
It's rare that I use this word to describe a place, but the food I had at A La Turca on New Year's Eve was truly amazing.  We started with an order of Havuc Kizartmasi which consisted of sauteed carrot slices on top of an amazing garlic yogurt sauce.  This was a wonderfully flavorful dish that would be worth coming back for alone.  Then for my main course I ordered the Beyti Kebap, which involved perfectly cooked ground lamb wrapped in lavash bread and topped with a great spicy tomato sauce and a garlicky yogurt sauce on the side.  This was without a doubt one of the best dishes I've had in months, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't think about returning the next night to get another fix.  We wrapped things up with a perfect turkish coffee, and the bill for three people, two appetizers, beer, and coffee was all of $63.  

Combine all of this with the fact that it's next door to one of my favorite bars, the Ha-Ra, and you have a place I'll be coming back to time and time again.  Just don't order the Turkish beer.  The phrase "tastes like mule urine" comes to mind.
author: Joshua W.

description: No frills restaurant with great food and fast service! It could use a little makeover on the inside - I felt like I was at a deli of sorts, but the food is solid, and the price is right!
author: Kane A.

description:
My good Turkish friends brought me here for the first time few years ago. To them  A La Turca was the closest they could find from a traditional Turkish restaurant. Although they stated that the food was better in Turkey this place is apparently legit. 

Im craving for their cheese pide, so good. The Sucuk and cheese one is also really yummy. 
I've tried many of their platters, but my favorite by far is the Adana Kebab. The lamb is well seasoned and really tasty. Even the rice pilaf and salad that come with it are good. 
Finally the desert I've been dreaming about since the first bite. Kunefe. You really gotta try that. Even though Im always full at the end of the dinner, I can't never leave without having my Kunefe. Yes total addict. 

The only down point for this place would be the location.. not always a super pleasure to park and walk in the TL. 

The service is mostly nice, and sometimes not really in the mood of working. 
Overall this place serves good turkish food for a good value, thumbs up.
author: Alice G.

description:
Parked across the street...starving after a workout... looking around for something to eat...Domino's pizza or Turkish cuisine? Hmmm...
Clean, small place with a friendly and attentive staff. Several people getting food to go... let's try it...

Chicken Doner (chicken sandwich with red cabbage and other veggies in a homemade round whole pita bread $7.00): considering I was starving it was ok. Had hot sauce on the side to give it flavor.

BF had the lamb kabob with salad and rice. Very small portion for $16.00+. He said the lamb was hard and had better at other places. (He ate the other half of my sandwich since the lamb left him still hungry. My poor baby...)

Waiter (nice guy) asked if we wanted a side of bread. We thought it was free but was charged $1.85. It was similar to my sandwich bread but fluffier. Would have been better with butter or some kind of a dip (didn't come with any).

Would we come back? No
Will it satisfy your hunger? Yes....but so will Domino's pizza.
author: M B.

description:
Yes, as good as it gets!!!

Living in San Diego w/ very few Turkish restaurants (and most of them fast food doner, at that), we were beyond happy to go to San Francisco for a friend's birthday, as we'd seen lots of Turkish places on yelp w/ good reviews!

We went to A La Turca twice over a long weekend, once with a group of 7 and once, just me and my boyfriend. 

With the b-day group, we ordered a bunch of things and shared everything. The vegetarian meze appetizer sampler, lentil soup, boreks, and probably 5 entrees. Highlights were definitely they BEYTI (both chicken & lamb/beef), the chicken doner (amazingly delicious! I would be eating this weekly if it was here in San Diego), and the spinach and cheese pide. The birthday desserts were KUNEFE (highly recommended - a variety of textures and flavors for a party in your mouth!), baklava, and sutlac (baked rice pudding). All good!

We stopped in one last time before our flight and were delighted to see that MANTI was a special... it's basically a Turkish ravioli, homemade in the restaurant, by a little Turkish grandmother type, I think Sundays only? We actually saw the adorable little woman walking around the kitchen and wanted to thank her personally because it was THAT delicious. Perfect amount of spiciness to it. I'm not exaggerating when I say I wanted to lick the rest of the sauce off the plate... but I settled for dipping their delicious bread into it to soak up every last drop. 

The service was a little slow with the group because we came during a busy dinner hour and were sitting on the top balcony area, but it wasn't terribly slow... think more of a relaxing, long dinner. The 2nd visit was great, service-wise. All of the staff were very great and helpful (the server actually told us to get the manti!) and to recommend things to do in the area as well! I can guarantee we will be back whenever we are within 50 miles of the place :)

A La Turca, please come to San Diego!! :))) I want some of your chicken doner right now!!!
author: Kuzu K.

description:
One of my favorite dinners for two in SF is the appetizer combo platter and the chicken sheesh kebab plate at A La Turce.  You get six appetizers (an eggplant spread, hummus, cacik, bell pepper salad, white bean salad, and something else that escapes me at the moment), a basket of pide bread, an ample portion of tender and flavorful grilled chicken breast, salad, and rice, all for under $30.

(I can't give it 5* only because I've had slightly better versions of some of these dishes at other places.)
author: Zain K.

description:
Came here to enjoy some post-superbowl grub, which didn't fail me!! Walked all the way through the TL to get there, too!

We started with some sort of Turkish style pizza that had some ground beef and veggies on it.  It was pretty good, but I'm sure they have better options for apps. I really wanted to try the hummus, but that's not really authentic Turkish cuisine, so we steered clear of that.

The atmosphere was great.  The tv was showing FoxTurca! Hahaha.  The people sitting next to us were super friendly and gave us some recommendations.  The staff was very attentive to our needs, friendly, and helpful.

I ended up ordering the Beyti Kebap, which was lamb rolled in some sort of a puffed pastry.  It was so so soooooo good and flavorful, but I did not care for the yogurt sauce...

Next time when I'm not so full, I'll definitely be indulging in the baklavah for dessert :)
author: Jenny W.

description: I really like this place.  I am going back.  In fact, in just a few days.  I tried it for the first time a few weeks ago and have been back 3 times.  Great Turkish bread with their hummus (hummus is a bit bland.  Yemeni's hummus is delish!), baba ganoush is quite tasty, and the combo donor is really good.  The rice is awesome- I don't know what they put into it but super tasty.  Filling portions at a really good price.  The location can be hit or miss so be prepared but the food makes it worth it to go.  Service is SUPER friendly and helpful.
author: Deal G.

description: Good service. Tasty appetizers. Ordered the Kiymali Borek and it was very tasty, if a little plain. The Sigara Boregi was quite good and the lamb shish kebab was VERY tender. Would definitely recommend.
author: Julius H.

description:
The price is right...
The food is right...
the GAWFEE IS THE AWESOME CRASHENDO...

You can tell a good Chinese restaurant by how many Chinese folks be packin da joint....
Well, at dis place, nothin but Turkish folks....I didn't know they existed outside the Sacramento Kings & da NBA.  Well, me n my ignant self went up in here cuz da menu said something was under $10

I ordered a dish wid lamb and yogurt sauce....and then I finished it off with some Turkish Gawfee...an awesome finish.
And I asked one of the waitresses about Mustafa Sandal...she said he like wut N'sync was 10 years ago...but I be jammin with Mustafa doh

So, in finality, the food was fresh, da lamb was cut in front of my face, and I done put all my junk in da trunk, cuz all yall know da TENDERLOIN aint a place to leave ya stuff layin out everywhere in da car...just FYI
author: Jay M.

description:
I go there at least twice a week. I work in the TL and if I don't want to eat Vietnamese food everyday, A La Turca is the best alternative. 

The Lentil soup is soooo good! I get it every time I go there, rain or shine. 
The A La Turca salad is really good too, although get the shish chicken instead of the other option. The lamb and the chicken on the rotating skewers kind of do my head in... and the meat is more than often dry so I go for the skewers instead which are really good.
The bread is so good too. 
The service is usually great as well.
author: Tova L.

description: Great place! Seedy-ish neighborhood. Service is ok (just ask for what you want when you want it). The food is AMAZING and price is right! We ate basically everything on the menu and it was all very very good. Highly recommend.
author: Michael A.

description:
That is the problem with Yelp, we are overly enthusiastic people.  I was pretty psyched to eat here thinking I was possibly going to get "the best Turkish in the city"... But (shrug) it just wasn't.

I was feeling the combos, so we got the combo veggie appetizer, the combo meat plate and the veggie cheese pide which I pronounced with a long "i" all night.  I should have looked that one up before I left.  Oh well (shrug). So the food was good, but not great... I took pictures. The servers were darling and the place was cozy just like everyone said.  I would go back, but with lower expectations.  A solid 3.5, but 4 because it was charming.

Get a pide.
author: Hayley W.

description: Came in tonight, the waitress looked right at me as I sat down.  She sat and spoke with someone at the same table for several minutes.  Then the waitress went to the area by the cash register.  She stood there for a little bit, then talked with an older gentleman who was working, assuming manager or owner.  Looked at me again several times in between this.  A table went to the register and paid, she spoke with them for several minutes.  They left.  She looks at me and goes back to talking to the manager again.  At this point 10 minutes have gone by.  I left and got a burrito at Gordo's instead.  Forget you A La Turca.  I'll take my business else where.
author: T. E.

description: Amazing! So flavorful and delicious. I had the combo doner for lunch. The Turkish tea was perfect as well.
author: Melisa W.

description: Really a surprise!  Not a fancy place, but clean and very reasonable. Great food. Turkish food made really well. ..
author: Steve T.

description:
Seriously...this is the BEST Turkish food in the Bay! I've been to many different Turkish restaurants, but even the fancy ones cannot compare to A la Turca. This is a no nonsense restaurant, very basic interior but the food is absolutely amazing. I have had their lam and beef shish kebab- the meat was so tender and juicy tastes just out of this world.

Nice thing is that you get great freshly baked moist Turkish bread while you await your entree to arrive and the waiters/waitresses are nice and friendly. 

As dessert we had Kadaiff,(strongly recommend this) which tasted just the way it should be..sweet and crispy.

Price : average...I know there are cheaper places around, but I would say that the food is way worth paying for so I am OK with it.
author: Achraf S.

description: I really dig their plates here, the wraps are ok, but the bread on the side is AWESOME.  Very good service, simple place, solid food over all and a place I do come back often too.
author: James H.

description: Five stars for a great restaurant. We drove 2 hours to have lunch here. The food, staff and service were all excellent. The restaurant was very pleasant and cosy. I loved all the pillows all around me. We loved their lamb doner and their byti kebab as well. Also, we loved their potato and cheese pied. I promised that I would give this restaurant a great review. Their tea is amazing along with their hummus. I am definitely coming back this winter.
author: Sam A.

description: The food is STUNGING and Staff are A-1 service but the neighborhood is NOT worth going at night unless you hire a limbo. DO  NOT park your auto near by. My friend Porsche Boxxer S Turbo was strip to the frame!  Why the owner place such a awesome restaurant in a danger location. Go to Marin CA location it by far nicer and the rent is not as high!
author: EdwardF A.

description: I've been here, yesterday and Its best place to have a turkish food in SF i ever been,service is really good.
author: John M.

description:
I had the combo platter last night, and it was solid. I had heard great reviews, but I didn't think it was anything special. That being said, all of the reviews raved about the sandwiches and the pide bread; I got the platter and the lavash. Turns out lavash is a flat, bland bread. 

I was eating with someone who got one of the oven 'pides', which are almost like Turkish calzones. It looked FANTASTIC, and I will be going back asap to get one of those. Look for an update.
author: Alex L.

description:
It is possible that I am giving 5 stars specifically because A La Turca is close to Union Square, home to the most bullshit overpriced and disgusting food in the entire city.

But I'd give 5 stars to the lentil soup alone.

I am officially addicted to the soup, even though it's sometimes thick and sometimes not (yeah I've eaten there enough times so that I have noticed the difference).  But it is always delicious.  Lemony, pepper-y, undefinable-y good and soothing, especially with the ridiculous bread they serve. Warm and fresh and delicious!

The hummus and baba ganoush are also great, and I've tried a few chicken dishes as well, which are good but a little too oily for me.  I've had great service there regularly, and as a regular have been treated to free appetizers when my food was taking longer than usual.

As a registered carbohydrate freak, I frequently order a bowl of the soup with the free bread, plus refill hell yeah, then one of the pides.  I'm especially fond of the spinach/cheese one.  Pide are basically Turkish calzone, and they are off the hook delicious.  Hot and savory and filling, perfectly paired with a side salad.

For desert go for the baklava and a tiny cup of perfect tea.  I love this place.
author: Alanna C.

description: I think maybe this place has gone downhill. I've been several times but the last few have been blah. Today I had a shepherd salad, humus and a spinach and cheese golems thing. All were boring or worse. Service was good but I can't recommend this place anymore.
author: Raj T.

description:
What a gem to find this restaurant in TENDER NOB.

If it's your first time to go here do your homework and check out the menu on their website first!  They've got great pictures of all the dishes that they serve.  Sadly, the in-restaurant menus do not provide the same illustrations.

If I had a Turkish friend, I'm sure his mom's house would be decorated just like this eclectic place =)

I've never had Turkish food before, so I was absolutely blown away at how delicious and fresh everything tasted.  For appetizers we ordered the Sigara Boregi and Kadayif.  I wasn't exactly sure what was inside the sigara boregi, but it was similar to an eggroll that was packed with so much cheesy goodness!  The kadayif reminded me of a shredded mini-wheat drenched in baklava syrup.

I ordered the lamb shish kabob, with a side of rice and house salad.  I enjoyed the lamb and felt a little clumsy eating the salad.  

Because of the sketchy neighborhood, I would only go back with a group of people, in the day time, if I can find parking right up front...or take it to-go...
author: Rochelle D.

description:
The reason why I gave 4 star was the food is fantastic, but the service is just terrible. If you are patient enough for the good food with a very slow service, it's worth a try.

As you probably know, middle eastern food is healthy, one of my favorite cuisine. Olive oil, lots of vegetables and yogurt... yum.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Cathy Y. and I came here after an invigorating pilates class last week, picking up her boyfriend on the way.  I'm a lover of all food middle eastern, and while I don't know what makes food decidedly turkish, I know that a la turca was delish.  

We started with the fried cigar shaped pastries filled with feta cheese.  I prefer this to the standard mozzarella cheese sticks that dominate american bar food, late night microwaving, and bowling alley menus.  We then shared the Iskender Kebap (lamb and beef with tomato sauce over bread with yogurt) and Adana Kebap (minced lamb log).  The Iskender was my favorite.  The Adana probably would not have filled me up, but the Iskender had a ton of meat.

The decor and layout make a la turca feel pretty casual, which was good since i didn't feel self conscious showing up in yoga pants and messy hair.  The food in the display case all looked good to, so I could see myself stopping by for take out.  

The waitress was nice, but not overly attentive.  My water glass was never refilled until the very end and no one came by our table to see how we were periodically so I couldn't ask for more water.  

The food is good and fresh.  I don't know if it's the best in the area, but sure, i'd go back.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Food was better than expected.  The highlight of our meal was the bread.  The rolls were piping hot from the oven, moist as fragrant.  You've got to have the bread.

I've designed menus for similar restaurants and I still have no idea what many of the items are.  Pictures would be nice but sadly not classy, however it's located near the corner of nasty and filthy with shopping cards parked outside. I think pictures on the menu are appropriate.

The hummus was a bit gritty and the Babaganush a little bland. The lamb cubes we're juicy but the sliced meats were a little dry.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I stopped by A La Turca on the way to the Curious George exhibit at the Jewish Contemporary Museum.  We had actually intended to eat at Brenda's French Soul Food, but found the long wait to be a bit frustrating.  So we walked a few blocks and found A La Turca along the way.

There were only two other people inside at lunchtime on a Saturday.  Some people see that as a bad sign when evaluating a restaurant, but I don't usually let that deter me. 

The only point of reference I have to compare the food to is Old Jerusalem in the Mission.  It's not that much different than what you might expect to find at a falafel house either.  That is to say, the food at A La Turca tastes vaguely middle-eastern to me.

As such, I ordered the same thing I had at  Old Jerusalem, a bowl of lentil soup and a sandwich.  The doner sandwich is somewhat akin to a shawarma, except the bread is different, and I liked the version I had at A La Turca better than the one at Old Jerusalem.  The Lentil soup was better at Old Jerusalem though.  

We got some baklava to go, and when we opened it a few hours later, it had soaked through the paper box.  Keep that in mind, I guess.
author: Gopal R.

description: i work a block away from here and usually call in to order, they are always on time with their service. pick-up are always on time as informed on the phone.  my favorites are  beyti platter and falafel wrap.
author: Thanh B.

description: Great food, service and atmosphere. What more can you ask for? A La Turca is definitely a gem in the TL!
author: Jay G.

description:
Downtown on a Friday night and reservation-less, which didn't leave a whole lot of options.   And so I dragged my parents through the TL (and right past the prostitute on the corner, nice) to A La Turca, hoping they'd like the good food and decent prices. 

I really enjoyed my first visit here, but wasn't as enthralled with the food the second time around.  Still good, but probably more worthy of three and a half stars than four.

The freebie bread was awesome.  My chicken doner was a little salty but still enjoyable.  I was the only one who liked the smoky eggplant mezes but the gozleme ("Turkish pizza") went over well, as did the shish kebaps.

Pretty quiet for a Friday night, but service was still friendly and nice.
author: Joanne G.

description: Awesome food. This is my preferred Turkish restaurant for now. The service is very friendly. I usually take the döner sandwich. They have some great dessert too.
author: Nicolas G.

description: yummy! Had a mushroom and cheese gozleme. It was like a turkish quesadilla. It was pretty nom nom, but more expensive than a quesadilla. The interior was really cozy and comfy, the ppl pretty nice. I would try again, but as I said a bit expensive. I work around here, so it makes sense for me, but I would not go out of my way into the TL. I mean if you were seeing an early show at the New Century, or pickin up some methadone near by, it makes sense, but otherwise, Troya, or gyro king, or park gyros, i mean this place seems way more authentic, but I can only give 3 stars until I try falafel...
author: Chelsey G.

description: Wow... Had the combo plate, the lamb was out of this world.  Incredible.  Like nothing I've ever had before.  An explosion of flavor and wonders like pop rocks sizzling in my mouth.  I'm so happy I've found this place!  Can't wait to go back. Bomb.com son!
author: Justin K.

description:
This Turkish restaurant is delicious..all for a great price! :)

I've passed by this restaurant a couple of times, but finally decided to check it out after reading a review in the Chronicle.  The inside has a very homely feel and the hostess/waitress was really friendly and helpful!
My friend and I shared an appetizer called Ispanakli borek and it was definitely a good choice! The perfectly flakey crust stuffed with feta cheese and spinach HMMmm :)
Then we shared a dish "from the griddle" It was basically like a quesadilla and we ordered the one with mushrooms and cheese. 
Even though we only got 2 dishes, it was filling.

Will DEFINITELY be coming back to try some more dishes!
author: Kei H.

description:
If you are not familiar with this particular part of S.F., it can get a little dangerous at night. (Just a heads up) I went here with a friend this week during the day. When I walked in, the place looked so cute. The wall was a mural of Istanbul. (I found out from my friend.) Our waitress was soft-spoken but very friendly. 

Our meal came out quickly. We ordered a hot appetitizer that contained feta cheese and spinach. I could not pronounce it or remember how it's spelled. The pastry-like thing had a light, fluffly crust. The taste had a hint of butter. It was delicious. The other item we ordered had mushroom and cheese from the griddle. It was a perfect quesadilla. The flat bread was nice and crisp. Also, the dishes had a mini salad on the plate, which tasted good too. For my drink, I had a Turkish tea, a black tea, and it went very well with the meal.

Overall, I ate some good food and had a good experience. This is my first time having Turkish food, so I cannot my experience to do something. And that's why I gave it 5 stars.
author: Ange G.

description:
Soooooo delicious!

I've eaten here about 4 times and each time its been totally yummy.
The wait staff is friendly as well.

If you have never had turkish food, i would recommend trying it...I am glad i did and cant wait to come back!!!!
author: Ripley B.

description:
Happy to report the lamb/beef doner pita sando is delicious. and big enough for two small appetites viz a viz light snack..  If, its just you, it will hit your tummy like a hand grenade. Your tummy tiger will be spent and ready to crawl under the nearest tree for a snooze.

Ambience is ok, love the turkish TV station and turkish music. Safe to go here during the day, not a good part of town at night .
  As I've seen before the lunch specials of food that are being heated in a big tray, under the heating lamps look oily,unappetizing and a hard $8 bucks.
quick muni ride on the 38L   , from financial district, get off at Leavenworth and walk toward Van Ness. The food is like Greek , yet different. Safe bet: lamb or falafel, consistently good.
author: Bert K.

description:
Falafel Plate: best I've ever tasted
Order of Hummus: best I've ever tasted
Lentil Soup: pretty damn good

Some of their dishes are good for when you have an appetite, some are definitely not. Your plate will come with exactly what the menu says (aka if you are hungry you might want to get an order of rice if the menu doesn't come with one...) However, if you are really hungry the falafel plate will do juuuuuust fine :)
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I a prepare for my trip to Turkey, I want to get exposed to the food as much as possible.  Alaturca was my first choice.   Tucked in the Tenderloin, my friends and I were quite weary of the place. But after entering inside, our worries disappeared. 

Being that I have dietary restrictions of not eating dairy and rice, they were very accommodating.  The waitress checked to make sure that the food that I ordered would not have any. My friends and I shared the hummus, which needed salt.  The bread that came with it was enjoyable, fresh from the oven and light in texture.  The lamahcun, was tasty and better than the one that I made the night before.  I had the doner platter with extra salad, substituting it for the rice. The salad had too much dressing on it, but the doner was very delicious.  The flavor was amazing. 

For dessert, my friends shared the baklava and kadayif. Unfortunately, I was unable to taste it, but my friends must have liked it as it was gone within 10 seconds.

The next time I am in the Tenderloin, I will have to come here again.
author: Marck N.

description:
I have to say that I was very disappointed with the food here.  I read the review in 7*7 and expected more.  I figured it would be no thrills, it's a cheap place in the Tendrnob but I expected authentic food.  It started with a salad that didn't resemble anything you would get in Turkey or any other country from that area and the California black canned olives on top of it just reinforced that theory.  

The Kababs were OK and the pastry filled with meat was more bread than meat.  Overall we didn't leave very satisfied with the food and figured we could have spend a little more to have a much better meal.
author: Inga W.

description:
Authentic Turkish food!

Obvious care goes toward serving uncompromisingly fresh fare.  Most Turkish standards are available on the regular menu, and if they only had mackerel sandwiches you could delay your next eating trip to Istanbul.

Consider the daily special, which changes frequently; this will show you that the chef is a serious professional.  Kuru fasulye is my personal favorite.

I always order a glass of the "House Burgundy" (clearly gamay-based by aroma and taste); $3.75, and it compliments all the meat dishes.  If you've heard (or assumed) box wine is crap, try this one and then reconsider.  Box wine technology kicks ass on re-corking a bottle of red wine opened a day or two earlier -- even with those corny nitrogen spray and vacu-pump gizmos.

The bread, gratis with meals, is dangerously habit-forming.

I've been to A La Turca roughly eight or nine times, mostly during the mid-2009 period when they received so many dings for poor service.  But I've been favorably impressed by the service every single time.
author: Francisco G.

description: Great Turkish food (entrees, deserts, coffee), vegetarian options, great atmosphere (music, painted murals, local Turks), easy location = authentic!
author: Adam B.

description: No frills, tasty Turkish cuisine.  We ordered the Chef's Meze Selection which came with a bunch of assorted dips, hummus, dolma, and other items with fresh warm bread.  Very yummy.  I had the "Beyti Kebap," which is ground lamb wrapped with a pastry dough and baked with a cream sauce.  Very tasty, if a little heavy, but that's probably just how the dish is.  Would definitely come back.
author: Matt Y.

description:
awesome. this was the 1st place i ate when i moved to the loin and i've been coming back several times a month, even when i moved to pacifica. I'm veggie and there are several awesome options, listed in order of their awesomeness:
1. tomato and cheese pide
2. falafel sandwich
3. fried carrots appetizer (can't remember the actual name for it- i think it's #16 on the menu)
extra stars for delicious pide bread and super-nice workers that remember your order everytime you go in. i suppose it helps that i order the same thing every time though! :) 
oh, and the hummus is super delicious too. mmmmm.
author: lindsy g.

description: I go to SF for a week each year and have been going to this restaurant for about ten years.  It's the only Turkish restaurant I've ever been to, so I really can't compare the food to other places.  I am a vegetarian also, but luckily this cuisine has many options for me.  My favorite thing to order is actually a dessert, the kunufe (sp?), something like a small, warm cheese pie wrapped in crispy shreds of dough and doused in syrup then sprinkled with ground pistachios.  What a delicacy.  Another dish that stands out is a very nice carrot dish with yoghurt atop and parsley sprinkles.  It goes great with the warm bread too. Enough for a light meal.  The spinach and cheese pastries are also good. However, I'd actually give three and a half stars because of some real downers: the area is a little spooky so I only go in daylight; I once asked if they would make me a kabob and rice meal, but just with vegetables on the kabob and I was told "no" (I've yet to hear that at Middle Eastern restaurants); and despite the many reviews here mentioning the wonderful service, over some ten years nearly every waitress here has been downright chilly to me and I can't figure it out...because I'm a lone diner? (I do tip well.)...because I break some dumb rule by eating all on my plate? (not here, but a few waitresses have actually commented to me about this, as if)...a carryover of an Old World contempt of an independent woman?  Still, those carrots and kunufe keep bringing me back!
author: Virginia H.

description: Authentic food, kind wait-staff.  They helped us "learn" how to eat some of our dishes appropriately.  My new favorite spot post Amsterdam Cafe.  Super good, but not a great place to tie up Sample the dog.
author: AP R.

description: Food was OK. I've had better Kebab at Park Gyros to be honest. Service was slow. Overall, the experience was not bad, the price was ok. I'll try out other similar options before returning to A La Turca.
author: Lazeeb C.

description:
Came here for dinner with a group of 7 people on a Wednesday night, and it was not too hard to get a seat.  There was a constant flow of customers during my time there, so I'm guessing that it probably gets pretty busy on the weekend.

Anyway, I chose this restaurant for my mini college reunion of friends because I wanted something healthy, affordable, and different.  While I was able to accomplish all 3 of these things during my research, my experience here was a bit disappointing.  

The food here is really good, but the affordable price is because the portion sizes are pretty small.  I had the grilled lamb plate and it barely filled me up.  2 of my friends ordered their tea which came in a glass about twice the size of a shot glass and had no refills.  

Service-wise, they are on point, constantly filling waters and asking how you are doing.  I'm guessing the 4 stars here are because the food is good and its a mom and pop type of place, so you know its pretty authentic.  However, I think there are probably places just as good as this place, which give you better value for your money.

*EDIT
Looking at the pictures on yelp again, I can see why I chose it.  The portions look normal size.  Maybe I came on a bad night?
author: JP T.

description: As a Turk who lives in Michigan for about 3 years, this place was kind of heaven for me.
author: Kaya D.

description: We happened here quite by accident and are very glad we did. While the ambience is a little cafeteria-ish, the staff is accommodating and the food was Yum! We loved all the vegetarian options and loved the Ezme! the lentil soup was a bit thin but wonderfully flavored, loved the caraway seed. Overall, I will definitely go back when in the city next.
author: Nicolle P.

description:
Good, fresh.  We got the sampler appetizer (forget exactly), and while ingredients were fresh, it felt weird to not eat it with any bread/carb.  I like eating hummus with something :)
I think we also got the lamb beyti, which was pretty good.
I forgot what else.

And it's really not that hole-in-the-wall as everyone said.
author: Xue H.

description: Neighborhood is a little rough and from the outside this doesn't look like much. Although take a chance and you will be happy you did!  The hummus is smooth and creamy. The bread they serve with it is fluffy and so so tasty! The service is quick and friendly!
author: Mitch H.

description:
Confession: This is my first Turkish restaurant, so take my review with a grain of salt. 

I loved this place! I took a first date here - no second date -- I don't think he liked that we went to the tenderloin -- but I'm definitely planning to return to a la turca! 

Fresh food, casual atmosphere (with cheesy patterned tablecloths) and generous portions. We ordered the appetizer combo and an amazing lamb dish.
author: Sarah T.

description:
I came here with a friend for a quick dinner before watching "In the Heights". I ordered the chicken doner platter, which came with rice and salad.

The chicken had good flavor, though I felt like it was a bit on the dry side. The menu had several interesting items, so I do want to come back and try some of the other dishes. I like this place because service is really fast and the decor gives the place a nice homey feeling.

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description:
My fiance and I love Turkish/Middle Eastern/Mediterranean food and this place did not disappoint. We were there on a Thursday night and it was pretty busy. We were immediately greeted and served water. For some reason, it was a really hot night out in San Francisco. We ordered the hummus and the Lentil Soup for starters. They even had an exotic wine selection and ended up with a Turkish wine (Yakut Okuzgozu Bogaskere). The wine was perfect and it went will with everything we ordered. They brought out the bread and we could not get enough of it. They bake it right there in the store and it tasted like a cross between pita bread and french bread, which these delicious sesame seeds on top. It went perfectly with the roasted red pepper hummus, was was a pleasant surprise to us. The lentil soup was perfect and was what I expected.
We ordered the minced lamb and beef and chicken korma plates. They tasted just like a Turkish place we eat at here in Seattle. We were not disappointed. They delivered on everything. The portion sizes were huge! The appetizers are too good to pass up on, so I would recommend getting a mixed meat plate for dinner to share. 
You can always order more food :)
author: Mini P.

description: The food is great.  We went for dinner and shared an appetizer platter for two, chicken donner, and beyti keypab.  There was so much food we had enough for leftovers.   The service was so so.  The waiters took care in refilling our waters but after the food came, they were missing in action.  While eating, we noticed a lot of folks were confused as to where to pay so when we finished we made sure to wave down a waiter for refills and asked for the check.  They were pretty busy when we arrived and luckily there were two booths available.  However, when we left, they had a line out the door.  I think that goes to show a lot.
author: Blia L.

description:
Great atmosphere!  Decorations were ethnic, TV was showing a Turkish soccer match, and the employees were conversing in Turkish.  Very authentic.  I wanted to believe I was somewhere in Turkey...but, alas I was still in the heart of the 'Loin.  

I ordered the Chicken Iskendar and had no idea how to eat this.  It was essentially chicken strips and bread crumbs dressed with tomato sauce (yogurt on the side).  It was good, but a little too foreign of an idea for me.  My friend had the Chicken Kebab, and that was delish!  Super tender and flavorful.  Lunch for 2 for something around $25.  I'd definitely come back to try some other plates and appetizers once I get tired of Little Saigon.
author: Yvonne P.

description:
Oh buddy, this place was yum! 

My boyfriend was craving Doner kabobs so we found this place on Yelp and gave it a shot. 

Cute little restaurant with lots of parking in walking distance. Be sure to bring plenty of quarters for the meters ($.25/10min..ugh). We went here on a Friday afternoon and didn't have to wait for an open table (probably because it was July 3 and everyone was out of town). I can imagine the wait can be long on a regular day (it's pretty small but very quaint). 

I had the grilled chicken plate and it was AWESOME. It came with some rice, a little mixed salad, dipping sauce and of course the oh-so-delicioso grilled chicken. The chicken was cooked perfectly with just the right amount of seasoning. The first thing I thought was, "omg, i need to bring my sister here". She's a super foodie and would LOVE this place. 
My BF had the doner platter and was happy with it until he tried my chicken...then he was upset that he didn't get the chicken. 
We also ordered a plate of hummus which was good, but not anything to rave about. The warm homemade bread that comes with your meal is really good.....mmmmmm warm bread fresh from the oven (really, i saw the dude take it out of the oven before she brought it to our table). 

I'll be back for more.
author: Mel P.

description:
+2 for the food and +1 for service. Delish and not too expensive. It's really clear that they put a lot of effort into making yummy yummy food!

The boyfriend and I visited here when we were craving Turkish food but didn't have a ton of time or money to drop. We split something tasty and chicken-y, and I'm definitely up for going there again!
author: N M.

description: I've traveled to Turkey a couple of times and I love this place! The cuisine is authentic and the wait staff is very nice! This is my go-to place when I am craving lamb chops. It's served with salad and rice and is reasonably priced. This place is located in the Tenderloin, and it's not high on atmosphere. Worth a try it if you like Turkish food -  great value, good service, good food.
author: Cathy P.

description: I think I need to try this place again. Their pita bread was amazing. Warm and fresh but the meal I got (chicken beyti) seemed like it had been frozen and then just  put in the microwave. I should have just gotten a gyro.
author: Kelly B.

description: The food was excellent and served pretty quickly. Service was slow however. Water and the bill were both difficult to wave down. Still, good food is worth small inconveniences, don't you agree?
author: Eric F.

description:
For the past three years, this place has been declining in service and quality substantially. 
In the beginning, the food was great, the portions were big, the service was generous. 
Over time, the waitresses have gotten grumpy and the portions in particular, have gotten damn near pathetic. Three years ago, when we would order the shepard's salad for take out, the container would be almost full to the brim. Now, we're lucky if we get 1/2 a container full. Same goes for the lentil soup. 
The Combo Donner was dry and tasteless on more than one occasion. 
BOO! Such a disappointment...some of the food is actually pretty good, and it will be hard to say no, but I have no choice but to no longer support them and their shabby service and food.
author: smokey r.

description: Friendly staff, generous portions, tasty food.
author: Julie J.

description:
Wow, had lunch delivered from here just yesterday and today went for dinner. You might wonder "how is Turkish food different?"...it's all in the spices.

Three of us had wonderful dishes including veggie platter appetizer, the "meat plate", and a couple of the bread dishes.  The ONLY downside was we think the mushrooms in one dish tasted like canned...

Otherwise, this place is a diamond in the rough. I have lived here 20 years and driven by this place 100's of times...

GO!
author: Mark M.

description:
My husband and I came here around 3p.m today. Someone suggested this place and it looked good and was close to where we were, so I choose this place.
