Since it is Memorial Day Weekend, I figured Fisherman's Wharf and the more touristy areas would be packed. I was right, it was. This place wasn't in a touristy area and parking on the street was free which was great.

This is a small and casual place. I think you just sit where you want as no waitress came up to us. There was only one waitress there but she was fast and efficient. We ordered the hummus and spinach and cheese pie for the appetizer. The hummus was good. I could tell it was fresh. The pie was strange. It's basically a Mexican tortilla filled with cheese and spinach. The cheese tasted a little off like it wasn't that fresh.

The complimentary bread was really good. It was hot and fresh. As for the main entrees, I ordered the  Combo Doner which is #66 on the menu. It comes with chicken, beef, and lamb doner with salad and rice. My husband got a falafel sandwich. My order was just the right size, not too big, not too small. Unlike most places, I didn't get a ton of rice and got a generous serving of salad drenched with olive oil. The meat was good but I noticed I didn't get any chicken, only red meat. 

I didn't care about that though as I was hungry and liked what I got anyways. My husband had no complaints. His falafel wrap was huge. There is a parking structure right next to this place if none on the street is available. For those of you watching your budget, this is a good place to go as S.F can be pricey at most places, even casual ones. Here are the prices for what we got:

Hummus: $4.75

Spinach and Cheese Pide: $7.50

Combo Doner: $9.75

Falafel: $6.75

Soda: $1.50

Not bad. And since we've been affected by the recession like most people, this was a good place to go. If we had more money to spend on food and not have to worry about paying the mortgage on our house and other bills, we would go to more expensive places. 

Today my husband surprised me by asking me if I'd like to go on a cruise to Hawaii in the fall or winter. I think this might be my Christmas gift this year-:) I sure hope so. That would be great. Of course, a European trip would be better, but we had to put off our annual trip to Europe for now because of the recession.  The business that he owns has slowed down since the recession got worse. Hawaii is great though. I've been there before and loved it! It is as beautiful as it is on TV and books. I hope I didn't make anyone too jealous, lol.
author: Butterfly A.

description: This place actually serves authentic Turkish food and it's halal (suitable for Muslim consumption)! I've found it pretty hard to find authenticity in most Turkish restaurants since some say they are Turkish, but end up being generic mediterranean. I ordered the Iskendar Kebab (doner kebab prepared from thinly cut grilled lamb or beef basted with tomato sauce over pieces of pide bread and generously slathered with melted butter and yogurt). You can only get this at Turkish restaurants! It was delicious, as was the chicken and mushroom pide. My friend ordered the Combo platter which was just as good. The Ezme could have been better though as I felt it was a little watered down. Would definately go back. Cute restaurant, nice ambience, attentive and prompt service. Go earlier in the day though as there can be gangs hanging around the area after dark.
author: Sabina H.

description:
I love this place.  I just had dinner here after a LONG DAY dancing in the hot sun at Carnaval in the Mission.  I show up tonight, sore, dehydrated and slightly hung-over from partying with my samba troupe.

The service is very gracious and attentive.  In fact, they provide even better service than I receive at some high-end restaurants.  

We started with the baba ghanouj -- the roasted eggplant cold appetizer.  It was light fluffy lemony and a subtle smokiness and hint of tahini.  It was a pleasure to eat it with their fresh-from-the-oven bread.

I had the Grilled Kofke Plate (only $10.25 with rice and salad) and it was divine!  Lots of seasoning, juicy inside with a nice crust on the outside.  Last time I got the Doner Combo (chicken, beef and lamb) which was also amazing.  I got four Kofke patties --- which is more meat than you'd expect to get for only ten bucks.  Mmm. . . so delicious.

If you are looking for a low-budget restaurant but with high budget food and service, I highly recommend this place.  Next time I want to get the Manti (turkish dumplings with garlic yoghurt, spices and butter).

Dinner for two, plus one yummy pilsner -- $35 bucks plus tip.  Awesome deal!
author: Freida N.

description:
I would give it a 3.75. Would have given 4 but I guess i was looking for some some more flavor than what i got. But overall, this place is complete value for your money. I ordered Chicken - pineapple that came in a bread that was so fresh. Chicken were soft and well done. In the end we had the dessert Baklava- do try that. its chopped walnuts between two crispy layers with walnut sauce oozing with every drop. Best thing about that Baklava was that the sauce was not too sweet. Just perfect way to end our dinner.
My husband took Canona Samosi (or sth like that). Though he ordered sth else and the order got mixed up, he liked his dish. And the waitress was sweet enough to confess the mistake. He also had a lamb starter and he just loved it! 
We will go there for sure - for it's worth your money and serves fresh food. 
Ambience - mediocre.
Waiters - very friendly.
author: debopriya b.

description:
New job means new lunch spots for me and my loyal girlfriends.

My girlfriend Jax and I vowed to continue to have our girl-bonding lunches even after I moved to my new job in the Civic Center. And we've been pretty good. This is our second lunch in 4 months. Not bad at all considering we are very busy career-girls.

I chose A La Turca because I've been here before with a someone who lived in Turkey for years. He even ordered in Turkish and connected with the staff at A La Turca. We sampled cold and hot appetizers, pides (pies) and platters. He guaranteed that the food was good and authentic.

Venue:  A little hole in the wall in the TL. Nice dining spot for pre-theatre dinner before catching a show at the Opera House or Symphony.  

Parking:  Garage is conveniently located next to A La Turca.

Ambiance/Decor: Casual and relaxed. Long seats and tables were covered with rich tapestries. Minimal Turkish decorations. Very clean and neat.

Girls' Bathroom: Very clean and spacious with a stained glass window.

Social Scene: Sparse Mediterranean crowd at 11:45 am.

Service: Very friendly but slow despite the lack of diners.

Food:  My gf and I were only able to sample two dishes this time:
1. GF:  #61 Falafel Platter (served with hummus, tahini sauce and salad)
2. Me:  #53 Iskender Platter (Vertically roasted and sliced ground lamb and beef in special tomato sauce over bread served with butter and yogurt)
3. I washed down my spicy dish with a strong glass of Turkish Tea which came with 2 sugar cubes (although it tasted like Lipton to me.)

My platter was delicious!  I broke my "no-meat diet" but it was worth it. The meat was tender. The sauce was full of flavors. Some of the bread cubes were crunchy and haven't completely soaked up the sauce but it was still very good.  I bet it was better with yogurt but being I was Lacto  I regrettably skipped it.

Recommend:  
1. A La Turca is a notch above your regular Mediterranean restaurants because there are much more to choose from.  There are 8 Cold Appetizers, 6 Hot Appetizers,  8 Sandwiches,  Soups and Salads, 20 Savory Pies From the Grill or the Oven, 16 Platters,  Desserts and even Kids' Meals.

2. The dishes at A La Turca are fun to share with friends.   Their dishes are definitely not boring.  Bring a sense of adventure along with your appetite!  Yummy!

Jax and I both enjoyed our lunch and made more vows to have more girl-bonding lunches within our hour or so weekday lunchbreaks. 

Tab:  $23.00 with tax not including tip.

NOTE TO SELF:  Jax paid this time. I have to remember to pay for our next girl-bonding lunch.
author: Leah E.

description: I love this place.  The Iskender is delicious.  The service is amazing.  They have a great private room upstairs that I had my birthday party at once.  The staff is just so accommodating and nice!  Just like most Turkish people generally!  Never a wait and always fast service.  LOVE IT!
author: Liz A.

description: You may think this is a hole-in-the-wall place but thats where they serve the best food, right? This place takes me back to my vacation in Turkey. The flavors are really delicious. I had the combo dinner which consisted of various doners which was very tasty. Someone else at the table had the chicken beyti, but I'm impressed with beyti in general so I wont hold it against this place. Try the baklavat and the turkish coffee too.
author: Kenson K.

description: Typical moderate Turkish restaurant. I been in much better places. Prices are very reasonable but the foods are moderate.
author: Alper K.

description:
I gave my old roommate a super hard time when she suggested we go to this place.  Tenderloin?  Really?  So, I sighed and went.  So glad I did! This is probably one of my favorite places in the city.  Yes its in a "special" part of town. But the food and the people in there definitely make up for it.

Order the mixed appetizer with all of the different sauces.  And definitely get the bread basket.  I could go there and just eat the bread.  

I always leave feeling extremely uncomfortable and full.  but thats my fault not theirs. :(
author: jessica b.

description: Based on reviews, we made a special trip.  The basket of warm, soft bread and the combo platter of cold appetizers comprising eggplant salad, dill yogurt, hummus, dolmas, white bean salad and roasted red pepper salad were ok, but not as flavorful as expected.  The tomato and cheese gozleme was nothing special, basically like a quesadilla.  The special was turkish ravioli, which was like tortellini in a large pool of rich sour cream and butter.  Service was ok...  Overall, everything was just ok.  Sadly, won't be back.
author: Esther R.

description: Have not written a review on Yelp in a while, but wanted to take this occasion to chime in on this awesome tasty Turkish dive in the Loin. Nothing memorable on decor, but yummy, yummy, yummy on the food front, which is what matters most. Enjoy!
author: Marc S.

description:
I discovered tonight that I really like Turkish food.
Had the chicken donor platter and was wowed.  Tender bird with a mysteriously but beautifully dressed salad and rice pilaf that was nothing like I was afraid it was going to be.
Four of us had dinner, apps, drinks, turkish coffees and dessert for about $90!  
The service was friendly and efficient.
I liked the Turkish music playing in the dining room and even the Turkish TV station on the big TV over the front door.  Nothing says family restaurant like a big TV!
I know that a fifth star is in a la turca's future.  I will be back.
author: Miss F.

description: Reliably delicious Turkish food in not-the-best neighborhood.  I have been to SF more than 50 times in the past 12 years, and i almost always fit in a casual dinner here.  Reminds me of the little diner-type places in Istanbul.   The burek and grilled meat plaster are not to be missed.
author: J s.

description:
Like a bratty ex-girlfriend with an oral fixation, even restaurants deserve a second chance.  

Two big strikes on this place - never going back and here's why....

First experience:  Placed an order for pick up, walked over to the place, confirmed order with girl at counter, got home and it was totally the wrong order.  When I walked back to get MY order I had to wait 20 minutes for them to remake it.  No apology, nothing.  The food was OK, but nowhere NEAR worth the trouble or the wait.  

Second experience:   Walked in after work, placed order, waited at booth reading magazine.  After 20 minutes I notice people that walked in after me already eating, and I was still waiting for my sandwich.  I walk up to the woman at the counter to check on my food and she admits (embarrassingly) that she forgot to put the order in.  Another 15 minutes goes by and I finally get my food..... I get home and its the worst piece of crap sandwich I've ever had, and they forgot to include the side of babaganoush that I paid for.  Yeah, its my fault for not triple-checking my order and giving them the benefit of the doubt, but COME ON.  

Final Analysis:  This place sucks.  I wouldn't eat in because its a dump and I wouldn't order for pickup because chances are they'll mess up your order.  The food is decent, I can't complain, but its not worth all the trouble.
author: Ted T.

description:
First the positives
- place is clean and has a parking garage next door - matters to me and the friend that I went with because we were accompanied by a very pregnant lady and three kids under 4
- staff is polite
- food presentation was somewhat nice for a hole in the wall place
- a turkish soda that we had was really nice
Now the negatives
- the girl who served us was quite, what they call "ditsy". Took the drinks order and then stood there chatting with her colleague. Had to wave to her to remind her to do her job. Never came by to check on us after food was served
- most important part - the food - was just average. Tasted a little bland (and I know that good mediterranean food is always flavorful). 
- the turkish beer sucks. Likely bud light in a turkish bottle
Overall, a very average place - nothing to write home about, but not too horrible either
author: Anurag B.

description:
Never again.

I ordered the beef/lamb doner, served over rice with a salad on the side.  While the rice was aromatic and tasty, the meat was dry and unimaginative.  The salad, pedestrian.  The most interesting part of my dining experience is probably the bout of food-poisoning that rendered me doubled-over and clutching my tummy in pain the rest of the night.

The only good thing to come out of the experience:  I spent the evening drowning my sorrows in liquor and discovered (HEADS UP ADVENTUROUS YELPERS!) that drinking alcohol before, during, or after a meal may alleviate the effects of food poisoning.  You live, you learn!
author: Teresa K.

description: I may have scarfed down my doner dish too fast to enjoy it, but it's flavor was simple at best. Would have preferred some flatbread or pita instead of their thicker bread slices for the hummus and baba ghanoush.
author: Palak K.

description: Tasty lentil soup, kebabs plates are awesome. Great quality for the $$ Highly recommended
author: Marcelo B.

description: Food was very oily and salty, service was ok, all was overall okay.  Their bread was the best. The location is horrible very depressing.
author: Seda M.

description:
Besides eating at Troya (Inner Richmond), this is the first time I've ever had Turkish food.  Had no idea this restaurant existed until our Turkish friend introduced us to this place.  I didn't even try to order, I left the food decisions up to him.  

The food was good!  I normally don't like to eat lamb, but the lamb here was very tender and had a slight hint of gamey taste.  Normally, I just can't handle super gamey meat.  

Iskender Kebab(Alexander) - combination of beef and lamb shaved off a gyro.  It went great with the tomato sauce and yogurt. 

Lahmacun - like a Turkish thin sliced pizza.  It's good, but needed a kick

Kunefe - awesome dessert.  It's like a crispy super thin spaghetti wrapped around a sweet cheese.  It's very sweet so only order it if you can handle the sweetness.

Turkish tea - kind of tastes like Lipton tea, which I'm not a real fan of. 

It's right in the Tenderloin and there's ample parking right around 6pm.    If you're looking for Turkish food, this place is as authentic as it gets.
author: Annie S.

description:
Food was ok not great. Service was fast but cold. The Deli style ordering confused me and I ended up getting food to go when I actually wanted to eat in. That may be why the staff was cold to me. Hint - Wait to be seated for dining in, use the line for take out. 
 It's family owned but just don't have that feel. 
If I was in the Neighborhood I'd give it a second shot but would not go out of my way to eat here again.
author: Kev S.

description:
This is the real deal.

I love Turkish food, and A La Turca is the only place in San Francisco that satisfies my craving for Adana Kebab, Doner Kebab, or Turkish coffee.

The flavors are right on, and the portions are generous.

Our waitress, Ezgi, was friendly and polite and actually recommended a dish I had never tried before that was beyond delicious.

I was on a date when I went here, and the girl wanted to try some Turkish beer.  We ordered two Pilsners from Turkiye and they were so good, we had another beer after dinner.

I will definitely go back to A La Turca!

Give it a try.  You'll be pleasantly surprised! :)
author: Justin C.

description: My most recent visit to A La Turca was the first time I've been back in years.  I remember the food being a little better back in the day but I don't know if that can be attributed to having developed a more discriminating palate for Mediterranean food over the years.  The falafel and kebab platters are pretty good but I did not like the hummus at all and the tahini sauce was watery and bland.  The best tasting thing I've ordered from here is the babaganoush (which is really good) and I feel like it's the only thing I could really recommend.  The other saving grace for this place that will likely have me coming back every so often is its relatively good value for the sizable wraps.
author: Erich D.

description:
O MY GOD... Can somebody PLEASE orgasm in my mouth, O wait A La Turca already did!!! 

Well to be honest the only thing I have eaten here was their Falafel and or Lamb sandwich on pita bread. ugh, But there pita bread is incredible and to die for. They make it from scratch and it is so fluffy and fresh. 

They also have the most moist, flavorful falafel that my lounge has ever had. 

Please get a sandwich and you MUST ask for the Pita instead of the livash bread. Okay ? GO!

wait before you actually go, you need to know a few details. The neighborhood is cracked out but it is worth the risk! The resturant is not fancy but very Turkish decorated and the staff is great! 

Okay, Now GO!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Totally used to like this place.  I went here tonight and had the worst runs ;)
The salad looked like they used old tomatoes and the olives were out of a can.  Very strange for a Turkish place.  The main dish of chicken was a little better but after I ate I felt like poo.  Not going back here.
author: Mitch A.

description:
How to tell if you're an oinker:

1)  Do you look at the menu and decide everything looks good, so you order everything that has 'sampler' or 'combination' in it's name?

2)  Does the waitress bring over a separate table for you just to hold your entrees?  That's right.  EntreeS.  With an 'S.'

3)  Do you clean your plate(s) of every delicious morsel like your mother taught you?

4)  Does your dining companion tell you, "I love that you love to eat!"  When he really means, "Damn girl, you can pack it in!"

5)  Do you then top off your delicious meal with 2 scoops of Bi Rite ice cream (not available at A La Turca but just a short drive away)?

Check, check, check, check, and...check.

Thank god I bought those magic ass pants at Lululemon.
author: Cindy W.

description: I've never had a better falafel than at A La Turca. Their rice pudding is phenomenal too. The prices are incredibly affordable since the location is somewhat sketchy (in the Tenderloin). It's not too far from the Federal Building though, so if you work around there, this place should be a lunchtime staple. Great service, great food, and great prices. Cannot be beaten.
author: Aseem P.

description: Very high quality food for the price.  The weird music videos with the news counter at the bottom are an atmosphere plus.  I will definitely be returning soon.
author: Vanessa S.

description: My husband and I wanted to grab something to eat before we went to a concert and we decided to try La Turca. The outside of the restaurant isn't much to look at, but the inside is nice. Most importantly the food is terrific and healthier than many of the places around the area. It's next door to a parking garage which was convenient and close to American Music Hall and the Regency Center. It's a good place have dinner before a concert and I shall return.
author: Sheila T.

description: It was interesting to try Turkish hummus (pinkish from paprika, perhaps?) with their delicious, warm bread. But my entrée was nothing more than a quesadilla, gussied up with a Turkish name. And we caught their pastry chef on a bad day, since he burned the dessert (which I could have sworn was Shredded Wheat, but was really phyllo), and skimped on the honey.
author: Brian W.

description:
I love their Lamb Beef Doner.  It's normally $7.50, but they have a daily sandwich specials bringing the price of the sandwich to $5, which is a great deal.

For dinner, their Combo Platter appetizer is a great choice if you've got a few people looking to get a little bit of everything.  Their Hummus is particularly good.

I had the Kavurmali & Cheese which is a nicely baked lamb dish with onions and red peppers.  So much flavor in the lamb and it just all goes together nicely.
author: Jason K.

description:
-1 star for being constantly understaffed! I've been four times and every time there weren't enough waitresses on the floor. This means waiting a long time for refills or to order. However, the waitresses are usually sweet and apologetic -- that softens the blow for me.

However, thankfully, the food makes up for this.

The cacik (like greek taziki) is really good, as is the bread. Mmm, it always tastes fresh baked, crunchy on the outside and substantially fluffy on the inside.

I usually order some kind of doner platter with beef and feta. Always tastes great to me.

Be careful where you set down their take-out containers, though! They are porous cardboard, as I learned the hard way when I set one down on my couch =/

Go to A La Turca. The prices are great for the large portions, I would go there for the cacik and bread alone.
author: Chenoa D.

description:
A friend took me here for dinner....Was a little leary about dining in the Tenderloin, however, it was an exceptional experience.  

I had never really tried Turkish cuisine in the past and I do love Middle Eastern food.  Every single dish we had was sensational.

Their special bread was absolutely delicious, the baba ganouj that I started with was one of the best I have had and the trio of meats I had for an entree were flavorful and perfectly done.

The dessert we had was very unique and delicious as well.

Our servers were excelllent...friendly and outgoing.

Can't wait to return and try more.
author: Eli B.

description:
I am so grateful to the fates for making us order the sucuk and cheese pide when Boyfriend and I ate here the other day.  If not for the specific alignment of the planets, the presence of our friend, and some butterfly flapping its wings in Africa, we would probably never have tried it and I'd still be walking around like an idiot, not knowing what I was missing.

As if the pide weren't enough, their hummus is my favorite anywhere.  It has a slightly egg-y taste, as if it contained yolks or something.  I have no idea whether or not it does, it just tastes a little like it.  I also love the kofte and the lamb and beef shish kebap.  The doner isn't my favorite, but it's okay.  

The only thing I don't like is the service or lack of it.  The women who work here are always super slow and inattentive and won't make eye contact with me.  What is up with that?  I'd get my food to-go, but I think it's better when you dine-in, and the pide won't travel well.  If they ever look me in the face or refill my ice tea the first time I ask, I'll bump Alaturca up to the five stars the food deserves.
author: Lauren C.

description: foods good but service is lacking. You know that economy is bad and all but our check was $31.78 for a meal for two and I placed $40 in the little black check book and they took it and never offered me my change. I am not sure for what reason they though I would leave $8.22 as tip.
author: Jasmine L.

description:
A la Turca is definitely one of my favorites in the realm of affordable eateries. Turkish delights abound - lip smackingly great hummus, crispy fresh (and huge) salads, soul-hugging lentil soup, savory lamb dishes, perfect dolmas, wonderful pides and so much more PLUS their addictive house made sesame bread to sop it all up with. Service is always friendly, dishing it out with a smile in the slightly odd, yet endearing atmosphere. 

Mmmmmmmm! Save room for authentic Turkish coffee and flaky baklava to further round out your happy belly. You will leave stuffed like a sweet little dolma, lighter in mood, but barely so in the wallet.
author: wendella a.

description:
People are social animals.  Obviously we interact to communicate important things where to find food and to warn one another of danger.

People are also emotional creatures.  We also communicate with one another to amplify our emotional states.

So when a group of people get together and feverishly talk about falafels, where to get really great falafels, and how awesome the falafels will be once they obtain them... well then... the bar is set pretty damn high now, isn't it.

So what happens when that group of people goes to a place rumored (on good authority) to have the best falafels in the city and they can't delivery on the goods?  Trouble.

Honestly, just about everything we tried here was pretty underwhelming with the exception of the following items: Bread, hummus, and coffee.

Perhaps they were having an off day.  I could give them that.  Maybe I'll go back the next time I'm cruising around the tenderloin with a hankering for some Turkish food.

(p.s. They have space in the balcony for parties and offer entertainment options like belly dancers.  That's worth investigation.)
author: Christopher K.

description:
A La Average. 

I do have to add that they are accommodating to a larger group, and made sure that my rambunctious companions and I were taken care of when, likely, we should have been asked to quiet down or leave.
author: Drue C.

description:
This may have been the first time I've been to a Turkish restaurant and it wasn't entirely what I was expecting. The waitress recommended the Beyti kebap which is a lamb lavash wrap sliced into pieces and covered with cheese and sauce. My friend ordered it but because of a weird coincidence I had a lavash wrap for lunch so chose the donor platter thinking it might be like a gyro.  

When I think of Turkey I think of the Middle East, I always forget its close proximity to Europe. What I perceived as an Italian influence on the menu surprised me at first but really makes a lot of sense. The Beyti kebap is pretty interesting, my friend let me try it, and it's covered with tomato sauce and mozzarella cheese. My Donor was ok but kind of bland.

I did like the atmosphere and the friendly service, I'll probably give this place another shot.
author: Manny F.

description: Came here once: had a good meal. Came here again and brought a friend: again, good, but I don't think my friend was super impressed. Solid food, and it's not like you can get Turkish fare just anywhere in the city. Worth a visit if you're nearby, but nothing to go particularly out of your way for.
author: Greg P.

description: So i was very hungry and i just walked out of a bar. My friend didnt want to eat so i couldnt enjoy a full meal but the sandwich i ate was quick and very good. Next time i go I'll have a serious dinner. All in all its a very welcoming spot and helpful. TRY IT OUT!
author: Erick I.

description:
A young Turkish guy sitting outside A La Turca told me it served up the best Turkish food in San Francisco. And he said he could make that call because...

1. He's Turkish

2. He's tried every Turkish restaurant in San Francisco

'kay. Fair enough. That's pretty irrefutable. 

However, I'M not Turkish, and I haven't tried every Turkish restaurant in San Francisco, so I'm not going to be swayed to give it five stars just because of dude's glowing praise. 

But Holy Mary Mother of Falafel, I AM going to give it four stars for the best damn falafel I've had in America. 

I didn't even eat the falafel IN the restaurant -- I got it for take-out and ate it in the Ha-Ra, next door. I have no idea what their service is like. But if the service -- and anything else on the menu -- is HALF as fabulous as that falafel, this place should get SIX stars.

This is a 100% Turkish falafel. It's on Turkish bread, with the Turkish sauce, and the cabbage... Oh my God, it's like the doener kebabs you get from the Turkish stands in Eastern Europe... Only with falafel patties instead of lamb. 

I'm having carnivorous flashbacks...

I actually texted my college ex to tell him I found Turkish doeners/ falafels in America. 

Thinking about meat, and my ex -- fondly.

That's one powerful falafel.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I'll give 'em props for giving SF a Turkish enclave because as far as I know it's the only one they've got.

The food is hit or miss in my opinion and I hope the Turkish community will not shun me henceforth.  I hope the EU lets you in because you have awesome hookahs, and I fantasize about growing a curly moustache and being a spy in Istanbul.  

The menu is like looking at a gas chromatograph: you know the composition of the dish, but not the shape it's in, so one time I got something that looked like a pizza, the next time it looked like a salad with a side of sausage and big ol hunk of bread.  They both bear three-word descriptions that say chicken and bread.  I liked the pizza one better.

I know I'm supposed to ask questions like a normal person but this is the internet age and it's much easier to just judge their menu like the Westernized bigot I am and then complain about its inadequacy.

Plus the girls who work there are cute and they make me shy.  It's hard enough to point to the menu item and stutter.
author: Cassio P.

description:
The falafel is evidently disappointing; We'd heard wonderful things about the falafel sandwich and while there may be something else about the sandwiches (The bread is really good) my co-diners report that the falafel itself lacks texture. One of them was pretty broken up about it; it was kind of hard to watch.

But screw the falafel. The doner is good and the chicken "doner" is really good, all tender and flavorful. If you stand outside for a minute before dining and just stare at the doner sitting on the vertical spit with slices cut out of the side and a tomato on top so it looks like a giant meat ice cream cone it will taste even better.

Check out the hummus and baba ghanouj too, with the aforementioned bread. 

Nothing wrong with the service, the place is bright and clean, and it's right next door to the Ha-Ra Club if you get tired of bright and clean.
author: matthew r.

description:
We had dinner here before heading over to the theater.  I hadn't ever had Turkish before so I wasn't sure what to expect; it turned out to be pretty similar to most other Middle Eastern foods I've had.  I had what was basically a Turkish quesadilla (from the "From The Griddle" section of the menu), filled with Spinach and feta cheese.  Yummy!  Several others also had something of the quesadilla persuasion with lamb or chicken.  Other delicious things I got to try included lamb kabob, lentil soup, and the baba ganouj (which I'm not usually crazy about; this was pretty good, though).

Bonus - it's fairly cheap (Turkish quesadillas range from $7 - $10ish; larger, more substantial entrees range from $12 - 20), and given that it was 7 pm on a Friday night, I was pleasantly surprised that we didn't have to wait (though it did look like they were starting to fill up).
author: Angela B.

description:
As someone from Turkey, I was stoked to find out about this place. However, aside from the kunefe, nothing else tastes like it is supposed to. It's pretty bland. This still remains as the only place I left without finishing what I ordered. Do not recommend at all. If you're looking for Turkish food, I'd recommend Hayes&Kebab by Hayes Valley and/or  Turkish Kitchen in Berkeley. 

On the plus side, the waiters and the atmosphere are really nice, but the same goes for the other places I mentioned. I'd only recommend this place if you're looking for good Kunefe and nothing else.
author: Su P.

description: I really liked A La Turca because it's inexpensive good food. I got the kofte kebab plate. It came with four patties of meat that nearly equated to two small burgers. The patties were almost too flavorful if that's possible. I didn't care for the raw onions in the salad, but the bread they give you is better than I thought it'd be. considering the price and location, I think A La Turca is great.
author: Regina C.

description: Flummoxed by the good reviews.  Baffled.  Grilled chicken tasted like a frozen, processed mess.  As a hummus lover who normally eats it by the spoonful, I didn't like theirs and left most of it untouched.  PN was not thrilled with his selection either.
author: Eric C.

description:
Excellent Adana and Shish Kebab. The lamb and beef Doner sandwiches are also very scrumptious!

I usually order to go, 'cos eating in, I've had the one of the otherwise charming ladies that run the place come over and unobservantly clean the table right next to me with some kind of ammonia flavoured aerosol cleaner, spraying it liberally all around.  That heady mixture of lamb, tahini and ammonia in my face wasn't too appetizing.  D'oh!?! 

4 Stars for yummy take out!!
author: I. O.

description: Great flavor. I ordered the Doner Combo and was most pleased. The Beyti Kabob came also highly recommended and my friend enjoyed that too.
author: Brandon L.

description:
LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT. Understated exterior and interior with big tables for large groups, or maybe they pushed the tables together before I got there. Considering they didn't know we were coming, it seems like a awesome place to for for an inexpensive but delicious meal for a group of 8-12 people.

Hummus, great, Check
Bread, delicious, Check
Unique appetizer, Lachmun I think? ie Turkish Pizza, Check

#54 Some sort of Chicken and Bread mixture with tomato sauce blended in and delicious yogurt. I'm usually not a fan of yogurt but bthis stuff was soooo good and mixed well with the meal.

I heard huge compliments for the Turkish wine, and the Turkish beer was a light lager but met my expectations.

I heard the dessert was good but I was stuffed. Everyone loved this place. So many great things on the menu.
author: Mike T.

description:
We only had 20 minutes to eat before a meeting so we stopped quickly at this place just the time to share a plate.

The staff was super nice and gave us some good recommandation on the fastest meals to prepare. We had a doner platter (around $10) which was exactly what we needed. Very good bread! Meat and salad were average but ok for the price.

I've never been in Turkey but I guess it might feel like this place a little bit.

Took us less than 20 minutes to travel. Cool!
author: Mathilde B.

description: Asked the owner if the beef doner was handmade and he responded yes and I wanted to make its not one of those store brought gross fatty doner rolls most places have and he said 'hurry up I'm running the store alone and don't have time to answer.' The doner kabob IS in fact store bought, not handmade and you can taste the fat against your tongue...and nice costumer service...not!
author: Masoud T.

description:
My sister and I live around the corner from A La Turca.  So needless to say we probably eat here more than we should.  OH how we do enjoy our lazy moments!

The atmosphere is warm and welcoming.  Turkish television channel is always on and or Turkish music playing.  It's not a large place and they are never extremely busy.  (Which means no wait!) 

The staff has improved immensely.  They aren't going to win awards on friendliness but they're getting better.  

The Kofte plate is probably one of the tastiest meat dishes I've ever had.  The portions are quite large and easily sharable in groups.  The Turkish coffee is a nice way to end the meal.  Prices used to range from $7-$10 but have recently changed to around $8-$12.

 A La Turca is worth coming to the loin for.  ^_^)b
author: Mary R.

description:
Solid good food.  Is it honest Turkish food.  Eh, not really.  IS it resonably priced for what you get. I'd say so.  Just had the spacial today. "Turkish Ravioli".  Delicious, if you like a light creamy, tarty sauce instead of red sauce. 

Now to find a blue collar GREEK place that isn't a joke in this city.

Servvice = decent
Food = solid (not orgasmical, not regretttable- atleast not yet)
Meat = average at best
Price = matches size, while I would agree with others does not exactlymatch the flavor.

The place on Clement  has better ambiance and service. But smaller portions and higher prices.
author: Spanky M.

description: This place has gotten significantly better in the last year or so! Their kebabs plates are excellent and their deserts are great too!
author: Jack L.

description:
I love the mixed meat grill platter.... I highly recommend it....
this place faltered a bit a few years ago but it has come on strong again
in all it's glory.....great food!...and great bread they make themselves
author: david f.

description:
I almost don't want anyone to know about this place, but I feel I need to spread the word. It's SO cheap and SO good!!!! 

Be sure to check it out, just don't mind the crazy tranny hookers hanging out on the corner... :0
author: Kandace K.

description:
Pretty OK Turkish food but amazing freshly baked, hot Turkish bread called pide. Pide is basically a Turkish version of pita bread without a pocket covered in black sesame seeds. A La Turca has very affordable prices. I always order the hummus and the cheese and tomato pides (sort of Turkish sandwich). The Aryan (yogurt drink) is not bad either. They have a $8.75 lunch special with soup and desert. Sort of kitschy decor. It is a short walk from Edinburgh Castle. Since SF lacks in good Persian food, I typically settle for good Turkish here.

When I was a little girl, my Persian father would always say that you can tell if it is a good bakery by how many of the black sesame seeds were on the top of the barbary bread (the Afghan version of pide). Well at A La Turca they use a lot of seeds!
author: Shannon Z.

description: Delicious, authentic, feels like Istanbul back street restaurant.
author: David B.

description: Well-executed family food. Donner in general can be dry and tasteless; theirs was not. Enjoyed the pides. Rice pudding and baklava were hits, too.
author: Brian C.

description:
It may not be the best location in town or the hottest looking interior. But the food is the best Turkish food you can get. The prices are reasonable too. 

Try their lentil soup on a cold day - which we have quite a few of in SF. 
Don't forget to leave room for Kunefe (an exquisite dessert with cheese and shredded fillo dough) to finish your meal. It is a heavy dessert so plan to share :)
author: Oz O.

description: I came here with my Persian father who has high expectations when it comes to anything that's semi related to the Middle East, Mediterranean, or Arabic. We came in here which I initially thought was a bad idea being it was our first time. I was almost sure that it would not meet up to my Dad's standards. Low and behold, he loved it. It's a small and casual place, service was good and not overbearing. We ordered the Lamb Chops Platter, Combo Grill Meat Platter and Spinach & Cheese Gozleme. They have a wide variety of platters and appetizers. YUM!
author: Natasha S.

description:
I think the food here would have tasted divine to me even if I hadn't just had 4 scotches next door at Whiskey Thieves.  My lamb shish-kebab was prepared absolutely perfectly -- seared on the outside, juicy and tender on the inside.  The vegetables and rice that came along with it was also quite good.  My two companions (Josh W and Patrick W, no relation) also loved their lamb dishes.  

A La Turca will definitely become a regular stop on the Tenderknob bar crawl.
author: Eugene F.

description:
Delicious, affordable, authentic. This is a great place for a date night, or for a big group. I've probably eaten here 10 times in groups ranging from 2 - 10 people, with consistently delicious dinners across the board. 

Pretty much everything we've ordered at A La Turca has been great, but our favorites are always the sigara boregi, lamb beyti, and kunefe dessert (really, to die for -- desserts are a must here). 

My love for A La Turca was reinforced last year when I brought a Turkish friend, who said the food was really authentic and made her feel at home.
author: Tess W.

description: A friend and I were here last night.  I live around the block from A La Turca and can't believe that it's taken me this long to eat here.  The food and service here is fantastic!  Wonderfully flavorful food and lots of it!  I had the #60 meat combo and savored every bite it was so good, even the rice is delicious.  I'll be going here a lot now that I know how good it is!
author: Mark T.

description:
It isn't going to win any awards for the ambiance and our waitress didn't exactly speak fluent english, but the food was good and plentiful. Comfort food that is filling and good.

I don't live close enough to make it one of my regular spots, but if I lived closer I would put A La Turca in my semi-regular rotation.
author: keith h.

description: I'll give this restaurant four stars because it serves up excellent Turkish food at very reasonable prices and does it consistently every time I go there.  Try the Turkish wines - they are great and not pricey.  My favorite dish is the grilled lamb chops - cooked just right.  The bread is wonderful, the appetizers super. The food is flavorful with healthy fresh ingredients.  It's in a funky  but interesting neighborhood and is very popular on the weekend.  I'd go on a weekday night and we try to go every time we are downtown.  Room for parties, but good for couples as well.
author: Tessie S.

description: I crave the #39 Chicken and Pineapple more often than I'd like to admit. Try it. you'll love it too.
author: Christi C.

description:
Iyi aksamlar my friends, this is as close to an authentic Turkish restaurant as it gets. From their delicious pide bread, tasty kebap and Efes Pilsner beer, all is well. They even show Turkish TV.

Of course, this is San Francisco, so a doner which would be $3-5 in Turkey - or Germany, heh - is as much a dream as a hot aegian summer day in the Bay Area.
author: Roland A.

description: Nothing else to say other than this is my FAVORITE mediterranean restaurant in San Francisco.  I die from ecstasy each time I eat here.
author: Buffy T.

description:
This is the best Mediterranean restaurant in the City.  But it's a *restaurant*, not a deli.  Don't come thinking you'll order a Shawerma wrap (go to Truly Med for that).

They serve real entrees here.  They have delicious specials, friendly waitresses and real menus.  Turkish people eat here, not college students.

Order the Babaganoush - it's the best I've ever had.  They'll serve it with warm bread that is excellent by itself.  And the Alexander dish (mentioned in other reviews) is dynamite.

Try a Turkish soda or yogurt while you're at it - it's all good!
author: Loren E.

description:
WOWZA! i have to add this to my list of "moving to the TL isn't so bad when you have restaurants like these"! 

a couple weeks ago, my friend and i were walking down geary as we sometimes do, when she stopped to look at the menu. we decided then and there to make a point to eat there. last night she and i dragged our boyfriends out and tried our first taste of turkish food from Alaturca, and i must say, i think we were all quite impressed!

we ordered a plate of hummus and one of baba ghanoush to start with. holy lord, the baba ghanoush was the best thing i've tasted in what feels like a long time! i could have eaten the whole plate plain!

my boyfriend and i split the special, manti, which was pitched as "turkish ravioli". again, knock-yer-socks-off good! the manti came with a garlic yogurt and butter sauce mmmmmmmm so tasty! the yogurt was a little sour creamy, but still so good!

the four of us split a vegetable pide as well, which we all liked. for desert we all shared a kunefe. what sounded really delicious on the menu came back as a dessert that was way to syrupy sweet and not at all what we were expecting. i probably wont get that again, i'll just try the baclava.

overall a really good fulfilling meal! i am definitely going to go back for more!!
author: Jaei P.

description:
Super Friendly Service.
Good Food. Good Prices.
I really enjoyed the chicken kababs. Rice was very flavorful.
The only thing I would not order again is a yogurt drink that was extremely salty and garlicky....yes its a drink....and it was too weird for me.....
Other than that I would definitely go back!
author: Judith F.

description:
I have a feeling my Turkish co-worker got real sick of us eating crap Mediterranean food. Today she took us here for some authentic Turkish food and did all the ordering. 

Thank goodness she ordered for us. Otherwise I'd probably end up sticking to more familiar dishes like hummus and shish kebabs. Got the Lahmacun as an appetizer, which is minced meat with some flavorful tomato stuff on flatbread. The Iskender Kebab plate, consisted of doner strips, cubes of bread, red sauce, and yogurt. It was moist, kinda sweet, kinda tarte, all a good combination, plus large enough for 2 people to share. For dessert we had the Sutlac and Kunefe. I'd definitely order the Kunefe again, but not the Sutlac. It wasn't impressive and tasted too similar to Kozy Shack rice pudding. 

I'll definitely come back here again. But next time I won't need my co-worker's help.
author: Victoria N.

description:
Pretty authentic Turkish food at reasonable prices.  Its not too fancy inside, so I am not sure if this is a place I would bring a date, but definitely worth checking out.  

I has the Iskender Kabab, which I ate all over Turkey on my honeymoon.  It wasn't exactly what I had in turkey, but it was close.  The yogurt was good, and that was key.

I will definitely go back
author: Steve S.

description:
went back and tried the lunch special

Lamb & beef Gyro sandwich, fries, soft drink $6.50

I thought it was excellent, the gyro was very filling and satisfying, they gave a me a big plate of fries too, it was well worth the money, I would recommend the lunch special.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: Really good food and friendly service. We had a spinach and cheese pide and rice pudding for dessert. Would definitely go back.
author: Brian B.

description:
Sorry but the staff here is fuc*ing rude.  I live around the corner so I only order takeout,  thus they know they won't be getting much of a tip (just a dollar or two for a big order).  The way in which staff acts under this circumstance speaks VOLUMES for the real level of customer service in a  dining establishment.  

They are rude little bitches,  throw your change on the counter while talking to their co-workers, ignore your requests after making the initial order, never say "thank you," and basically seem to enjoy turning off customers from eating there.  I will NEVER DINE IN. I do love their Chicken Dolma though,  so i'll be back for more takeout...  

BUT THEY AREN'T GETTING A TIP!
author: Matt G.

description:
A La Turca is a gem of a dive in the tenderloin!  Go here for great kabobs and chops!  Portions are fantastic and the food comes out pretty fast!  The restaurant is not big so on weekend nights be ready for a wait.  Also there's really no waiting area so you're basically standing right next to patrons' tables.  

BYOB is ok if I remember correctly.  Try the lamb chops, the best in the city I've had!  Entrees are plenty enough food and cost between $10-15.  Great bargain!
author: Hui C.

description:
Pho in the Tenderloin after 7? Forget it! Go Turkish instead. The spicy lamb and beef must have made an indelible impression on my tastebuds, because even the dessert tasted like meat! (they ran out of baklava) Don't be alarmed by the funny snail shell, just think: Turkish Escargot. And that much better when washed down with some after dinner tea.

I'm trying some more of their fabulous pie next time I go back. Oh, and the hummus platter that the people next to us were eating looked mighty good.
author: Angela C.

description:
The pide bread is amazing. Really really good. The combo plate appetizer was also very, very good. 

Now that said, the rest of the food goes on the mediocre side for me. The lentil soup tastes like colored water. The lamb dino(sp?) sandwich was rather bland. 

The service was very good. One of the waitresses in particular is smokin'. Seeing her again would be the only reason I would come back here any time soon.
author: Mark G.

description:
Hard to dispute anything that anyone has said about this place.  It's the best Turkish food you will find in this city, right next to Turkey itself.  My brother introduced me to this place.  He lived in Turkey for 5 years and really wanted me to try Turkish food.  To my surprise, it was amazing and I seriously mean amazing people!!

The place isn't an elite decor by any means, the acoustics aren't so bad, the bathroom is clean, the neighborhood is becoming hip and trendy, slowly.  I personally like the area, myself.  The employees are always nice and attentive, good for one, two, three people and even fairly large groups.
I've tried numerous plates here and have not once been disappointed.  My little cousin who is 15 and doesn't know a thing about Turkish food, except Baklava, LOVED IT!  

OH and their baklava (which I have personally never had before my little cousin forced me to eat it here), is AMAZING and I will go back again and again, simply for that!!  

A MUST TRY for anyone.  Locals, tourists, all a like:)
author: Kat M.

description:
I have tried quite a few items, but my favorite is the beyti kebap!  The lamb is perfect, without an overpowering taste.  Sooo good, with plenty of yogurt!  

It's nice to sit outside for lunch, when the weather is nice enough.  My only beef is that it is a bit cold when I sit inside.

Not too pricey, and you get plenty of food!
author: Violet S.

description:
We had an event here for over 50 people. George, the owner, worked with me the days before setting up the menu and working with my budget.

The food was amazing, the service was so friendly, and we all had a wonderful time.

They have this great upstairs room for a private party. Trust me you will not be disappointed with A la Turca. Fantastic place!
author: Bay Area Tribe B.

description:
Have you ever had marinated and grilled carrots with garlicky yogurt sauce?  

No?  

Then get your ass in here, because I can't stop thinking about them.  Hoe-lee shite.

I've been here a few times for pre-movie dinners, and every time I go, I can't believe that I don't visit more frequently--Delicious! Aromatic! Cheap! Great Service!  Everything you could want in a little ethnic hole-in-the-wall.  Warm fuzzies galore!

I implore you:  talk to the staff about what they like to eat there.  They may not be as excited and forthcoming as Jeeves in the 5-star restaurant, but the recommendations they gave MADE my meal last time I went.  To share a little of the knowledge:  Order the Turkish wine.  Try the Beyti Kebap.  Get adventurous with your pides.

So you have to step through a couple of blocks of drug dealing crack heads to get there, yeah, yeah, yeah.... You think you could get this kind of experience if the proprietors were paying restaurant rent in Hayes Valley?  Where's your sense of adventure?
author: Laura F.

description:
Great pricing

Big portions.

Love the kefta kabab plate. 

The location is a bit jenky, but when you walk inside, the space is clean, warm, inviting and smells divine.
author: Judy L.

description: OMG so good.  I love, love, love (and crave) the chicken beyti.  I have never had a bad meal here.  The decor is nothing to talk about, and it is located in the TL however, there is always a seat when you arrive, so no waiting, the service is friendly, and the prices are reasonable.  Very good Turkish food.
author: Rise G.

description:
What do you get when you put kebab meat in a Fudruckers burger bun?

A La turca, of course.

Gule gule

Fudruckers...Fubruckers...Fubuckers...Buttfuckers
author: Tak H.

description:
We went to the movies on Saturday and I was looking on Yelp! for places to eat around Van Ness and Alaturca popped up so we thought we would give it a try.  Joey and I had never had Turkish food before so this was a little adventure for us.  

We got the the place and it was pretty crowded, which is almost always a good sign.  It's not a fancy place at all, but once you start eating who cares!  The food was excellent.

First off they bring you this wonderful bread which we had with hummus, baba ghanouj.  We also had the Ispanakli Borek, which is pastry dough with spinach and feta.  Very good, but you only get two pieces so if there are three of you, order two.  We also shared a very refreshing large salad.

For our entrees we shared a Cheese and Mushroom Pides.  All I can say is heaven.  It was simply delicious.  We also shared the Chicken Beyti, which is chicken wrapped in lavash bread with red sauce and yogurt.  The chicken was a tiny bit dry, but the preparation was spot on, so I still have to give them five stars.

For our first experience with Turkish food we were sold and we will definitely be going back to Alaturca again and again!
author: Sean O.

description:
Oh yum...

The neighbourhood is a little bit... trashy, I believe is the right word, but the food was decent and a surprise compared to what we thought! We got the lamejun appetizer and boy was that nice. It almost makes me wish that I could have just ordered a full plate of the stuff instead of having to share it with my friend. I got the spinach and cheese pide and it was a giant, tasty turkish calzone. Yeah... The food was a little bit bland, but it was still tasty and definitely worth stopping in.
author: Reese W.

description:
I'd been wanting to try this place for a long time, so, over the summer before a DYL at Edinburgh Castle, SF DYL newbie Pam B. and I went to A La Turca for dinner.

Besides the hummus, neither of us had any idea of what to order. We ended up asking our waitress for some recommendations and everything she suggested was delicious. The tomato and cheese pide was tasty (and huge) and the chicken beyti was delicious and tender. Oh, and the hummus was good too, especially with the light and airy bread.

In addition to all of this, there was a Turkish soap opera playing on the television on the wall, which was fun to watch while we waited for our food.
author: Katie I.

description:
Yakshamaash!! Gotta Love Turkish food!

This place is great. They are not too big, and have the right quality of food for the right price. We had a group of 8, with 8 different dishes, and no one had a single complaint. 

My wife had the Beyti Kabob, and loved it. I had the vegetarian plate (including falafel, hummus, tahine, etc), and it was tasty. 

Would have given it 5 stars. except for the fact that it's in the Tenderloin. Makes it not so nice if you are there late. 

Otherwise, this place is worth it! (and have an Efes beer while you're there)
author: T C.

description:
This place is such a hidden treasure in the t-loin.  Great place to grab a meal before getting drinks at The Edinburgh or going to see a show at Great American.  A Turkish family runs it and everyone there is super nice and the service is really quick.

As for the food for apps they have this awesome taquito looking pastry that is filled with feta, and meta, or you can get it without meat.  I love their pides which are back pies, they are kinda like a calzone, order with a side of the yogurt sauce and dip away, for $7 they are huge.  For the dinner options I love their Beef Kabob, it is cooked to perfection in a delicious tangy red sauce and served over an eggplant puree.
Save room for Baklava and the deliciously thick Turkish coffee.
author: Katie M.

description:
DELICIOUS meat, fresh salad, and clean and pleasant service in the 'loin.

2 of us chowed down on a combo platter and a platter of lamb chops (4 of 'em...tender as buttah!). *hic*
author: Liz K.

description:
Big fan of this place despite the sketchy location.   Stop by after going to a movie at AMC Van Ness.

Skip the meats and go for the breads and Pides.  Portions are good and prices affordable.
author: Zk K.

description:
yum.  best turkish food in the bay area, for sure.  

the atmosphere isn't superb, but that isn't the point is it?
author: John R.

description:
Tasty Turkish bread.  Cheap Turkish beer (basically a pilsner).  Flavorful, very chunky baba ganoush.  Huge selection of platters (served with rice & salad), sandwiches, and what are basically Turkish quesadillas.  Mostly reasonably priced, though the platters are on the slightly higher side (~$10).

The atmosphere is very fluorescent-bright, in an order-from-the-counter, almost cafeteria-esque sort of way, though it's a sit-down place.  Romantic it ain't, but it'll fill you up.
author: Don H.

description: Not best value but decent service & tasty food.
author: Oriol S.

description:
Awesome Turkish restaurant! Lentil soup and pides are great. 

Everyday they have something special for the day and you can even get homemade manti!
author: Gercek K.

description:
I was craving a lavash wrap filled with something, and A La Turca totally delivered. I started writing this thinking it would be a four star review, but on further consideration, I think they deserve five.

First off, you can choose from quite a few preparation methods for your meat. For chicken, my options were a shish kebob (my choice), doner (off the vertical spit) or grilled thigh. Can't remember the last mediterranean place with that kind of selection.

Second, there was no hesitation to swap in some house hummus instead of tahini sauce.

And third, the greens seemed dry, which was a nice surprise. Usually they are soggy from all the dressing.

So yeah, this is definitely a five star place. Plenty of options, cheap, and I'd say a bit healthier than similar cuisine offerings elsewhere.
author: Jason B.

description: Delicious bread, soup, doner. The eggplant appetizer is unreal! Bread Bread Bread!!! Wonderful warm service. One of my favorite places to eat. Very affordable too!
author: Geoff B.

description:
I work 12-4 and 6-10 downtown on the weekends and had to run some errands between shifts, so I was hungry and didn't have time to go home. Walked past A La Turca and saw their gyro deal and took 'em up. For $7 I got a lamb gyro and some french fries to go; about ten minutes in-and-out.

The gyro was huge. We're talkin' bigger than a Chipotle burrito. It wasn't the best lamb I've had, but it was totally passable, and since there was so much of it I wasn't going to complain.

The fries were Ore-Ida. Wish I hadn't bought 'em. The gyro's a go, though, and A La Turca's totally worth your money if you hit 'em during the special (I think it's 2-5pm?)
author: Timothy F.

description: great staff, aside from being a little on the slow side.  However, I grew up in turkey and I have to say this takes me back to the exact smell, taste and all the goodness that I remember.  The food is insanely good.
author: Jacob G.

description:
I'm a big fan of Turkish food having spent a couple of weeks there in 2005 and frequented a few excellent Turkish restaurants back in my hometown of London. There aren't many Turkish options in SF, so I was delighted to finally check A La Turca off my list.

I got the borek for my appetiser, which is very similar to Greek spanakopita. It was reasonably tasty although I found the crust a bit too thick and the filling not generous enough.

I decided to go for the mixed grill for variety's sake. The doner was delicious (isn't it always?) and well-seasoned. The shish was ok, but not as tender as I would have liked. The kofte was definitely too hard and overdone. The rice was excellent, but then again anything with butter tastes good right? :)

All washed down with a refreshing Efes beer. Something I haven't had in a while, although I recall that they have it at Tommy's Joynt down the street.

Overall: solid if nothing spectacular, but with the lack of Turkish restaurants in central SF, I think I'll be back. I'll give the Pide (kind of like Turkish pizza) a go next time. And hopefully I can convince someone to join me for hookah at Cairo Nights a few doors down after!
author: Jeremy H.

description:
I learned that Turkish TV is kinda wild while eating here, there was this show that was pretty much Turkish bikini amateur hour going the entire time throughout the meal, which was pretty funny.

The mixed appetizer plate is delish, especially if you get some bread piping hot from the oven with it. Also, the Ezme (walnut/red pepper salsa stuff) is damned tasty, and the Pides are yum. Sip an Efes along with the meal. A great neighborhood spot!

Watch out for little kids climbing the faux rock wall, the last time I was there, one almost got seriously hurt due to neglectful parents who just thought their obnoxious kid was damned cute.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Great new (new to me at least!) spot!  I loved the advice I got from the server at this place to try some veggie appetizer they were serving.  Such great strong flavors!  Man, not to mention the meat here, it's a perfect place to get your fix.  Tons of lamb, chicken, and beef in so many forms.  I got the grilled meat combo platter, a decision I made after I rejected the meat donnor.  For some reason the grilled stuff is more appealing than the shaved meats on the rotating carousel of meat, but that's just me.  Tons of spice, but not spicey, and tons of flavor.  I had plenty left over for a snack the next day.

Juicy, flavorful meats, tons of variety, I need to get back there to explore the menu.  Check out the pictures on their menu, they will sell you 100 times over.  Get here!
author: Jon S.

description:
I love this place, the food, the decor, the accent of the waitress, the family who owns this cute restaurant. It's a gem in the not-so-great neighborhood. Also it would be a nice(not in the fine dining catagory) date spot, I think.

The most amazing thing is the homemade Pide here that comes with the meal. I am extremely picky about my bread, who thinks that only bread from Tartine is worth mentioning and never buys bread from supermarket. I really have to say, probably one of the best bread I've had. It's like a Naan, but thicker, or a soft thick pizza dough. It's a little bit salty and buttery, with some sesame seeds on top. Yummm.....

The Lahmacun is my dream pizza that I've had when I was traveling in Italy. It was this small pizzeria Le Volpe in Urbania, that had the most amazingly thin and crispy pizza dough that I've never encountered afterwards until I found A La Turca. Thin and crispy, almost feather light. When the dough comes so thin, a big problem they need to deal with is the moisture in the topping, but A La Turca does it right! Lahmacun has ground beef, lamb, gree pepper, onion, tomato, nicely seasoned, makes a great light warm appetizer. It comes with 4 pieces and salad, so great for sharing.

The Combo Doner was THE ONLY platter that our waitress recommended. "What dinner platters do  you recommend for 2 people to share?" "Combo Doner is the best." "What about the Iskender Kebab?" "It's good, but Combo Doner is the best." "What about the Lamb Shish Hebab?" "Good but Combo Doner is the best." "What about @#$%^????" " "Good but Combo Doner is the best."  "Good but Combo Doner is the best."  "Good but Combo Doner is the best."  "Good but Combo Doner is the best."  "Good but Combo Doner is the best." Yes she repeated like 20 times. I guess....Combo Doner it is. It's thin sliced lamb and chicken, with rice and salad. The lamb was pretty amazing, especially with the yogurt sauce.

Lamb Shish Kebab is soooooo juicy! I love lamb, especially leg of lamb. I make pretty amazing braised lamb shank, but it's so nice to have some flavorful lamb that's NOT cooked for 10 hours and melt in your mouth. I like to chew my meat.

Dont get the Baklava, it's too sweet, soggy, and greasy, although they use pistachio. Get the Baklava from Philz Coffee which is made by Oasis Bakery in Fremont. They are excellent and easy to keep too.

I'll keep coming back to try other things. Yummy!!! Oh my Pide!!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I don't have much experience in Turkish food, but when I discovered this place, I can't help but think about the next time I would come here and what new foods I would order. It's become the ideal after work dinner spot on a budget. 

I've once had the combination appetizer that I shared with a friend since it would be too much for one person. It's well worth trying when you can't decide which items to order or are not sure if you would like it or not. This way you get to try a little bit of everything, except for two of the items from the Appetizer list.

Their bread basket is really good, especially with the Lentil Soup. I've also ordered the Chicken/pineapple pide and Ground beef/bell pepper/egg pides at different times. I really enjoyed the one with the beef. They come with side salads that I wasn't too thrilled about, but my friend took hers home and had it the next day and she said that it was better than expected. So I'm willing to give them another try when I go back. 

For dessert, we shared a Baklava and each ordered Turkish coffee. It was a great pair. The tea is good but I found it to be too sweet. I'm not used to having sugar in tea unless it's Thai tea.

We've had the same server every time we went and she has opened up to us becoming regulars. She smiles more and cracks a few jokes. With a few more visits and we'll feel like part of the family.

They play Turkish music and have Turkish videos on a wall that are fun to watch sometimes.
author: Eriko W.

description:
Always phenomenal Turkish food.  Must orders: 
**ANYTHING THAT IS A SPECIAL OF THE DAY IS GOOD SO ORDER IT.***
1) Lamb kebab
2) Feta & tomato pide (like partial open faced pizza)
3) Baba ganoush
4) don't ever leave without trying their rice pudding.  i always have to eat this.  it's not your typical rice pudding, it's a little runny but i can't leave without a bite.  just the top of the pudding in the little ramekins is heavenly.  

ghetto warning: neighborhood is sketch.  parking is not easy since this spot is in the TL.
author: Cindy F.

description:
I don't know what happened here. I had high hopes. I had the lamb and beef doner, Lahmacun, and alaturca salad. I really didn't like any of these dishes. The meat was really dry. The Lahmacun was bland and had too much tomato sauce. The salad had HUGE chunks of cucumbers and way too much feta. Did I order the wrong things?

If you are ever in Chicago, you must go to Turquoise Caffe Restaurant.
http://www.turquoisedining.com/
They have delicious Turkish food.
author: Diana S.

description:
In an unassuming storefront in a vibrant but dingy neighborhood* you can find a damn good Mediterranean meal for a very reasonable price.

A La Turca has a cozy interior where neither the TV (when it is on) nor the music are too loud.  Service was a little slow getting started but very attentive once we got to place our orders.  Five of us ordered three appetizers, which were served with fresh warm seed bread (the waitress even came out to take away a basket of cold bread she had set down not a few minutes before, only to swap it out for a piping hot basket of soft, fresh bread that smelled great).  Drinks were served quickly after we ordered them and water refills were attentive and frequent, without having to ask for them.

Entrees range from standard falafel to meat and/or veggie "pies" (more like pastries) with or without cheese, to meat served wrapped in lavash and smothered in spicy tomato sauce, to kebabs served in long thin slices of meat over bread, yogurt, and more spicy tomato sauce.  Everything was delicious and the desserts are good too - great baklava.  We really liked both the turkish coffee and tea.

Definitely recommended - tasty food and unusual offerings in an unexpected locale.  We'll be back.

*I'm allowed to slag the 'loin a bit - I lived there for two years!
author: Eclipse T.

description: I love there food. I always get chicken shawarma its amazing. Try the Ezme of ur for some cold starters !
author: Sulaiman B.

description: Reasonably priced good food.  I had the lamb shish kebab and kadiyaf for dessert.  The kadiyaf was on the sweeter side.  The table next to us had the kunefe for dessert and was raving for a good 15 mins about how fantastic it was.
author: May C.

description: This place is lovely, a jewel in the TL! Very relaxed atmosphere and the wait-staff is excellent! The chef rocks! I've been here a couple of times now and the experience is always good. Great for large groups and or families.
author: Juliet W.

description:
This place is seriously one of the great CHEAP EATS in SF.

It's cheap, clean, and never too crowded so you don't have to wait for a seat. This is definitely a go-to place for those of you who don't cook at home often.

The kofte plate is my favorite thing on the menu. Good for groups too.
author: Cindy P.

description:
Hidden away on Geary in the tenderloin, I randomly stumbled into AlaTurka last week and was surprised with their great food.  A small cozy place with OK service, the food was really good and tasty.  The Chicken Beyti dish, a kind of chicken wrapped in pastry was especially delicious.  Other notables were the combo doner plate where the meat was very juicy and perennial standard Beef shish kebab.  I'll definitely be wandering into this place again, and the next time not randomly.

There's also a pretty cool hookah bar just down the street that i'll have to tell you about later...
author: Lemar H.

description: The piyaz was the second best food I tried all last year. It was so good I was drinking the juices with any piece of bread I could find.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Really tasty, flavorful and inexpensive food.  I'm glad we have such a great treasure in the TL.  Every time I eat here I feel transported away from the city -- and that's what, I think, we're all really looking for when we eat out.  So come here!
author: Elaine Z.

description:
FOOD= 100% AMAZING
waiters= nice and pretty nice
good vibe 
in a shady area but its all forgotten once entering restaurant.
it can get packed later in the evening. 
their fries are whatever, but everything else is superb.
clean and friendly
author: xzene c.

description:
According to my friend, all Middle Eastern food is really Turkish food, didn't want to hurt her feelings, but I've heard the same argument from my Iranian friends.  But truth be told, this spot acts like it invented the Doner kebab-made me think I was stumbling all over Europe stopping at those ubiquitous 3.50 euro kebab stands that contributed to my 10 pound expansion back in '03, except the food here is better quality.
Props to the waitress for remembering Defne A. and mentioning this dessert that I can't pronounce, but it was this yogurt/gelatin like consistency confection topped with some sort of honey syrup and pistachios-tell them it's similar to Tavuk Gogsu.  An update will include the name of this dessert.
author: Mike U.

description:
In my continual quest to find cheap places to eat, so I don't have to cook, I wandered into Alaturca, and what a find it is. 

The Scene
Ok yes, it is the TL....but once you enter through the stone doorway, the walls are painted with a combination of historical ruins and mythical ones, beginning with the modern day Bay Bridge and continuing the Trojan Horse in what I can only imagine to be Troy. Alaturca is more of a cafe feel then a restaurant, and is family run, so it has the warm "homey" feel. The service is impeccable, although if you ask them for a recommendation, they just say everything is good. 

The Food
Unfortunately, I wasn't my normal starving self...damn this diet...so I only ordered an entree and desert...but I will be back to try more...
38. Kavurali & Cheese spiced lamb cubes with onion and red pepper-it was like a spicy calzone...very delicious, VERY large
Gozleme:  Flat Bread Filled With Veggies Or Meat And Served With Baby Greens Salad, Grated Carrot.. 
-49. Sucuk & Cheese spiced beef sausage and mozzarella-It was delicious! Melted cheese, spicy enough, but not painfully so...yum!
67. Baklava phyllo dough and pistachios topped with syrup-sweet and perfect, although not as cinnamon flavored as I like 
 68. Sutlac rice, sugar, milk cooked and baked in the oven-Wow! I don't know how else to describe it but, vanilla pudding with the occasional grain of rice. It is delicious, although cold...I feel it would be even tastier warm
author: Bianca L.

description:
Just happened to be across the street, and we said "eh, why not!"
Inside the very euro diner, with the kitschy painted walls and loud Turkey version of wheel of fortune blasting from the tv, served with the super sweet imported orange soda, we dove into a few classics of anatolian cuisine of which we were complete ignorants...
First, a nice big serving of their vegetable pide, aptly described by the friendly staff as a Turkish calzone. Not sure how authentic it was, but you can't go wrong with pizza especially if rolled and buttered up and stuffed with canned veggie goodness. The sampler we then got had a mix of meats, of which the gyro was the best, followed by the lamb cubes - kinda dry, but good with the soft tasty rice. 
Bottom line, filling, friendly, ok food, fun Turkish tv shows.
author: Paolo D.

description:
Everytime I think of this place I giggle because my boyfriend swears that A La Turca is slang for "on the penis" in Nicaraguan/Spanish.  So for a fun joke we talk about how mortified his mother would be if I told her my favorite place to eat is A La Turca.  
Seriously though, the food is pretty yummy and the prices are great.  It's definitely another one of those Tenderloin Treasures that make it worth braving the neighborhood.  The portions are generous and it's cozy on a cold and foggy night.
author: Jill D.

description:
I have only been here once and it was by chance. We were up the street at Edinburgh Castle and were hungry. I was so happy with my pide. It tasted like the ones I had in Turkey when I visited last year. The other dishes my friends had were quite tasty as well. I was digging the atmosphere since it reminded me of some alley bars in Istanbul with Turkish TV and an eclectic mix of aromas. 

I hope to go back soon and add an addendum for a more thorough review since it was a few months ago when I first ate here. I am definitely feeling the urge for a lamb kebab in the future.
author: Bathrooms Only ..

description:
3.5 stars..

Been meaning to try this place as it is only a couple blocks away..
Picked up take-out for lunch today and although the service was a bit slow, the food was very good..  they make their own pide..
D had the Lamb Pide Sandwich and I had the Combo Plate with Lamb Chicken Rice and Salad..  Both were quite good..
We'll be going back there for sure..  we just wish they had the lamb shawerma like Yumma's.. 
nonetheless, good stuff...
author: Rose C R.

description: The food is just so great here!  It's fresh and filling.  The meals are hearty and the food is full of flavor.  I tasted chicken that was so soft and tender, it was like nothing I've ever eaten before.  A strong recommendation to those who consider, make like Nike and "Just Do It!"
author: Qyon G.

description:
Only putting 4 out of 5 stars because the waitress was a little slow to get to me at first and there was a big lump of condensed Turkish coffee at the bottom of my cup.  Don't know if that's normal, it's only my second time having it, but it was delicious.

Mediterranean food is always my first choice in ethnic food and this is the best Turkish dish I've had to date.  A big step up from City Kebab on Polk.  Wow was I blown away when I saw my Chicken Doner Platter today!  These guys definitely don't lack for presentation: The chicken glistened with an orange-ish tint, it was so moist as was the deliciously seasoned rice it rested on.  The salad was tossed well in a light oil and the parsley flakes sprinkled over the dish really upped the enticement level.  The bread that came with it, again moist and warm from being fresh out of the oven.  In my opinion, the overall quality of a Mediterranean restaurant can be judged by the tzatziki sauce (don't know if that's what the Turkish call it too) which was great here, but I've had better.

As a graphic designer, I'll say don't be fooled by the crappy design of the menus vs. the nice pictures posted here.  This food deserves better looking menus, it looked like someone using Microsoft Word for the first time slapped it together.
author: Teddy H.

description:
Have you ever been to Italy?  Quite obviously they have the best Italian food that you could possibly get.  But that's it.  You're eating italian, and you're gonna like it!

My gluttonous friend comes to town and in one week we have thai, chinese, japanese, german, american, korean, ethiopian and finally TURKISH!

Now this was the best damn turkish that I've ever had.  And since it was the only damn turkish that I've ever had, it gets two thumbs up.  A lot of salty meat, rice, and just a little side of veggies.

And pretty waitresses to boot!
author: Rocco B.

description:
Had lunch here couple of days ago. The place is nice and homey. Food is good. I would come back often if I live in the hood. The salad that comes with the combo plate is worth a mention, very tasty. 

It is just one of those places where if someone says want Turkish for dinner, sure let's go to a la turca. But if some one says what do you want for dinner, a la turca would not be the first to come to my mind.
author: Mr P.

description: This place was inviting & relaxed though busy for a Friday night. The dolmas were the best I've had and the lentil soup well balanced with spices & lemon. The stuffed spinach & cheese pides were fresh & toasty hot from the oven. We also had the Turkish tea served traditionally in a glass with a lump of sugar. There were several Turkish families dining there to - definitely a good sign
author: Shawn S.

description:
I had the combo doner plate, with chicken beef and lamb.

The beef and lamb were a bit dry, and the salad was drenched with this heavy, oily dressing that had no flavor - this part of the meal wasn't impressive.

The rice was fluffy and perfectly seasoned - 8 out of 10.

The chicken was moist and tender and absolutely delicious - will go back just for the chicken.  The baklavah was a bit on the sweet side, and for $4.25 I don't think it was worth it...will stick to my dude at the Alemany Farmer's Market.
