Highlight of my dinner? The Turkish bread. SERIOUS good eats. Chewy, warm, crispy, yeasty goodness.  It was so good in fact, that I ended up eating just that for dinner and saving the rest of the meal for tomorrow - and I don't regret it one bit!
author: Mary M.

description:
I really like this place. Its located in shitty part of town. Great food, friendly owners and waitress.You have to try their frini .. Its Lassi with some spices. Sweet place ... I would recommend and always go back.

By the way its a casual hang out
author: Amlan S.

description:
Fantastic homemade pide (savory pies)!  It's ultra cool that you can see them rolling out the dough and putting your pide in the oven to bake.  The Turkish native sitting next to us was highly complimentary of the authenticity of the food at this restaurant.  And the prices were super!

However, I'm three starring this establishment for the following reasons:
1) inconsistent portion sizes.  My friend loved the beyti but the portion was way too small.  my chicken assortment was definitely more food.
2) dry chicken.  I got the chicken assortment and it was just wayyyy tooo dry....
3) ambiance.  Turkish pop videos projecting on the flat screen TV above the doorway might be entertaining to the staff, but it did not hold the same entertainment value to the customers.

I'm willing to try it again, but next time I'm getting a Pide.  And I won't bring my carb-avoiding guy friends who will only order protein w/out carbs.
author: Jane A.

description:
Inexpensive and delicious. Visited here for the first time today and will hopefully be back. The place is sparklingly clean and inviting, homey and warm. Our server, Suzan, was friendly yet slightly reserved -- but that was fine by us.

The homemade pide (pita?) bread was outstanding, truly notable -- warm, soft, fluffy, not greasy. We shared a chicken combo platter and a beef and lamb doner kebab on pide bread. Both were quite good, but I'd give the sandwich the edge for full and interesting flavor. The menu's huge, and I'd love to try more things. All the more reason to return.
author: Tara M.

description:
I love this place. I used to be a regular when I lived in SF. Fast forward two  years and the food is still good. The platters have changed: you no longer get the salad with the combo kebab plate and the spicy stuff in the shakers has been replaced with generic crushed chilies, but I don't care - I love this place.
Highlights are the warm bread.
It is in the Tenderloin but there's a garage right next door, so for the fearful you should be able to scurry into it from the "safety" of your SUV with few problems.
author: David S.

description:
Some of the best mediterranean fare I've had in the city. Their lunch specials are a deal. The gyros are huge, the meat is juicy and exploding with flavor, the pita bread is some of the best I've had, and they don't skimp on the onions, cucumber, and other accoutrements. Ask for some extra sauce, though.

Their baklava is the best I've ever had anywhere, hands down. I've never been to Turkey or anything but I've had my share of baklava in my day, and theirs is amazing. Not too sticky, not too much honey. The filo stays nice and crisp but they douse it with a nice light, sweet liquid that complements the texture really nicely. Good stuff. They also have Turkish beer and some other tasty filo dough concoctions. Haven't really branched out from the falafel and gyro but they do have some interesting specials which I will have to get around to trying one of these days.
author: Brian H.

description:
Nice surprise to stumble upon this place wandering around the upper 'Loin the other night. Clean, relatively cheap, authentic and delicious. 

My favorite was #18 - How can you not love a dish called "Patlican Biber Kizartma"? wow. Super tasty.
author: Bowen D.

description: I came here with friends before a show at GAMH. It was pretty good, but hard for me not to compare it to the Turkish place in Berkeley on Shattuck & University, which is just better all around. I will give this place another chance though.
author: Ken L.

description: This is slowly becoming our "go-to" restaurant for inexpensive, yet delicious food with an appropriate restaurant-style ambiance for good conversation. Solid!
author: Sally M.

description: Their food is good. I live  only a couple of blocks away and I'll come here once in awhile. Ambiance is ok.
author: Kissy F.

description: A bit of a dive, but I think it's supposed to be. It was a fun place to have a good mediterranean meal for not very much money.
author: Dolce S.

description:
My favorite go-to place.  I have the number on speed dial and when I am in the mood for some serious donner - I would call for take out on my way home.  

Service is friendly.  Food is consistently good.  And the best part?  It's affordable!

It's great for groups!  The decor is bare bones but the food makes up for it.
author: Veritas V.

description:
I don't have much experience with Turkish food - but dang, the pides, doners, kebabs are amazing here!

Love the bread basket, and also the variety of pastries they have here...  The sigara borek is a pastry filled with feta cheese, and lahmacun, which is a thin pizza-like pastry with a baked crust..

I'm taking a star off though, because they didn't give me a bread basket when I first went for a solo lunch...  I'll give it back if I get one when I go next time.
author: Haywood H.

description:
Thank goodness for friends that like to go slummin' or else I would never have eaten here!

Never mind that it is in the Tenderloin, if you fast reflexes and cat like moves, do your best to get to the best Turkish food in SF. 

Everything is so tasty and no grease! If I could eat the plates I would've. We had the appetizer plate, grilled chicken and lamb with rice, pita and much more.

For delicious cheap eats that are filling and a the chance for a free sneak peak of the trannies on the corner or the midget hooker, this is the best!
author: Liz L.

description:
I don't know much, if anything about Turkish food but the food here taste good.  Good enough for me to walk through the TL to eat it for lunch.  I call ahead and pick it up because its faster then eating there.

My office orders lunch here all the time and they take new hires here on their first day.  So far no complaints.
author: Angela A.

description:
Great food, and the meal can be as light or as heavy as you want. I love the shepherds salad (no greens, just cuc and tom), the sauteed carrots with yogurt, and the amazing bread that comes with the meal. Also great are the sandwiches that come in the bread - but I forget what they're called. 

There are always tables available and service is friendly. There's an independent garage next door but it's pretty easy to find street parking.
author: Marina N.

description:
I went to Turkey this summer, and was craving some Turkish food again. This place was a good find.

It's very simple. Entrees between $7-12. They even have Ayran, a Turkish delicacy -- a drink made of yogurt, salt and water. Try it if you're feeling brave.

My chicken beyti was delicious. Chicken wrapped in thin bread with tomato sauce and yogurt. My friend had the combo kebab -- the chicken was good, the lamb, not so much. A couple beers to choose from, including Efes, a Turkish beer. 

If you're in the area, it's worth a try.
author: Evan G.

description:
I love nothing more than delicious ethnic food. That's why I come here a few times a month with my hubs. 

We order the babaganoush to start. get it with some piping hot fresh bread.
For dinner I order the combo grill platter. If you like meat, this is for you. The steak and lamb cubes are perfectly cooked, never dry. Also includes kofta and doner. mmmmmm
He orders the alexander kabob: doner, cubes of bread, tomato sauce and yogurt
For dessert I like the kunefe. we just ate here last friday night. Went in at 8:30 and there was no wait.

One of our favorites.
author: cali c.

description:
After reading the previous reviews, I was excited to try some good Turkish Cheap Eats. A La Turka didn't disappoint.

We started with the Combination appetizer. Honestly, this was the best part of our meal. While I can't wait to order this dish again, the bread that came along with it stole the show. Hot, doughy goodness!

For the main course, I had the Combination Kofte. The rice was really great, the meat was nice and tender, but the salad was a major disappointment. It just wasn't at the same level as the rest of the meal.

Overall, A La Turka was just what it promised. Good, cheap eats with large portion sizes. I'll be back.
author: Yum N.

description: SO GOOD. I love those little cheesy cigaro guys. I even gobble up the slaw side salad that decorates the plate cuz it's great too. The bread is AWESOME, like really tasty - I like the seeds on top, white and black, really great looking bread. I like that the tea comes in a tiny glass with sugar cubes on a tiny plate. And the coke is so syrupy delicious. Nice staff too. I eat here alone or with friends, and it's always a delight.
author: Brittany L.

description:
I've been to Turkey, and I've had Turkish food, so I guess I'm biased by what's authentic instead of what's good.

The Lahmacun (pronounced L'ah Mahjoon) was a bit shaky by my standards.  The toppings involved just a bit too much meat for me.

I had the Iskender - since that's my favorite Turkish kabob - and was sorely disappointed.  I know, Iskender's supposed to be smothered in butter, and rich beyond belief, but this was a gut punch.  And the donor was just not very good.  On the bright side, they did do an ok job with the Shish, and the Beyti seemed to be done well.  I just had a taste from what my friends ordered, but those two dinners seemed fine.  If I came back (big if) I'd stay away from anything that was Donor based ...

Oh, and the Turkish tea was good.  Unfortunately they don't brew Apple tea.  Sigh.
author: Omar S.

description:
This place serves up pretty decent Turkish fare.  I had the Lamb/Beef Doner, and it was tasty, but nothing to write home about.  Next time I'd probably get a plate of something - the adana, maybe?  The baba ganouj, however, was very good and very fresh.

For my money, I'd rather stick with a more take-out oriented place such as Ali-Baba in the Mission.  But I've heard this place is pretty great for dinner.  This place certainly isn't a bad choice if you are in the neighborhood, but you might also rather hit up one of the various asian food places that are all around.
author: jeremy f.

description:
After battling through addicts, dealers, and SFPD I finally arrived at La Turca, a welcome oasis in San Francisco's drug country. On one side of the restaurant is a huge wall mural; the other side is an open kitchen/kebab grill. I usually like watching the cooks do their thing but the guy manning the kebabs was on his cell phone the entire time. He showed lots of skill being able to do everything with one hand but I was afraid of getting a bloody finger in my rice.

Their complimentary bread was flavorful but a bit dense and tough. I had their combo doner plate ($9.75) and my friend had their spinach and cheese pide ($7.50). I usually don't order chicken in restaurants because it always ends up too dry but the chicken on my plate was moist and flavorful. I couldn't shut up about it. The lamb and beef doner were equally tasty and the yogurt accompanying the meat was cool and refreshing. The salad was so-so but the rice was fluffy and went well with the meat. The pide's dough was herby with the right amount of olive oil and the filling was a good combo. The pide also came with a big plate of salad. My vegetarian friend was happy.

Service was slow (i.e. they move at their own pace) but the waitresses were friendly. I almost hid my leftovers (almost a whole meal in itself) in my purse but didn't so I had to give it up to a homeless lady on Larkin Street. I predicted it would happen. I hope she enjoyed it.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
If you want turkish food, this is THE place in the city.
It's not a fancy place, nor is it in a fancy neighborhood. Quite far from it.
BUT, if you want proper Turkish food, it's worth the trip. In broad daylight though. It's relatively cheap, too. I loved this pizza thing they had. I forgot the name, but it's like Turkish pizza. Loved their lamb donor as well.
author: Food L.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place since I love Turkish food, and I finally made it there. I will definitely be coming again. 

I had the doner platter which was very tasty. The rice was very flavorful and had a nice buttery texture, the meat was seasoned to perfection. The only downside was the salad which lacked salad dressing, making it very bland.  My friends had a Turkish sausage and cheese pie which was super tasty and very filling! I wouldn't recommend the hummus, lacked flavor. 

I definitely would like to try more dishes.
author: Henriette P.

description:
Mmmmmm Turkish food, tasty!  Me and my friend went on a random SF adventure and after a shady hunger filled walk we stumbled upon this place.  It doesn't look like much from the outside, but inside it's nice and it smells wonderful.  They make their own bread too which is really tasty and gives the place a nice smell.

The food itself was very tasty and well priced.  We both got these Turkish sandwich/pizza things made with their homemade dough which were mighty tasty.  They gave us a generous amount of food and the meal was cheep.  The side salad that came with it on the other hand wasn't too great.  It was small, oily, and didn't tasty very good.  Plus it had way too much cabbage on it.

Overall I really liked this place, the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was because my friend found a fair in her meal.  It wasn't a huge deal, the food was still excellent, come here.
author: Christopher W.

description: Terrific food!  Terrific service!  Terrific price! I have to admit that I am new to Turkish cuisine, however this was the best experience I've had by far.  We started with the LAHMACUN.  It's basically a minced lamb flatbread and was awesome.  I got the COMBO MEAT PLATTER  and my friend got the BEYTI KEBAP.  The meat platter consisted of spit roasted lamb, cubed beef, and a beef patty, with rice and a salad.  It was super flavorfful and filling!  Leftovers for sure.  At $13 it was a great deal.  The BEYTI KEBAP was really good too.  I've had this several times elsewhere and it was nowhere near as good as A La Turca.  Our waitress was warm and friendly, especially when I told her that I am taking a class on Istanbul, which was her home city.  Great food and cheap prices makes for a great restaurant.
author: Tyler J.

description:
I love this place.  I used to live in Turkey, and this place certainly brings back good memories of great food.  I lived on the south coast, near Adana and Mersin, and this restaurant does a phenomenal job with their Adana Kebap - I highly recommend it.  I have to say that my very favorite is the Iskander Kebap.

You also cannot leave without trying the Hummus!

Enjoy!
author: Nick T.

description:
A la turca offers fresh delish food with good service and decent prices.
Even the free bread with your meal was fresh and good.  Tasty and a bit buttery flavor.

Turkish Tea - bolder flavor than regular black tea.  It was good.

Sigara Boregi - Very gOOd!  Like small egg rolls filled with feta cheese and herbs.  Mmm...yummy!  

Lahmacun - just ok.  "Turkish pizza" with minced meat and tomatoes topped with leafy greens and red onions.  Crust was crispy. I thought it need more meat, less tomatoes and more salt.  I had better ones in Europe.

Lamb and Beef doner plate - Flavorful slices cut off the huge meat on spinning skewer.  The lamb was not gamey at all.  The plate came with flavorful rice and crisp salad with vinegarette dressing.
 
The Lahmacun tasted better after we added sliced meat from the doner plate on top of it.

Although this place is located in the tenderloin, the ambiance was nice inside with glass table tops over a decorated tablecloth.

I've heard good things about the pides and lamb shish kebabs and will come back next time to try them.
author: Serena H.

description:
Solid Turkish cuisine.

Good: Fresh baked bread is a real treat...Kunefe is a must have dessert and worth the extra time to prepare....Kabobs are always tender.

Bad: Rice is subpar for an authentic Turkish restaurant and service is hit or miss really.

A must try Turkish restaurant!
author: Barca F.

description:
I'm no Turkish cuisine connoisseur, but this place was yummy. Solid good eats for cheap. 

I went with a few others and we got a few apps to share - grape leaves wrapped rice, fried feta sticks, grilled eggplant. All super tasty. 

For my entree I ordered a chicken doner. The chicken was really tender and flavorful. The other dishes that folks ordered (chicken beyti, beef shish kebap, lentil soup) were all met with "oohs" and "aaahs" too. 

At the end of dinner, we were stuffed and happy. You threw down $20 each (to cover food and tip) and went along our merry way. Bonus that it's right next to Whiskey Thieves!

Minus one star for our surly waitress.
author: lily l.

description:
Awesome food, and as others have reviewed - this is not a fancy restaurant. The lighting is too bright, the tables are a little too cafeteria looking, and it has a bit of a smell.

But... the food is amazing. Came here on a Wednesday night around 8pm, no problem getting served. Hit up the menu, maybe ordered a little too much, but it was a great selection.

Appetizer - Spinach and Cheese Pida (7.50) - I don't even like spinach, but this was great
Main - Beyti Kebap (11.25) - simply amazing, probably the best Turkish dish I have ever eaten
Main - Adana Kebap (12.50) - great tasting chunk of meat
Turkish Red Wine (22) - actually pretty good, went really well with the meal

Definitely worth all the other good reviews on Yelp, just don't go there expecting a romantic ambiance
author: Joseph T.

description:
Slow service-
good food, i go there once ina while to get my turkish fix! it is as close to turkish food as possible (if not let me know wher else i can go and try) but this one does the job.
try it- my fav. "Iskender Kebab".
author: C A.

description: Giving it a fiver for overall food quality/value, and in SF, relative uniqueness. Back east, greeks and turks galore. West coast not so much. Been here 3x, everything we had was top notch tasty from the gyro-like sandwiches to main dishes.
author: Eric T.

description: This place is alright. The space is super nice for the neighborhood and lots of the food was tasty and well priced. Pretty clean and good variety.
author: Catherine C.

description: I drop in to A La Turca once in awhile when I want some variety for lunch.  Usually I am always eating different Asian cuisines because that's all there is in the TL.  A La Turca has a great lunch special where you can get a shawarma/gyro wrap for 5 bucks.  I prefer mine with Pita bread, but since they charge extra for that I just stick with the lavash bread.  I have tried the other dishes and they are all pretty decent.
author: Bert N.

description:
Ok, so my friend Daniel -- yea the one all posed and model-like with the wife-beater on . . . was moving one day, and I had to help.  Cheers to that HORRIBLE f'd up U-haul truck!!  Anyway, after moving Daniel took me across the street to this amazing Turkish hot-spot!!  Well, to be honest we were the only two there, but we certainly shouldn't have been . . . this place was (and is) incredible!!!  

If you are in the 'hood, or even if you aren't . . . it's worth a trip!!!  Cheese is good . . .
author: Steven P.

description:
My fascination with turkey lead me back to this place, i remember coming here for the takeout (when they first opened a few years back).

Inside, the lighting reminds me of safeway, why so bright? 

I do like the transparent nature of their kitchen on the right, I had the pork doner, pretty good, and the dolma appetizers were nothing too special, but the meal did come with a yum yum bread bread, i will mos def try something more exotic next time...
author: wayne s.

description:
There were no daily specials on the day we went to A La Turca, but the regular menu was exciting enough.  We started with cups of Turkish tea (which I enjoyed without adding the sugar cubes).  The combo platter under the "cold appetizer" section contained hummus, eggplant salad, piyaz (white beans, parsley, red and green pepper, onion), ezme (crushed roasted red and green bell pepper, tomato, onion, parsley), stuffed grape leaves, and cacik (yogurt with cucumber, mint, dill, and garlic).  The hummus was excellent: smooth, creamy, and the perfect accompaniment to the flatbread.  I'm not a fan of beans normally, but the rest of my party loved the bean salad.  The ezme looked like a salsa, but had a very subtle taste that also went well with the flatbread.  We also enjoyed the ispanakli borek from the "hot appetizer" section, which was a pastry dough, baked with feta cheese and spinach.  This was perhaps my favorite appetizer because the spinach with pastry is a perfect combination of textures and tastes.

Among our entrees, we had one disappointment.  We ordered a flatbread with mushroom and goat cheese, but modified it to have mozzarella and tomatoes as well.  Unfortunately, the resulting flatbread was bland and tasteless.  Adding tomatoes should not have resulted in such a boring dish -- perhaps a bit of feta would have punched it up a bit?

We ordered two lamb dishes as well, both of which were significantly better than the flatbread.  First, the adana kebab is skewered minced lamb flavored with special herbs and spices.  While the minced meat itself was definitely flavorful, the taste of the herbes/spices overpowered the lamb itself.  The highlight was the rice, which went perfectly with the intense adana kebab.  We also ordered the lamb sish kebab, which was more subtly spiced and thus had a more pungent lamb taste (which was appreciated by all).

For dessert, we ended with the baklava, which was too syrupy sweet, and the sutlac (rice pudding), which was delicately sweetened and had a wonderfully thick consistency.

There were some inconsistencies in the quality of the food here: the good dishes were great, while their interpretations of some dishes were lacking.  I would definitely give this restaurant another chance to improve their rating.
author: Jim W.

description: This review has been sitting here half finished for a while now - (Sorry A La Turca). It's pretty straight forward though - I know the neighborhood might be an issue for some folks, but this place is worth getting past that. The service is always super friendly and the food is fresh and delicious. Plus it's really affordable and you get to watch Turkish music videos. Seriously - how often does all of this come together so well?
author: J F.

description: Just went today for the first time (carryout). The food was delicious and reasonably priced (especially for the large portions).
author: Rami R.

description:
I tried the combo kebab platter because it was similar to a plate I got  when I was in Turkey. Not bad!! Yum, yum :)
I can't wait to go back and try some other things.
author: Clementine O.

description: Great spot. Came here for a friend's birthday once, had a good time, so decided to celebrate mine here as well. Great quality food.  Love the fact that after food, drinks and tip this place comes out to $20-25 a head after a ton of food. Great for sharing plates in a large group.
author: Gene K.

description: Excellent value. My book club came for our December meeting and we all found something to like. The beef and lamb were yummy. I loved the light creamy rice pudding for dessert.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
I like this restaurant - I tried a lot of items on the menu, beyti is delicious, I like the lamb chops or simply the marinated lamb cubes. Their appetizers are very good, the combo is giving you a taste of all Mediterranean appetizers and is so good and inexpensive... 
The bread is very good - they make it daily int he house, I think...Portions are well balanced, there is salad, the sweets are not too sweet and the Turkish cafe is a treat. 
In one word, this is a good, no frills restaurant where you can have a good meal for a reasonable price and I highly recommend it.
author: VIORICA C.

description: Delicious food.  Nice service.  Appetizers and pides are excellent.  We've been here quite a few times and will keep coming back!   Ambiance is quiet, homey, not too fancy.
author: Linda P.

description: WONDERFUL FOOD! i cant speak highly enough of the combo plates here. if you want wonderfully prepared meat, perfect sauce, divine side salads (the eggplant is my favorite), tied together with a generous portion of freshly baked bread then go to A LA TURCA...NOW!
author: Lindsey H.

description:
FInally made it to a la Turca after walking by it to downtown from my apartment for months.  It was great.  The service was Excellent and the ambience exactly what we expected after reading the previous reviews and having eyeballed the joint on our previous excursions through the neighborhood - plenty of genuine Turkish to represent and the TV was completely entertaining and not a distraction at all as previously reported here.  

Foodwise, it was great.  We had the lahmacun which was excellent . We had also the barbunya pilaki, a cold bean and potato dish which was also very good but also was basically cold beans and potatoes.  The hummus was OK, I think it's hard to screw up hummus, and the final dish was the mixed grill kofte plate which came with rice and a salad, and was absolutely perfect .

As good as those dishes were, the crowning glory was the sutlac, the creamy creamy rice pudding  which was mostly creamy and less rice-y and came with a delish skin with burn marks on it.  OMG it was good.  I was told in no uncertain terms that the next time, and there will be a next time, we get separate dessert.  No sharing of the sutlac will be tolerated.  All that, plus tip and a $4 glass of wine came to $40 for two.  Not bad.  Very yum.
author: Glenda F.

description:
OK, I don't have much to say. Since there aren't that many Turkish restaurants around, this is a decent place to try. However, restaurant itself is not very clean, service is average and so is their food. Deserts were terrible and I couldn't even tell what they were.

My recommendation is to come here for lunch but not for dinner. Surprisingly, they are busy over the weekend.
author: Shumi S.

description:
It's too bad that one of the few Turkish restaurants in the city has to be in such a 'unappetizing' area. This must be a trend because when Sultan Kebab (another Turkish restaurant) was still open, it was located in the tenderloin. Anyway, once you hop off muni and make your way through the shadiness to the restaurant, you have many good options (some even vegetarian friendly) to satiate your appetite. I recommend the following:
- Turkish tea &/or soda
- Freshly baked bread
- Lentil soup
- Mercimek kofte (lentil balls)
- Pides

The price is reasonable, and service has been good. Not usually crowded, so you can enjoy the company of Turkish tv & music...simultaneously. Just wish they would amp up their Turkish desserts.
author: Lauren A.

description: Absolutely scrumptious.  Went with large group. Pleasant casual atmos, loved the tablecloths.  Had clean bathroom.  Extensive menu.  The baba ghanouj was outstanding as was the bread it was served with.  I had the lamb pide which did not disappoint or leave hungry, prices very reasonable, unpretentious. The group was pleased overall and I would def visit again.
author: Ana B.

description: You can feel the love in the dishes they make. Warm, comforting food with good service at a reasonable price. Get the combo plate with yogurt!
author: naushad h.

description: Lamb Chops are amazingly tasty. Baba Ghonoush is very good too.
author: Maitrayee B.

description: Granted, I'm more picky about stuff liek this since I'm Middle Eastern, but for some reason, this just didn't do it ofr me. The portions seemed a little off, and everythign was all right, but nothing was great. The soup was a little bland. I'd consider coming back for a sandwich maybe.
author: Mark A.

description: Our friends took me and my bf there for dinner when we visited San Francisco.  The location is awesome, you can have dinner here then hop to one of the trendy bar nearby.  Street parking is easy to find.  This restaurant is small but warm and cozy, the service is fast . We had the sample platters and everything was delicious.  The baklava here is a must try.
author: Yen W.

description: It pains me to write this review as I have eaten here many times over the past few years, but the food quality has become too inconsistent and now the prices have been raised WAY too high ....  The food has always been up and down, depending on who is cooking.  The main cook has been here since it opened (a fairly tall fellow with thick black hair and a prominent nose) and is very good and takes pride in his work -- when he is working, the salads are fresh, the vegetables grilled perfectly, the meat tender and moist, the portions fairly generous.  But when he's not there, watch out ... the back-up cooks (and there have been several) are very stingy with the rice and tend to overcook the meat and use older, wilted vegetables.  Last week I ordered a dish to go and the salad was inedible (tasted like it was left over from the day before and had an acidic taste), the chicken was dried out, and the rice was almost non-existent (spread thinly over the bottom of the plate).  A terrible meal (I should have known not to order when the main cook wasn't there) but I was very busy, so I didn't take it back.  The head cook always cooks on weekend nights, so I figured it was safe to call in my order last night.  I did, and when I picked it up was shocked to find that the prices have been raised across the board, and the cost of the dish I usually order had been raised 40%!!!!  I know the cost of ingredients has gone up, but raising prices 40% all at once -- especially when the food can be as inconsistent as it is here -- did not sit well at all.  Farewell, A la Turca, it's back to the local Thai and Vietnamese restaurants for me ....
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I've become a regular at the Turca.  Any other Yelpers out there?!?  I always get the hummus as an appetizer (paired with their super tasty and fresh bread), tomato and fresh cheese pie, and the behti kebab.  Service is A+ - you definitely have the impression that this is a family run business.  And who can beat the prices??  

All in all a great place to go for a simple and yummy meal.
author: Catherine B.

description:
I'm lazy and would rather not write a full review, but A La Turca is DEE CHIT.
(That wasn't supposed to be some sort of tasteless race/accent joke; I'm just not sure if we're allowed to use that kind of nasty language here, you know, for ALL the Yelpers under 12.)

I've only been here once.  I got the spinach and cheese pideh and some sort of soup (chickpea?).  Both were delicious and I'd definitely come back.

A small and relatively unimportant tip:
If you're either not sure about or have never had something on the menu, definitely ask about it.
author: Megan L.

description: If I could verbalize the sound made when I throw up I would. This place is gross. I wanted to like it cause a friend recommended it but I just can't. 2 of the 3 dishes we ordered we left almost untouched. The baba ghanouj was too tart and tasted like they used a bad eggplant. And the Adana Kebap (minced lamb) was disgusting. Not only did it taste gamey, it still had chunks of fat in it. Sick. I thought my friend's chicken kebab was tasty but he wasn't a big fan. Overall run far, far away from this place. Given how delicious Turkish food can be, this place does the cuisine a great injustice.
author: Shreya C.

description: 4.5 stars! Small cozy restaurant with friendly service. Parking garage next door definitely a plus. Food was awesome. First timers but ordered like pros (servers recommendations) Everything thing was good. Portions are moderate and decently priced so we ordered more just to try. The mixed grill is a good way to get a sample of a lot of the meats. Don't know what they put in their rice but it is really good. Very aromatic. Will defiantly return to try more. Oh yeah don't forget to order a Turkish beer to complete the experience.
author: Howard C.

description:
The food here was excellent. The ambience is lacking somewhat, especially considering the prices (reasonable but on the high end for a place that lacks much atmosphere) and the overall appearance of the place was not the best, but the food and service made up for this. 

We ordered a variety of dishes and were in general not disappointed by any. Although they mixed up the order for my main dish, when I pointed this out they were most apologetic and exchanged it right away. 

Definitely a good choice in the area.
author: Mitul B.

description: Food is 4 stars solidly, but the service is 2 due to understaffing.  I had the Lamb Kebap plate, which wasn't what I was expecting, but it was very good.  The "sandwiches" here are huge and also quite good, as is the bread.  Prices are pretty reasonable, too.
author: Scott S.

description: Turkish food!   This is part of why I moved back to SF after living in San Diego for 10 years, the food!  A la Turca is no exception.  If you've never had Turkish food, try it.  I won't spoil it but saying what I like best here because in all honesty, I've liked every dish.  If you're into Indian food, Greek or Mediterranean, your tastebuds will thank you for adding the food here to your repetoire.
author: Holden A.

description:
Until 11 p.m. most nights, a garish neon sign pushes back the Tenderloin darkness with more than enough force to make its message clear - "OPEN". Framed by large plate glass windows, it beckons you into a wide open space gleaming sickly with cheap fluorescent lighting, guaranteed to make anyone look at least a few shades more sallow. To your right, quiet chefs in a cramped space work with great economy of movement, separated from hungry clientele by a only a too-small divider and a display case offering tubs of various salads, dips, and whatever else they've felt like making that evening. Almost certainly one of the raven-haired waitresses, who looks remarkably similar to her partner, will direct you to a utilitarian but eminently functional table and get you settled efficiently but with no great warmth - it takes a few visits before they'll warm up to you, but have no fear that they shall, with a modicum of effort on your part. Given some of the things I've seen area patrons try to pull on them, however, their reserve comes as no surprise. 

When it comes time to make the always difficult decision of what to eat, I find myself usually drawn to the plain and simple falafel sandwich - a delightful creation consisting of a thick stack of crunchy, fresh spheres combined with a straight-up salad, liberally mixed with a yogurt sauce and enclosed in either lavash or pita; you had better order the lavash however, seeing as you're in a Turkish restaurant.  The greens snap deliciously under the assault of teeth, with the falafel providing just enough body and oil to make everything go down just right. Anything from the menu that includes their homemade dough is also a safe bet - you can usually see them preparing the next batch right there on the spot, and the painstaking preparation really comes through upon consumption. Bonus points for accepting plastic, a rarity among restaurants in the area.
author: Alex B.

description: Best Turkish restaurant that I've found in SF so far...
author: Ryan C.

description: This place is truly excellent ! Fabulous Turkish food at very reasonable prices. Delicious deserts made on premises and great tasting tea. The Turkish music playing transports me to another worlds and provides me with a mini vacation each time I visit this great place. The neighborhood is kind of rough, but hey, its San Francisco, home to every freak, weirdo, misfit and a lowlife you can imagine, a city  where for some twisted reason looking like you're homeless  is cool.... A la Turca may just be the best thing in this miserable sick, sad and soul less city
author: Dee B.

description:
Ok if you are from europe and you are looking for a doener- this is as close as you will get it !I m from germany and for the second time now was suffering from "extreme doener craving exiety " due to pregnancy ! lolololol the women out there with cravings during pregnancy for things they can't get know what I m talking about ! Anyhow order the doener with lamp and beef in the homemade bread, not the wrap , with extra of the salad and get some of that white sauce on it and you got yourself a doener you cant get enough of. Yeay ! The lady who works there and the chef are real sweet hearts too ! Very nice !
Enjoy your doener there ! I found my doener spot !
author: Sabine G.

description: Delicious Turkish food. I had a lamb sandwich. Can't wait to try this place again.
author: Joshua S.

description:
I've been meaning to review A La Turca for awhile - especially because I keep recommending it to friends as one of the best cheap eats in the city!

Everything we've ever ordered from there has been amazing - especially their pides - and it is a great place to go if you have vegetarians AND meat eaters in the group. Highly recommend!
author: Kimberley Y.

description: I love Turkish food too bad I don't live in sf I would eat here breakfast lunch and dinner  the young lady who served me was so nice and helpful she has a great smile aw I am getting hungry now I luv A La Turca I will be back ASAP :)
author: Steven M.

description: lordy, aren't i love this place. amazing food, fresh ingredients,  good services, and reasonable price. Friend of mine and i went for a goodbye dinner, we walked out of the restaurant with bulging stomach and walked in slow motion. AND don't skip out on their dessert, the baklava and Turkish rice pudding are divine!!
author: Bruce L.

description: I really enjoyed my meal here last night.  Good, fresh food.  Decent service.  And super yummy turkish soda.   They do a much better job at lemon lime soda than Sprite/7UP or the like...  Who knew?!
author: Kerry L.

description: The falafel platter was yummy.  The light salad on the side was just right.  BUT, when the menu reads that hummus will be included in the platter, I'm expecting more than just a dab of hummus on each falafel ball.... mmkay?  And they could've given more sauce for dipping- especially when the bread is so soft, chewy, and delicious.
author: CAKE E.

description:
This was my first time going to a "Turkish" restaurant, though I've been to plenty of Middle Eastern places, and the food selection is fairly similar. The atmosphere was fine, though nothing special. Waitstaff were very friendly. Quality of food was decent, but nothing spectacular. Portion sizes were medium, not that filling. For dessert, had baklava, which was okay, but again, not nearly the best that I've ever had.

I haven't been to SF very often, but I suspect that if I spent a couple of days here, it would be difficult *not* to find better dining options.

That said, the restaurant is solidly "acceptable", with the service being the strong point for being polite, and fast.
author: Bob S.

description:
Best Turkish place in San Francisco!

Having lived in Turkey, I am a big fan of the Turkish cuisine. This place has delicious authentic Turkish food. The entire menu is excellent. I recommend trying the Lahmacun, sigara borek, sucuk pide, Adana kebab among the many delicious dishes. Be sure to try the Turkish tea or the Ayran.

For dessert, try the Kunefe for a different kind of experience. It is delicious and very filling.
author: Tina T.

description: This place is amazing, the kebobs are so frickin good, it's like putting the ambrosia  in your mouth, the Gods have blessed this food.
author: Chaz N.

description:
I have always gone to A La Turca  anytime I felt homesick. I was very happy in the past years. Last Monday evening I went there with an American friend. The food was terrible. I was really embarrassed.
The Grilled Chicken Salad had minute pieces of dry chicken, no dressing to taste,  Spinach and Feta Gozleme had hardly any feta to taste or see,  the Chicken Iskender was cold and dry with minute amount of sauce.
My friend does not eat things with four legs so we stuck to chicken.  It was a disaster! Only thing good was the desert, Kunefe.  Service was good.
What happened? Are they suffering from success going to their head?
As a Turkish customer, it will be a while before I go back.
author: Yasmine S.

description: I am  embarrassed by how long it took me to try this restaurant, as it is steps from home.  And, now I really feel a fool because I totally enjoyed my meal...nothing extraordinary, but a darn fine lamb kebap and if you like pudding with the skin  on (I do!), then the rice pudding is an absolute must.
author: L W.

description: It is fine, but expensive for what it is (I think).  I really prefer the great ambiance (nice rugs, great lighting, good style) of Adana Kebab AND their good food.
author: Laurel B.

description: This place was the bomb! Went here for an SF Dinner club and we ate family style.  Everything was delicious and I'm happy I was able to sample so much.  We all left well fed and several people took home leftovers.  With tax and tip we each paid less than $20, not bad at all.  I recommend that you share dishes if you go because one dish is probably too big unless you're very hungry.
author: Peter W.

description:
We've been to A La Turca twice.  The first time was good-- plenty of food at reasonable prices.  A litle meat-heavy, but that' not a bad thing.  We had the combo plate appetizer with tons of babagonoush, hummus, and dolma.  I had the combination kebab plate, with a variety of meats on a bed of rice.  Overall, it was good food at a very fair price.

We went again last night, but we weren't as hungry as before, so we ordered the dolma appetizer (rice wrapped in grape leaves).  It was like $5.95 and seriously, we got four small dolma.  That's more expensive than sushi, and these should not be that expensive.  It was borderline ripoff!
I had the ground lamb beyti, which are wrapped in lavash bread and in a red sauce with sour cream.  It was pretty good, and I liked the sauce, which made this dish less dry than a kebab plate with rice would be.  My wife had the sucuk and cheese gozlome, which is a sort of crepe with spiced beef sausage and mozarella cheese in it.  
It was definitely a bit on the small side; I could easily eat two if I were hungry.  But this particular sucuk was very salty and a bit gamey; it tasted far more like goat than it did beef.

Overall, I would've given A La Turca four stars based on our first visit; this second visit was a borderline 1-2 star experience, so I am giving A La Turca two stars for this review.  Truth be told, I'm not sure I'd go back and risk having an experience like the last one.  There's way too many good, cheap eats in this area, and all the Vietnamese joints on Larkin are much more consistent.
author: Dave N.

description: I'm of Turkish descent, I lived in Turkey for 20 years. This place is horrible. It only has the meat based Turkish meals and they aren't even done right. I can't bring myself to go eat there when I feel homesick. The food they serve there has nothing to do with Turkish cuisine. I just didn't enjoy it at all.
author: Denise Eda G.

description: My friend raved about this place, and I had never tried Turkish food so I was interested to see what it was like. I ordered the chicken shish kebab. Of course, it wasn't my first time having chicken kebab, but it was my first time ordering it a Turkish restaurant. Overall, I really liked it, the spices were great, but it wasn't anything out of the ordinary. the restaurant itself is casual and cozy. I'd go back again, because the prices were reasonable, the service was good and the dish was good as well.
author: Natalie M.

description: Had the Turkish Tea & Falafel Plate, both excellent!  Great place, will certainly be back.
author: Tommy L.

description: I thought this place was fantastic.  Although our server seemed to be having the absolute worst day ever, because she barely spoke to us, the food at this place was amazing.  I will def be back to try some other things on the menu... I had the Donor platter, which was great.
author: M S.

description: The first time I ever had Turkish food was at this hole in the wall place in Oxford...England. It was seriously authentic - you know it's good when the cops roll in for their stake out take out. But this review is about A la Turca.  As clean a restaurant that you can have in the Loin and friendly service that makes you glad that you stopped by. The lamacun ("llama-choon) and pide ("pita" with a bit of an "uh" at the end) are absolute must appetizers. The baklava was really tasty as well.
author: Jenny R.

description:
i've walked by this place many times but never thought to give it a try. i finally gave it a shot last week and i regret never trying it before. 

the pides are cheap, huge, and fantastic. i've tried the sucuk & cheese (spiced beef sausage and mixed cheese - this one was my favourite), the chicken & mushroom pide (sauteed chicken and mushroom), and the spinach & cheese (sauteed spinach, feta and mozzarella cheese). i also tried the combo doner platter (chicken, beef and lamb doner thinly sliced served with salad and rice) which was awesome and it was huge and cheap at $8.75.

this place is definately good and CHEAP ... and conveniently located right next to whiskey thieves ... so you can have a stiff drink and smoke a fag for dessert.
author: James J.

description: Travel abroad while staying in the 'loin.  I love the feel (and price) of this place.  Not fancy or romantic, but casual, fast, fun (Turkish TV & radio) and good.  The bread is lovely - crisp on the outside, soft on the inside, warm.  Mmm.  The lamb (one of my favorite foods ever) is very well done.  Don't miss the kofta or the coffee.
author: She-Ra ..

description: I often eat at this place with a friend who has now moved away. This is warm and friendly place to have a nice meal that is far from the the ordinary. Friendly staff and the only place to get Turkish coffee and Turkish beer called Efes. The food is unfound like no other in the world, prices are relatively middle of the road. All in all I certainly would recommend it to anyone who is a fan of Mediterranean food.
author: Robert L.

description: I'm no expert on Turkish food and I'm sure this place is pretty average.  But alls I know is that any place with this much melted cheese can't be that bad - 4 stars!
author: Daniel H.

description: This really deserves a 3.5, but since it doesn't exist.  It really is worth trying for Turkish food.  Solidly good comfort food, and a bread that is absolutely fantastic fresh out of the oven.
author: Dawn G.

description:
I've been here a few times and I have to say that the quality of the food has improved.  I went with a group of friends and we ordered a bunch of stuff.  The Beyti Kebab (which I have disliked from this restaurant in the past) was really tasty today.  So was everything on the Combo Grilled Meat.  The lamb/beef doner was also good.  The only thing I didn't enjoy was the chicken doner.  

We also shared a Kunafe, which is one of those hit or miss desserts,  and theirs was a hit.  

We sat around for a few hours chatting as we sipped tea and we did not feel rushed to leave.  I am glad I gave this place another chance b/c my last experience with the dry lamb/beef doner did not impress me.

They also seem to be able to accommodate groups pretty well.
author: goph s.

description:
Love this place. Come here for their tripe soup and other great food, that this place has to offer. But tonight I dont know what happend. They mistaked my order, instead off tripe soup, I got the lentil soup. Servers looking at me like, really? Got my main course before they fixed my soup order. Took it and told them, I still want my soup, just bring it after im done eating my main meal. 10 minutes later after I ate and was trying to get anybody who work there to bring me my soup, it happend, finnaly.  I got one sorry from the stuff and my bill before we even finished our turkish coffee. And that was my B-day dinner. Love their food and im a server myself, but this was a bad experience for me, a chaos, a madhouse. And the Ragby team party sure didnt help! And charge me for my tea even after they have made mistake in my order. A bit rude.
Way to go, Im just sad. Do I come back? Well, let me sleep on it.
author: Alena V.

description:
i'm not that familiar with turkish cuisine, but this place is amazing!

so clean and mellow with fun and attentive staff. and the food is not only delicious, the presentation is beautiful!

i love in the area and will definitely be back!
author: Katy N.

description: Stopped by on a whim a while back. Mostly cause it was the best looking place  in a 2 block radius. Anyways, my intuition served me well. I cannot recall what I had exactly, but it contained lamb. I seek lamb like a wolf. Cause it's so tasty and tender. And easy to stalk. But so hard to make exceptional. And this place did a good job. It was some sort of savory pastry with lamb. All my dinner companions were pleased with their repast as well. I shall return and redeem my failing memory.
author: Matt L.

description: The food here was very tasty.  I'm not in that neighborhood very often and I wouldn't make a special trip but it's worth trying if you're close by.
author: Toni C.

description: Not being terribly hungry, we opted for a hot appetizer; Ispanakli Borek, made of yufka dough and baked with feta cheese and spinach (basically, a spanikopita-like concoction of a light, buttery pastry and not-quite-enough filling) and a meat pide of sucuk (a chorizo-like sausage) and a mixture of cheese. The pide was somewhat like a thin, open-face calzone. I regret that I did not ask what the cheeses were as they were quite flavorful and rich (Mozzarella-like but seemingly sheep or goats-milk based). There was a dried spice on the table that included dried thyme and mint which added to the flavor and both the appetizer and pide were served with a side of salad (mostly shredded cabbage and lettuce with diced bell peppers and tomatoes with a vinaigrette).
author: Carolyn T.

description: this was my first foray into turkish food, and i really enjoyed it! i'm a vegetarian, so many of the main dishes were off-limits, but i was excited to try the pides. i had the one with tomatoes and cheese and my lovely date had the one with spinach. i hope to re-visit soon and maybe try one of the falafel/appetizer dishes! also, the service was great and it was a cozy little restaurant. i'm glad i finally got to try it.
author: Kate W.

description: First of all, it's very difficult to find a turkish restaurant in the city. And even if the ambiance is not really exotic, the food is really good, authentic, and not expensive. Try the appetizer mix to have a great overview!
author: Christine C.

description: My husband and I met in Turkey and lived there for a while.  This is the most authentic and delicious turkish food we've been able to find.  We were able to practice our turkish with the personable waitress, complementery cay (tea), wonderful food, I especially loved their rice pudding, just like in Istanbul.  I recommend this place to anyone who loves turkish food, meat, and great service!
author: Lissa N.

description:
Although it has taken me a while to write this, I figure better late than never.

I organized a large group dinner at A La Turca on New Year's Eve and boy, did I pick the perfect spot!  We had our own private area upstairs overlooking the rest of the restaurant.  The manager was really nice in working with me to come up with a delicious, but extremely reasonably priced menu to offer to the group.  The service was fantastic, especially considering what a large group we had.  All of my guests commented on how good the food was and the great value.

I highly recommend you consider organizing your next group dinner at A La Turca...you won't be disappointed!
author: Cyndy W.

description: Dropped in here last week for an early dinner. I had the Adana Kebab, which was fantastic - well cooked, spicy, and very flavorful. The service was friendly and efficient. My only nitpick is that I wish the portions were a little bigger!
author: Sobhi M.

description: Straddling the Geary divide between the TL and Lower Nob is a small, nondescript hole-in-the-wall restaurant with a sort-of-tacky sign announcing its presence - but don't let its outward appearance fool you. Walk inside A La Turca and you're greeted with Turkish news blaring on the TV; bright, warm lighting; and painted murals covering the walls. Most importantly, the inviting joint has some great Turkish food at relatively cheap prices. Everything from the pureed lentil soup and doner combo to the chicken iskender is packed with flavor that warms the stomach and satisfies the appetite. I don't have a whole lot of experience eating Turkish food, so I can't tell you whether the food is completely authentic or not. All I know is, my taste buds were really happy. This place is definitely worth a visit.
author: Jennifer H.

description: This place is awesome. They have such a huge selection! Even a vegetarian like me had so many things to chose from. The Mukver with yogurt was amazing. The babaghanouj, fluffy pita bread with sesame seeds.. yum. Dessert was great too. The people at the next table got something that looked like a cheeseless pizza .. (looks like its called lahmacun reading the previous reviews) and something that looked like a bread roll with cheese filling. I am going to go again and try those things..
author: Kaushal P.

description: Ok so I work 2 blocks away from this place at a hostel.  I've seen this place many many times on my way to Whiskey Thieves, but have never stopped in.  There's this Turkish dude staying with us, and after eyeballing the online menu for 45 minutes, I asked him what the best dish was.  He recommended the Beyti?  It's tasty but not the best.  It's basically meat wrapped in lavash with a side of yogurt.  It seems like the kind of you food you need to eat on the spot because taking it home definitely sucks.  The lavash gets all soggy and the doner gets too tough.  I need to go back to try the rest of the stuff on the menu, but so far, the Beyti wasn't worth the $12.  But I shall return!
author: Meh M.

description: I have eaten here 4 or 5 times; a couple of times just 2 of us and several times with a large group. The food is always very tasty and filling. Having been to Turkey, it is a nice reminder of the delightful food and lovely people. Speaking of people, let me say the staff are awesome. I went to day to plan a take out meal for 20 people; needless to say I was a little anxious thinking about this task. I didnt get the name of the lovely Turkish waitress who helped me, but she was an angel. So patient with me; very helpful in making the decisions; honest in her appraisal of what would and would not work. We worked out a delightful menu in under 15 minutes. Oh, and while I was at it, I picked up dinner. Typical of my experience of the people in Turkey, she was gracious and helpful and then wouldnt accept my tip; saying she was just doing her job. Oh yeah, did I mention the food is delicious?? Oh, and if you ever get the chance, plan a trip to Turkey- I have traveled quite a bot and have to say what a surprise it was that it has been one of my top trips ever.
author: joshua s.

description:
Disclaimer: I've never been to Turkey nor do I eat a lot of homemade Turkish food, but I have had doner kababs in more countries than I can count.

All that being said, Alaturca was a bit of a disappointment, except for the doner.  

We had the Kiymali Borek (#15 on the menu) which was obviously from the day before (or possibly longer) and heated up.  When it came out the pastry dough was flaky but it tasted stale, and there were bites of the ground beef that were on the wrong side of luke warm.

Lahmacun (#13) was a bit better.  Very fresh, thin crust right out of the oven but the "ground meat" (it didn't say on the menu, but I suspect it was lamb) didn't have the strong, spiced flavors you'd expect from Turkish food. 

The saving grace was the doner (#51), which was excellent.  The thinly sliced pieces of lamb and beef were fragrant and peppery and crispy on the edges.  The pide bread was stale though, again probably from yesterday.

Service was fine, tables clean, Turkish on the radio and TV -- what you'd expect from a Bargain Bite on SFGate.  But it was nothing to write home about and I probably won't go back again.
author: Alex W.

description:
My friend Mikey bought a condo and moved to the T-loin about 6 yrs ago.  Actually he's in a fancy art deco doorman bldg. on O'Farrell, so we call it the Uber-loin.
I never in my long SF life had given that nabe its culinary due until we started crawling the streets (before the trendy cocktail lounges started springing up).
While Turca isn't Istanbul, or even Berlin, it's the best Turkish in SF.  All the basic stuff is tasty and abundant.  I love the dish that resembles bread salad with sliced meat product.  
The servers are super nice, and the chef is one of those dark, sexy Turks with a nose from here to Izmir.  If you haven't been to Turkey, go for the men.  Some real smoldering beauties!  Better than Italia even.
This is one of our T-loin regular spots, along with Osha Thai, Indian (we tend to go to Pakwan and pig out on Tandoori lamb and peas 'n cheese), and that amazing Vietnamese place with the giant "7" on the awning, that we presume must say "7 Courses of Beef" in VNese.
author: Rob B.

description: Amazing Turkish/Middle Eastern food. The atmosphere is simple but authentic, makes you feel like you are someplace foreign. Delicious platters of all the traditional spreads; babaghanoush, hummus, grape leaves, etc. accompanied by their delicous home-made sesame bread is perfect for sharing. The lamb chops and grilled chicken are so tender and flavorful, served with a refreshing vegetable salad and rice. After lunch/dinner you must end the meal with a traditonal turkish coffee and a piece of their phenomenal baklava (made with pistachios).
author: Laura Gardner S.

description: This place has very good food with lots of vegetarian options.  I've tried several flavors of the Pides (spinach, potato, tomato, and cheese), the Gozleme (tomato, potato, and spinach), and the Turkish bread.  Everything is delicious - my favorite is the potato Gozleme (think buttery mashed potatoes served "quesadilla" style).  I've introduced many friends to this place and all enjoyed it.
author: Kaman C.

description: The food is good and tasty. They are similar to Greek food. Really good and the place is clean for being in the edge of Tenderloin area. The only thing I didn't like was the fact that the place is small, although cozy, was very crowded... so it felt like I was in a (meat) market! But, other than that it is really good and very decent in prices!
author: Daisy S.

description: Its nice turkish cuisine i can tell as a turkish but some stuff canbe fixed.Service fast enough and staff is attentive but some food is not what expected , served cold which wasnt supposed to be, they serve ayran(yogurt drink in small glass and warm most of the time). So far i can tell Lahmacun and Kunefe is the best food i had there. Must try.Prices  are good.
author: nurten a.

description: Best Turkish food in the Bay Area. I've tasted other Turkish cuisine in SF, Peninsula, East Bay, and South Bay and none has been any comparison to this restaurant.
author: Jo'an R.

description: Decent place to have some food.  Avoid the Salted Yogurt Drink, tho.
author: Lane H.

description: Finally tried it after many moons of wanting to get there.  Eh (shakes hand from side to side).
author: T-Bone L.

description:
Fantastic food, really reasonable prices.  Not sure what other Yelpers were referring to, as the service was friendly, helpful, and fast.  We even found free parking on Geary.  

Will definitely go here again.  Generous portions, best to only order 1 per person.  And be sure to try the Pide--the handmade bread--with spinach and cheese!!!  Also, the lamb was tender, and well made.
author: Mel B.

description: Great value. Hits the spot for when you're in the mood for middle eastern cuisine. Chicken Iskendar kicks some serious arse~
author: insipidphishie P.

description: I came to this restaurant with my brother expecting a lot.  However, the food was fairly bland, and my sandwich was kind of dry.  I would have to say that there are much better options for Middle Eastern food in the city.  The atmosphere was friendly but nothing special.  There are better options just around the corner I would say.
author: Sven S.

description:
I've always been able to go a really long time between meals and not feel light-headed or low-blood-sugary or cranky - things my friends have complained about over the years and I never "got" - until recently.  

So, I had just scored a parking space and dashed into the Goodwill on Geary when it hit me that I needed to eat.  I saw A La Turca directly across the street so I whipped out my iPad and checked out the ratings.  I was curious about Turkish food as I had never eaten in a Turkish restaurant, so I decided to try it.

Meh.

The pluses - the places is spotlessly clean (and that's kind of important if you're eating in the Tenderloin, because the neighborhood is skeevy so you want your T'loin restaurant to PROVE they care about cleanliness).  And, the waitress was friendly and efficient.

I ordered an appetizer which was supposed to be meat mixed with tomato on bread, with other veggies.  What I got was a miniature tomato pizza with no taste of meat, with some raw lettuce, red onion and I believe bell pepper in the middle of the plate.  The bread/crust was very crispy and thin.  Not in a good way.  It was like eating crackers with warm tomato sauce on them.  No, that makes it sound worse than it was.  It was OK.  Healthy I guess.

Then I ordered the combo doner sandwich.  On the waitress's recommendation I got it on pita bread.  It came wrapped in aluminum foil - a HUGE sandwich stuffed with lamb and chicken.  The pita bread had been fried I believe (or grilled after being brushed with oil).  So, a bit greasy to start with.  The lamb unfortunately was not memorable.  it didn't really taste like lamb and it was salty.  The chicken was in little cubes and did not taste like chicken meat that comes right off a chicken, it almost tasted like pressed food like Spam.  It was also a bit too salty for my taste.  Aside from that and I believe a few onions, there were no spices or flavorings.  I was so hungry I just kept eating and eating even though with each bite I was thinking "this is missing something!" so about 2/3 of the way through I asked for some yogurt and she immediately brought me a little dish of flavored yogurt that I poured all over the sandwich.  After that, it tasted better but - still missed the mark.  

Anyway, it's a good value for the money, and I only tried two things, but I would not come back here.  I hope that this is not what Turkish food tastes like because I was pretty disappointed in the lack of spices and flavorings, the greasy pita bread and the meats that were just not happening for me.
author: Alexandra D.

description: food good, wish is had a bit more flavor
author: pochini m.

description:
bf and i wandered in here again for the first time since last summer. i dont' know what happened to them. this was once of the worst meals i can remember.

we ordered a white bean app to share. i ordered a flat griddle pie filled with cheese and mushrooms, and he had a pide with lamb.

first off, the waitresses were very standoffish in attitude, and sat around talking and ignoring us when we tried to get their attention. 

entrees arrived-- mine was pretty much inedible. it was basically very thin tortilla-like thing filled with cheese and mushrooms, not very different from a small quesadilla. the tortilla-like part was ok, but the cheese tasted weird and sour, and the mushrooms were FROM A CAN. it also came with this weird salad that was basically a big pile of shaved carrot over a few greens. it was oily and flavorless. the pide was good, maybe smaller than last time. but really, it was no better than a freshly baked pizza topped with some lamb.

we didn't get our appetizer until later in the meal we asked our waitress about it. without a word she runs off to ask another waitress whether or not we ordered it, and eventually they bring it without a word of apology.

not worth it anyway. $4 or 5 for a tiny bowl of what tasted like white beans from a can, with some chopped up vegge bits. it was watery and bland.

maybe it was an off night, but we won't be going back.
author: Dana D.

description:
There is another A La Turca in Berkeley or something apparently?

I came here for the first time a few months ago compliments of my new favorite turkish friends Isa and Aslan. I walked in and they immediately spoke to a few of the waitresses in Turkish (at this point I had NO IDEA what anything meant) so I felt a bit awkward. The inside is extremely warm and cozy and smells of delicious warm baked bread. I had some Sarim (baked grape leaves) DELICIOUS!  They have this amazing salad with onions and cucumber and tomatoes -i always ask for extra salad now! I don't remember what kind of imported beer they had but it was very good. And their rice is some of the best. I'm a big fan of Turkish food now and come here as much as possible since everything is priced SO well. 
Whenever my boyfriend comes in they give him some baklavah for me because they know I go ape shit for that stuff!
I would give this place 4 stars, but Plus one more for playing TRT (a turkish entertainment channel) and having Tarkan and Ismail-YK on everytime I come in :)
author: Amanda S.

description: The decor of A La Turca is pretty barebone and reminds me of a cafeteria with nice table cloths.  Nonetheless, I appreciate that, unlike other chichi restaurants, it doesn't pretend to be something it's not.  Last night, my friend and I shared the grilled chicken platter, the chicken & cheese gozleme, and a Turkish soda.  The grilled chicken was juicy and flavorful.  The gozleme, though it tasted exactly like a quesadilla, was crispy on the outside yet retained moisture and tenderness inside. It really hit the spot for me.  A Turkish soda, for those of you who's never had one, is an equivalent to a Sprite.
author: Lily T.

description: This is one of my favorite foreign restaurants.  For a taste of Turkey without actually visiting the country, take a venture (adventure) into this place.  The restaurant looks and feels authentic as is the food as if you were really in a restaurant in Turkey.  I've tried the chicken, lamb, beef, and pork dishes (kebabs and cubed), some with that amazing yogurt-laced concoction of a sauce.  The salads, soups, and desserts are all also super.  Proportions are good.  The best Turkish food you could ever try is right here in town.  Prices are very reasonable and the service is great.  5*****'s
author: Ms. C.

description: Mmmmm.... Love A La Turca... Very very cheap, and the portions are HUGE!!! I highly recommend the hummus and baba ghanouj... Also the falafel and the pides!! And of course the Turkish coffee... And the rice pudding... And if that weren't good enough, the atmosphere is great... Turkish TV is on most of the time and unless you count the people I bring with me, I rarely hear any other language other than Turkish... I definately recommend it... Check it out!
author: Lindsey S.

description: Get the falafel wrap (on lavash bread not pita).  It is SO good!  Oh, and they have good babaganoush.
author: Tabatha Y.

description: Simply put, tasty goodness.  Try the Pides, any Pides.  You won't be sorry.
author: Aaron F.

description: 3.5 stars. The service was slow but you can't really expect stellar service in a Turkish diner. The food was awesome but portion sizes were a little on the skimpy side. Actually I think it depends on what you order - I had the chicken combo dinner which left me hungry still, but I saw other patrons order the pides which were enormous. I kept admiring a fellow diner's pide that took her like 45 minutes to eat and was the size of her head.
author: Jess H.

description: Good bang for the buck in this Tenderloin joint. Clean and sparsely decorated, the open kitchen, visible cabinets, and kitschy tapestry lend to the feeling you are dining at your Turkish grandma's house... provided you were Turkish and had a grandma to call your own. The eggplant salad, kebap combo, pide, and warm baked bread are generously portioned and flavorful. Well worth the hike to the dark side for some decent grilled meats for cheap eats. Try the tea. Its served in tiny little glasses that make you wonder if they are meant for small children, but my my is it tasty but kinda of pricey for a whole dollah to make ya holla. GO TURKISH TV!
author: Stacy T.

description: Good Turkish food.  Friendly Service.  Quaint decor in restaurant.  We ordered the Sucuk & Cheese Meat & Mushroom & Cheese Gozlemes (Similar to a Calzone) and it was good.  Friend ordered the Pide (Similar to a Quesadilla) and thought it was o.k.  Good hummus.  Really good bread that comes with the hummus.  Order two servings of hummus & 2-4 baskets of bread for a group of 4-5 people.
author: Atif Q.

description: I am fair and will not judge all Turkish food based on this one place... perhaps I should go again... but I really did not feel it was anywhere near a good dinning experience... I love falafel... but perhaps I just don't know any better? Is this how it is supposed to be? Will I just have to go find some new Turkish friends to school me on the fine art of a good falafel? This place was recommended by a Turkish friend... could there be two menus... for Turks and non Turks? Hmmm... ok... I will try again because I had a good time watching their variety shows in Turkish... I love Satellite!!! Food is culture... and I love food... therefore... I am cultured! LOL... ok... it has been a long day already... onward!
author: Amelia M.

description: I enjoyed the food here quite a bit.  I don't know the name of the dish I got, but it consisted of ground lamb wrapped in what seemed kinda like a tortilla(not quite pita bread), with a tomato sauce and a yogurt sauce on it.  It tasted really good.  My gf got the falafel plate...she only got like 4 smallish flalafels which seemed kinda skimpy to me.  We also grabbed a beef/phyllo pastry which was pretty good.  A bit pricey for the size of the portions, but it was pretty fast.
author: Brett T.

description:
Went last night with 2 Turkish families and everyone loved their meals.  Offered a wide variety of delicious Turkish cuisine that is not often offered at most Middle Eastern restaurants.  Both families felt everything from appetizers to desert were truly authenticate and well prepared.

The appetizers like Baba Ghanouj, Borek, Dolma, Sigara Boregi and Lentil Soup were all delcicious.  The kids loved the Sigara Boregi.

For main courses I had Iskendar Kebab.  Doner (Gyro) meat served with cubed bread with a tomato sauce and side of yogurt.  It was excellent and I rarely see it on menus.  It was a real treat.  My wife had Kofte which was also delicous.  The sandwiches looked great, as well.  

The service was excellent.  The prices were very reasonable and the quantity and quality were great.  We will definitely be back soon.
author: John K.

description: Very delicious and pretty affordable. The vintage, rocky interior is an added bonus.
author: bill l.

description: This place is a gem.  Authentic Turkish food.  The price is right.  The baklava is amazing, as is the Turkish coffee.  The pides are fabulous, as are the kebabs.  The beef I had was a little dry.  The lamb was perfect.  I don't recommend the entree that is like a quesadilla.  Go with pides and kebabs.  The assortment appetizer plate is awesome.  It's amazing the similarity to Middle Eastern food, yet the way in which a slight twist in usage of spices can throw the sensual experience into a whole other dimension.  Love it.  Will definitely return.
author: Abendigo R.

description: best hummus i think i've ever had, which is surprising considering i never knew turkish for hummus... but anyway i had a sausage and cheese pide which was very good and VERY big for the money (6 bucks-ish) it was tasty and filling but a bit too salty for me. they gave us delicious fresh hot bread while we waited. SO delicious. the place was very 70s, so i felt as though i was in turkey. also, try the turkish coffee, but beware the last sip of the tiny cup will be thick grounds, so stop before you get there.
author: Lisa M.

description: Great food, decent prices.  Huge selection on the menu, 10-20 appetizers, 10+ dinner platters, plus salads and many other sandwich/gyro type things.
author: chad n.

description: To start with, falafel is not an authentic Turkish dish. I believe this restaurant has it in its menu to look more like a middle eastern place. So, I wouldn't get falafel here but rather lam/beef doner, eggplant and veggie dishes, dips, and the dessert kunefe, these are pretty good. It is not your top Turkish place but decent enough to give it a try. And lastly, you can not compare asian food to Turkish food, they are way too different to be comparable. I'd say go Turkish instead of asian places around...
author: Burcin T.

description: So this is the first time that I've ever eaten turkish food, so I am as far from being an expert as one could be. That being said I thought the food was pretty good. I will update as my pallet does.
author: Erik S.

description: It was me and my friend's first time trying Turkish food. The food was delicious, the atmosphere pleasant, cool murals on the walls. The only funny thing was mid-way through the dinner, we caught a whiff of a really strong, pervasive perfume. It was very fragrant, exotic, it filled the air and was suffocatingly sweet. It was really weird and random, out of no where and we were a little sketched out. It was hard for me to continue a conversation with my friend because I'm really sensitive to smells. So fyi, but I'm thinking this was maybe just a random incident and won't ever happen again?
author: Jenny W.

description:
mmm. inexpensive and tasty. ambience was a little crazy, but that was because there was a table of 4 adults and 6 kids. So, yes, it's kid-friendly. I didn't mind the rugrats jumping all over the place.

We ate: lahmacun appetizer-this crisp flat bread with meat, tomatoe mixture on it (decent), lamb shish (mmm), a beef sausage/mozzarella pide (delish). I love the light fluffy bread and how everything comes with a salad.  I'm no Turkish food expert, but I know food. and this food was good.
author: Nima K.

description:
Ok run down of what was ordered and tasted:
Patlican&Biber Kizartma (eggplant appetizer)
Chicken Beyti
Pides (spinach& cheese and potato&cheese)
Chicken&cheese gozleme
Sutlac
and of course..Turkish bread

Let me just first say that I think the yogurt sauce goes well with everything we had. The eggplant appetizer was a good start with the Turkish bread. Good way to start the meal. The best dish in my opinion is definitely the chicken beyti (also recommended by our waitress). It's like,  pieces of chicken wrapped in their lavash bread topped with a well spiced tomato sauce and yogurt. It's very good and everyone at our table thought so.  A pide, according to waitress, is like a calzone, but Turkish of course. This was also not bad, and as I'm more of a potato person, I enjoyed the potato &cheese over the spinach one. Nice and piping hot. Chicken and cheese gozleme, well I suppose it really was like a Turkish quesadilla as said by Patrick M, but not so much cheese in it.  Lastly, the sutlac, which was like a rice pudding sort of dessert (served cold) was quite good as well. A nice taste to the palette after all the spices and yogurt sauce from the meal.  

Overall, not too bad of deal, with our tab coming out  under 70$ for 5 people. Service was not bad, although we did have some mixup in the ordering aspect. The meal definitely makes me want to go to Turkey.
author: Yosie G.

description: Went here for a coworker's bday dinner. We had the upstairs room which I liked. We pretty much had the floor to ourselves. The food was ok and I didn't like it that much. I don't remember what I had but some of the meat was dry.

This places serves turkish food.  This is the first time I've ever eaten turkish food so I can't really compare it to any other turkish food obviously.   The prices were super-reasonable  and the service is great.  The atmosphere is cute too.  The food isn't as greasy as I thought it would be.Would definitely go back to again to eat.
author: T M.

description: I love it......Have been here twice.... Delicious and fresh food, tasty kebabs, cold Turkish beer, friendly wait staff..... I only wished they'd open a 2nd store in Bernal so I could go more often!
author: Mike S.

description: My sis-in-law just moved to the neighborhood and last night she had a little house warming get together.  She ordered a whole bunch of take out from this joint.  Yes to the beef and chicken kebabs, the vegetable pides, salad, and the bread and hummus!  Very fulfilling, and tasty.  I'm looking forward to visiting the restaurant for a sit down.
author: Meesh K.

description:
Pides are really good, though the last time I went the dough was cooked slightly different then previous times. I always order the tomato and cheese pide. Their combo platter in the beginning is great to order if you are going with a group of folks unfamiliar with Turkish cuisine. I think they have one of the best baba g. in the city.  I also like their Turkish tea.

Servers vary sometimes very sweet and sometimes reserved, but if you like to go eat and not be swooned over-good spot.  Feels very much like a living room with the television on and the Turkish music playing.  

Very good spot.
author: Batia L.

description: That's 5-stars for delivering authentic small-restaurant mezes-style food without pretense or hooplah. It's not a gourmet see-and-be-seen destination restaurant nor is it trying to be romantic, quirky, trendy, hip, or posh. It's just plain good. I discovered Turca a week after returning from a visit to Turkey so, like Jessica, I had an idea what the dishes were supposed to takste like. They're right on the mark! Many folks may steer clear of the baklava-style desserts because, indeed, they can be super sweet. But give the Kunefe a try... kesar cheese melted in kadayif angel-hair dough and soaked in a honey syrup... wow!
author: Michael H.

description:
best "alexander" and the kunefe is to die for.

once, we ordered the pide and it was quite disappointing. the mushrooms were canned (*gasp*), and the overall texture was rubbery.
