i got over it and still love this place.

don't think about going w/o trying the kunefe.
author: jennifer y.

description: I used to be a regular here when I lived around the corner. Incredibly yummy food!
author: Teresa M.

description: I'm glad Yelp offers the "Trend" option.  After reading the recent reviews, which were not all that good, I went there and the trend in reviews has not been good.  I enjoyed the food here before, and I've always raved about the hummus and the bread that goes with it, the worst thing was they never gave you enough bread.  Tonight, the hummus is so bland it's not even appealing, and the bread, normally redolent of olive oil and spices, and steamy hot, is cool, hardening and nearly without flavor.  What happened?  I was there just before seven, on a tuesday night--normally they'd be hopping, and every table, every chair, was empty.  So sad.
author: Paul T.

description: Good bang for the buck.  I've had the hummus and the baba ganoush, both of which were okay but I've had better.  The bread is good so ask for more.  I'm still going down the list of pides and so far, haven't had one that I didn't like.  A friend ordered a chicken and rice plate which turned out to be a little dry.  Too bad for him; my food was good.  Have some tea afterward.  The place is quick and good for the wallet.
author: Lyn D.

description: Sometimes the grape leaves have raisins, other times they don't. Either way they're great. As are the falafel and pides. It's not expensive and has that spare "I'm in Turkey now" feeling. I always go for cheap and good and this is it. Oh, and don't forget the rice pudding. As if you could.
author: Mudaba A.

description: Good food, nice sized portions, and great prices.  The service was a liiitttlllee slow; but, they were very pleasant.  I will most definitely go back....mainly because I LOVE rice pudding and I didn't try it!  The reviews rave about it!
author: Gillian F.

description: This place is awesome and right next to my favorite bar in town (whiskey thieves). the only problem I had is that they have doubled their prices as they have gotten more popular--but other than making a profit on great food, this place is super yummy! Try a pide with the sausage (I can't remember the name) it's the best hangover food EVER. Also, their pita is homemade and fluffy as a cloud ("is there anything fluffier than a cloud?" - Simpsons). Anyway, it's a great place and the neighborhood has a lot to offer (again about the Whiskey Thieves).
author: ida r.

description: A good place for kebabs and pides.  Reasonably priced and unpretentious.  Get the eggplant with ground beef.  It's a bit greasy but comes with rice to sop up the saucy goodness.  Close to bars and a good place to eat before hitting the drinks.
author: L Y.

description: You can't find better food for the price anywhere in San Francisco. Very good and very cheap!
author: Scott H.

description:
ate here last night with j.p and said boyfriends. i was unsure of what to expect and what some of the dishes were. we started off easy with a plate of baba ghanoush and one of hummus. the hummus was pretty good, but what really blew my socks off was the ghanoush! holy crap, i scraped that baby clean! i also used it to enhance our next dish, which was a mushroom/tomato/potato "filled flatbread." this dish is known as "quesadilla" to most people. my boyfriend liked it. me? not so impressed. 

thankfully, we moved on to a mushroom/tomato/potato pide, which was quite tastey! the bread at alaturca is freaking delicious! which is good, considering how much we saw of it. we ended the night with kunefe, which is the superior version of kadayif. it was not what i was expecting, though not entirely bad. i think i would eat it again, if not for the super sweet syrup-like substance coating the bottom. however, i will probably have to eat it again anyway, because mu sugar-hungry boyfriend liked it quite a bit.

good for vegetarians, maybe not so much vegans. great for carnivores and my biggest word of advice, stay away from the salad. the two main ingredients are lettuce and oil. 

try this place though, it was a fun new experience. excitement!
author: Tara A.

description: I love this place!  I always get the lamb shish kabob platter and it's always as good as the first time.  The rice pudding and baclava are amazing!  The service is great too!
author: Laura H.

description: We love this place. My husband started going years ago, and we've been going together for the last 3+ years, probably once a month. We always leave full, happy, and satisfied. Our order almost always includes the chicken beyti and we always make room for kunefe ( a round piece of cheese covered in shredded philo and baked, then covered in the sweet syrup used for baklava- yum!). To be honest though we've never been disappointed- vegetarian items, chicken, or red meat, all delicious.
author: Reva B.

description: This place used to be pretty good. I remember the day when I easily could give it 4 stars. Today however, its nothing like it used to be. The food is not as fresh, feels like kebab was cooked a day ago and microwaved, and its probably what happened. I was going to give this place 3 stars. Until, I came there with my wife, and they gave her charcoal kebab, that clearly burned. We politely asked the waitress to replace it and pointed out that it was burned. She was pretty reluctant saying that its suppose to be like that, but then changed it and apologized. Finally, they brought the new plate where the meat was heavily undercooked... you could see blood in it. At that point i did not want to say anything, but I did have to trade my food with my wife's because she simply could not eat it. Again, we came here many times before, and its sad that this place has deteriorated together with the economy.
author: Andrew S.

description: Good but stick to the lentil soup and side dishes rather than the dinners which are weak in my opinion. Must try the yopghurt dip with homeade bread here as appetizer. -Out of the park...
author: Ross J.

description:
Best turkish -- if not "middle eastern on a budget" -- in all of SF.  Tasty kebabs (I always get the chicken donner on pita).  Interesting pides.  Terrific hummus, baba ganoush, etc. (try the appetizer sampler for two people).  The best part is the pita bread, which is almost always fresh and hot out of the the oven (btw, I cannot overstate how much getting warm bread improves a restaurant's stature in my mind...).  The service is incredibly friendly -- clearly almost all the staff are turkish.  If you feel like something different, try the entree that is lamb rolled in lavash, arranged in a circle and served with a buttery sauce (can't remember, but I think item 52 or 53 -- ask the server).

Corkage fee is a steal if you want to bring your own vino ($10 I think).
author: Jeff L.

description:
A La Turca was just good enough to earn it  three stars. We went just before closing so they were out of  Donner both chicken and lamb/beef.  

My Chicken Kofte sandwich was overly toasted (slightly burnt) and  the kofte patty a little dry.  Overall average. 

The service was spotty but at this price point I am not expecting much. They ended up overcharging us but fixed it promptly. 

A little care in the food preparation might have earned them one more star. But since it was pretty late and almost closing they didn't lose one. A La Turca straddled a very fine line to get the three stars. 

May be a revisit at a more reasonable time might change my mind and push it into the four star range.
author: Arun R.

description: Love this place!  The food is SO fresh and delicious and the wait staff is very friendly.  No, it's not in the best part of town and the decor is funky....but personally, I like a little dive with my food.  I've eaten here about 5 times and I'm always impressed.  Will be back many more times.  You get the feeling that the owners and staff really care about what you're eating and your dining experience, while keeping it very casual.
author: Kimberly C.

description: I came here on a full stomach but when I saw (and smelled) the Lahmacun I had to try it.   And let me tell you, I don't think any other restaurant experience has triggered memories the way A la Turca did for me that night:  Istanbul's warmth and friendliness, and smells of street carts selling sandwiches came flooding back.  Also tried some lamb and other meat dishes, which were also very good.  I left feeling sick, but in a good way.
author: Sarah C.

description: Never even noticed this restaurant even though I've driven past it a million times. Honey got a chicken & pineapple pide.  I got a chicken kebap plate.  Yum and yummier.  Not to mention cheap.
author: Jeanne L.

description: 5 stars for taste and authenticity. Love the Adana kebob and the pita is worth the visit, too. Lived in Turkey (in Adana) for 2 years, and have visited many times and this is as good as anything I ever had "in country."  I try to eat here at least once every time I come to SF. Love the Borek and Lamacun. Pricing is reasonable and the staff is very friendly. Not the fanciest dining experience, but surely one of the tastiest if you are looking for some tender lamb dishes.  Cok iyi.
author: Duane H.

description: I have been here twice and I think this is the best Turkish restaurant in the city. Lahmacun is my favourite, it is very crispy, almost the same in Turkey. Lamb kebap is delicious. Also Kunefe is perfect. Service is ok. Why 4 star? Because the portions of the appetizers are very small. Overall it is the right place to taste delicious Turkish food.
author: Fatih Y.

description: To start, the pita bread is out of this world.  So simple and yet the flavor is amazing.  I once mentioned  this to the waitress and she stated "It's just flour and water."  To which I replied: "That some damn good flour and water!"  I usually have the daily special, garbanzo beans in broth with lamb, lamb with vegetable, or just about any of the specials will do.  Although I've never had home made Turkish food I get the feeling the A la Turka comes very close.  This food is so good - just give it a chance, I did and now I'm hooked.
author: Roxy I.

description: Based on my trip to Turkey last summer, this place is authentic. You can't complain about the tasty, tasty meats. But I actually  think the appetizers might be even better than the mains. The babaghanouj is smoky-flavored to perfection, and the lentil soup is really good. When you get a main, get a sandwich on the housemade pita--it's out of this world.
author: David K.

description: I was really excited about Turkish food, but I don't think I liked it as much as my friends did. I ordered a baked spinach thing that was similar to a calzone that was good, but it didn't change my life. The hummous was pretty good but not too great (Sorry Lisa M.). Altogether, just alright.
author: Clare G.

description: A beautiful Tenderloin treasure! Although it was not as good as my hometown favorite (The Kebab Cafe of Arcata, CA) I liked the hummus and the warm bread. The waitress was fun and it was pretty packed for a Monday night! Overall good food, could have been better...
author: Lizzie N.

description:
I absolutely adore the food at this restaurant. I've been here five or six times, most recently about a month ago, and ordered several different dishes. Never been disappointed yet.

The reason to come here is, without a doubt, the bread. If you're a fan of bread, you will really appreciate the miracles they perform in their kitchen; if you're not a fan yet, you will be. They do bring bread to the table regardless of what you order, and it's heavenly, but I strongly recommend ordering a main dish that also has a bread component. 

I think my all-time favorite is the pide (basically a baked sandwich) stuffed with lamb beef doner and mozzarella. Even if you're not into lamb, I'd still recommend it because theirs is not gamey at all. I'm a pretty decent baker myself and I tried my best to replicate this dish at home, but their version is so delectable you won't believe it. It comes in an oval shape, slit down the middle vertically so all the goodies inside are bursting out, and sliced horizontally. Yummy yummy yummy!

Also outstanding is the lentil soup. I usually don't like lentils, but this is to die for. You can order it separately as an appetizer, or if you order one of the specials it comes with the meal. Dipping the bread into the soup is one of life's little joys.

I've had all the desserts and they're fabulous, especially the kunefe. It's a shredded pastry with sweet cheese, syrup, and pistachios. After having one of the pides (along with the bread/soup appetizer) you may feel you can't possibly squeeze this in, but you should. Worry about the calories later!
author: Sasquatch M.

description: One of the first places I ate after moving to SF, I happened upon this place while looking at an apartment in the TL (which I thankfully, ultimately, didn't take).  But this place has rockin' pied, which if you've never had, this is the place to go.
author: matt s.

description: I used to like this place and visited quite a bit. Then I saw a rat running in the dining room and the kitchen staff chasing it. That was the end of it for me. Never again.
author: levent o.

description: really good place, service is excellent , everyone that worked there had a smile on their face, lamb donner didnt taste like those frozen meats you eat at most places, nicely seasoned and has a smoky flavor m lahmacun was gone in 2 seconds , and the deepfried eggplant and pepper even better , second time there and more visits to come , great place
author: NAEL K.

description: One of my all time favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I love love love their hummus.  It's clean and the staff is incredibly kind.  It is perfectly priced and perfectly delicious.  The Pide's are amazing!
author: Jennifer V.

description:
First of all, food always taste better when your in the
native homeland. But this place is excellent for us gringos and native Turks.
Stay away from hummus you can get it anywhere-DUH!! try the adana kebob,the pides, etc..lentil soup is excellent to. The rice pudding and baklava are awsome. I had pretty much everything-I swear.
Now I don't understand with some of the negative remarks about the waitstaff. That has never happened to me and I have eaten here often.I have also brought my friends.Everyone seemed really friendly with me. Once I met the owner who happened to be behind the cash register and he just started a friendly chat and said he will be opening another A La Turca on 9th and Irving, Hope this happens soon cuz this place rules!!
author: angela b.

description: This is one of my favorite dinner spots. They are really tasty and really fast. Usually on a slow night I can come in, order and by the time they have finished swiping my card and I've signed for it and all that my doner is finished and bagged. Plus it takes exactly one playthrough of Frank Sinatra by Cake for me to walk back home, including a stop for cigarettes half a block down. That, my friends, is convenience.
author: Rob R.

description: Pretty impressive, although most of the food was flavored and spiced relatively mildly (as compared to House Of Falafel in Cupertino).  The spinach and cheese pie was piping hot!  Try their Turkish beer- I forgot what it was called- it goes perfect with their food.
author: Passdatanqueray M.

description: This is a great place for lunch or dinner - I live in the neighborhood and come here regularly.  I downgraded one star because of the television, but at least the sound isn't on.  They have your typical middle eastern stuff (humous, falafel, etc), but also some things I hadn't eaten before, like lamachoun (spelling!), and pides (I love the potatoe and cheese ones).  If you like meat, the lamb chops are great.  I'm also a fan of their lentil soup - definitely add some lemon to it.  The bread is out of this world.
author: sunny o.

description:
Great Turkish Food. Iskender Kebap is highly recommended. Turkish Tea and Coffee are great as well. Service was very nice. In general, it levels up to be better than most other Turkish restaurants, though I haven't tried all the restaurants in the Bay Area.

This is a Zagat-recommended place as well.
author: Vivek A.

description:
DELISH!!!! ONE OF MY FAV'S IN THE CITY!!!

YUM.....you wont be disappointed with anything you order from the menu!
author: Lindsey G.

description: Fell into this placing when wandering by and everything was delicious!!  My never can fill up son actually was full and we will come here when ever we are in the area.  Delightful waitress!!
author: Patrick Z.

description: I go here at least once every 2 weeks and the food quality is just great. During my last 3 years I have never had any odd incidences. I bring all my SF visitors to this place and I recommend this to everyone!
author: Milli G.

description: I like this place.  I must agree with the naysayers that the wait staff is pretty surly.  I almost expected my waitress to emerge with a cigarette (replete with inch-long ash) dangling from her bottom lip.  Wouldn't it  be rad if I married her and she read this and it totally ruined our future?  Anyway, I got a sandwich that was actually a 12-foot lamb filled pastry lacquered with Pam.  It was so fucking good!   My girlfriend got some pussy-ass dinner like half a sesame seed or something, totally ruining  my usual 'one date, two dinners' M.O.  Yes, I basically call her a jerk if she doesn't give me all her food.  Remember, I am fat.  I felt really original ordering the Turkish Coffee and remembered that the last guy who read my leaves breathed through an oxygen tank so I felt like I let him down when he revealed my fate was a pretty staid affair.  Next to us was seated an obnoxious family with one of those really loud moms and the dad that doesn't say a fucking word but you just know he's preoccupied with which size shotgun to use.
author: J P.

description: If you haven't tried Turkish food before, it's actually quite tasty and certainly approachable. Roughly speaking it's fairly similar to Greek food but with more heat and spice. The space is comfortable and the high ceilings make it seem larger than it is. There's not much decor but the vibe is still pleasant and welcoming. We were a large group on a Friday evening and we had the entire semi-private upstairs area to ourselves which was really nice. The short wine list has some interesting choices from California, Italy and of course Turkey. I went for one of the cheaper options, Salmon Creek Pinot Grigio, which was just fine and worked with the dishes we enjoyed. For appetizers, we had Eggplant Salad, Piyaz, Ezme and Hummus. The Eggplant Salad is nicely baked eggplant with red and green pepper, onion, parsley, lemon juice and olive oil. The vegetables work nicely together and the lemon juice lightens the dish a bit. Piyaz is white beans, parsley, red and green pepper, onion, lemon juice and olive oil all tossed together. It's tasty and the generous amount of beans makes it fairly hearty as well. The Ezme, crushed and roasted red bell pepper with tomato and onion and spices, is served on grilled pita bread and it works as a simple starter. The Hummus was quite tasty as well, though not as thick as I usually like. The appetizers are all under $5 a pop so it's not a bad idea to sample a bit. We also shared various platters for our entrees. The Doner, or beef sirloin and lamb spiced and roasted and thinly sliced, was tasty and the meat was nice and tender. There's also a Chicken Doner with the same preparation and presentation. We also had a few of the Kebab options which all had the same spice but all were nicely prepared and the meat wasn't overdone. We couldn't resist the Sucuk and Cheese pide, which was really tasty. Not sure about the Chicken and Pineapple combo on a pide, but I'd be curious to try it if I go back. There also are a few soups and salads and a short kid's menu. Alaturca is a cute and laid-back spot that's great for a casual meal, and definitely works for big groups. Hope you have the opportunity to pop by sometime.
author: Leah B.

description: A pretty good place - well seasoned meat, nice waitresses, yummy looking food. I think I'm spoiled by other regions of Mediterranean food - that I honestly prefer. The things I did like was how amazingly tender our beef kabob was. The interesting thing is that the normal tzaziki sauce that is served at other places is very watery here, but it's still good... I think my biggest beef with the place was the lack of overusage of garlic in their dishes - which proved quite satisfying after leaving but a bit empty upon stuffing my mouth. The rice has a great buttery texture. Not a fan of the salad that comes with it - i'd rather have a "greek" salad. Enjoyed the warm turkish bread that came with our hummus. Sorry that was quite the hodge podge of thoughts. :(
author: Jeannette L.

description: So I had Turkish food for the first time yesterday, and A La Turca was a good place to start. My friend and I went in and enjoyed the "ethnic" setting, but their meat counter kind of threw me off. Whatever. So we ordered right way: I got the Chicken Iskender and my friend got the Doner and Künefe. My dish was so damn good with the tomato sauce, yogurt, croutons and thinly sliced pieces of chicken. My friend's Doner, however was quite bland. I hesitated to even to try it because I don't eat lamb, but when I tried it, it still wasn't that great. We later dug into the Künefe, which was very moist and crispy; it was delightful. This place left a pretty good impression on me until about an hour after we left. My friend started complaining about her stomach aching and suspected that it came from the lamb. Apparently it was a pretty serious case of food poisoning. I really wanted to like this place. I mean, I loved my meal, but food poisoning? Come on.
author: Alex Y.

description: ehhhh whaz all peeps gettin hyphy bout dis place fo? not that great. beyti kebab? indian/paki before that.
author: miriam b.

description: We ordered the two specials of the day.  Those were cooked spinach with ground beef and baked eggplant with lamb.  Both were delicious.  For dessert we wanted to try something other than baklava.  Baklava is good, but we wanted to taste something new to us.  We asked the waitperson for her recommendation and took it.  Her recommendation was kunefe.  We liked it even bettter than baklava because it was not sticky sweet.
author: Bob M.

description: solid eats $6-13 for the authentic entrees.  good flavors and lots of choices.  i'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Java Z.

description: first of all, if you have even been to turkey you know that turkish food is amazing.  as far as turkish food goes, this place is pretty average.  i only come here because turkish food is hard to find in the city.  if you have the oppertunity, try efes beer.
author: charlene l.

description: Good food, great prices, friendly service.  This is one of my favorite places to eat in SF.  The Combo Grill was excellent and at $13 it's enough food to share.  The hummus is a must but I'd avoid the "Turkish Pizza" aka #13, it was ok but too many other good items to choose from.
author: Nichole S.

description: what a disappointment. I dined here a couple of years ago and it was such a great experience. brought my in laws for dinner and we ordered several items from the menu to share. started with combo appetizers which was very bland only hummus tasted edible. lahmacun tasted stale, bread was warm but not fresh, meat was chewy and dry. I felt so embarrased for bringing my in laws here instead of some decent place. never again a la turca.
author: john b.

description: i like this place a lot, even though tonight they gave me something different (mushroom-cheese pide) than what i'd ordered (chicken-mushroom pide) and insisted it was the same thing (there was nary a chicken piece in sight).  but regardless, their pide bread is amazing- baked fresh on the premises, it's soft and chewy, just plain carby goodness.  i like the pides, which are similar to calzones- meat/veggies/cheese stuffed into dough and baked or cooked on a griddle.  the beyti is also delicious, but i haven't exacty sampled a lot of beyti in my lifetime.  parking can be difficult, but it's a great casual place w/friendly service, great bread, plus you get to watch turkish game shows on tv.  what more could you want?
author: Zoe L.

description: ordered 2 veggie soups and some desert to go, i told the girl behind the counter no baklawa but she gave me baklawa and she gave me two homemade bread with the soups and 4 pieces of baklawa all this for $29.00, She got the $29.00 then she gave me the breads without washing her hand or wearing gloves. would you picture that ,handling money and bread with no gloves,that's very bad, I went home when i found out the desert was wrong, i called the restaurant,the only thing she said is  ( I'm sorry ) people can die or get sick for that kind of mistake.
author: Elijah H.

description: First time wasn't a good experience.  Only thing I can remember is their service was horrible and lamb wasn't done enough.  I refused to go there until my friends raved about it 2 years later.  Second time was good.  I still think their main dish is not their strong point.  However, their appetizers are great!  I would just order several appetizers and call it good.
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: This was one of only decent looking places open past 9 pm on a Friday night. My friend and I were in a hurry, so ordered the Cold Appetizer Combo Plate. All of the items on the combo platter were excellent. We were big fans of the smoked eggplant and yogurt with cucumber and dill. The bread served with the platter was fresh, moist, and tasty.  Service was great too.
author: Meg P.

description: One of the better falafael sandwiches I have had in SF.  Their homemade bread is delicious.  For the price, this is a great place to visit.
author: Thomas W.

description: Four of us went for dinner last night. Very good, although the best Turkish in or near SF for me is still Mivan in Burlingame. We started out with Hummus and Cacik as well as a lahmacun and ispanakli borek. They were all tasty, and the lahmacun was particularly good, The crust was appropriately thin and crispy and the meat mixture was nicely spiced.  I had an Iskander kebap, one of my favorite dishes at Mivan, for comparison. A la Turca's version was tasty, but it lacked in a couple of ways. I like the bread cubes to be more crispy, these were very soft and with the added meat and sauce on top they had no structural integrity by the time the dish reached the table. At Mivan they're more like croutons and it's a nice contrast to the tenderness of the meat and the zingy sauce. The sauce at alaturca was very good and there was a lot of it, they were also very generous with the yogurt. One of my dining companions got the Chicken Doner and it was quite tasty. Another got the Beyti Kebap, also good, although I wasn't wowed by it. The final diner got a Falafel sandwich which was very good. Really flavorful tender falafel on excellent homemade pita.  We finished up by sharing a Kunefe and a sutlac. The kunefe was good, but the Sutlac was excellent! I'd go again just for a bowl of it. With the success of our friends Sandwich I think if I went back I'd try the Gozleme, Pides, or their sandwiches. The service was good and attentive,  but there was a glitch when we went to get the check, apparently they ran out of register tape and didn't have any on hand and we had to wait for the owner to go buy some and bring it back. That took quite a long time and while they apologized, I would have liked to have seen a little more of a gesture go into it.
author: Joyce H.

description: Originally I gave this place 4 stars, only because the appetizer and music was reminicent of my time in peace corps macedonia.  After my nostalgia wore off, I downgraded to 3 stars because the food isn't all that. The lamb was dry and the side "salad" was weak.  The gozleme was like a quesadilla with cheese and salame.  I still would come back because I like the restaurant atmosphere, but I will try other stuff on the menu.
author: LT B.

description: The food is ok. Its a bit hit or miss though depending on what chef is working that day. The selection of food is pretty limited but its solid enough. Service is friendly, prices decent and the decor is so-so. Love the bread!
author: Maggie X.

description: PIDE!  I haven't had this in years. Just never found it in the states until now. A pide is sort of like a Turkish pizza: fluffy, chewy flatbread topped with cheese and vegetables/meat with the sides folded over. I had the spiced cubed lamb and cheese, which delicious and not greasy at all. My friend's lamb beyti (meat rolled up in flatbread and topped with a red sauce) was super flavorful and rich. The potato and cheese gozleme was warm, soft and all kinds of good. Tasted just like a pierogi (but I'm not complaining). Warm atmosphere, bizarro Turkish programs on the TV, nice waitresses. Looking forward to going again to try more!
author: Tammy C.

description:
How much do I love this place ?? well everytime they put a brighter bulb in the lamp or change the table cloth or the flower vase, it does not go unnoticed by me! Initially I used to be accompanied by my turkish friends, but by now after making countless number of visitis, I gathered enough courage to bring my friends from different continents!!I  Let me tell you, people  from all these different parts of the world with very different culture and taste,  have all made it to this place atleast twice if not thrice!  

If you are in a group of 3-4 people, it is great as you can share some appetizers and main dishes. In the appetizer category my favorite is Borek (deep fried and cheese inside) and Mucver.  Also, get some Piyaz which goes really well with the fresh bread the provide. Turkish style Pizza, known as Lahmacun is very good too, although some days it lacks consistency and can become more soggy than crispy. But in general it is great with lettuce, onion  on top and lemon sprinkled. In the category of main dish, starting from Adana Kebap to Doner are all good, but my number one recommendation is Iskender (Alexander Kebap). You are served fine pieces of meat and bread with yogurt. Very good ! Once again, I will have to mention on some rare occasion, I have noticed the meat stripes are not thin enough. May be I can catch these inconsistencies being an avid supporter of  Iskender  for  the past 3 years or may be its time for me to try it in Istanbul once!  There are some choices for complete vegetarian people as well, go for Pide with mushroom, spinach and feta , they can customize it upon request. Also, try the lentil soup. 

Finally, you will have to dive into the category of the dessert selection. I have noticed Baklava is the most favorite among the non-Turks and Kunefe is the favorite among the Turks. My pledge to you: Please give KADAYIFF a chance....you will find a new favorite dessert for you. Oh and do not forget the Turkish tea while you wait for the food or enjoy the dessert or watch the Turkish TV and listen to Tarkan.

It is not a place you go for upscale ambience or for a fancy date, but the variety of  food they offer in huge servings at an  affordable price  and  the Turkish hospitality (which they are well known for),  Turkish TV, music and tea you "don't feel more abroad than you are at home.."..... truely fits the spirit of San Francisco.
author: Kingshuk g.

description: The food is good, big portions and a good price point, service is friendly, but it is the cleanliness and mainstream diner look of A La Turca that makes me come back...very approachable cuisine, but not bland...fun to eat my way through the menu over time.
author: salty j.

description: Consistently good and interesting food.  Have tried lots on the menu and Ala Turca has yet to miss.  Cheap, simple, good.
author: Keith J.

description: I've eaten here five times in the last half year and really like this place.  It's straight ahead, no b.s.  Good food and good service.  Turkish food is slightly different from other middle eastern cuisines--it seems to use more meat and cheese--but it is tasty.  Not spicy but they put hot sauce on the table.  Very good bread and really good Turkish sandwiches for lunch.  Also a Turkish calzone that my friend swears is heaven.  Good pastries and drinks and very reasonable prices.  It's worth the down-and-out street scene to duck in here.
author: Murray S.

description: Man, this place is so great. Fresh, cheap eats. Love all the pides and the deep fried carrots. They usually have soccer games on and the servers are super friendly. LOVE IT!
author: Disko D.

description: wow. you can't get a better value than this. when they have the manti on the menu, it's a must order (they tell me they have it on sunday, they are little meat-filled turkish raviolis with a yummy yogurt sauce.) really all their food is delicious. ask for recommendations, and order those. no need to go for the usual ol' appetizer sampler. how many times have you eaten hummus and grape leaves. try the hot entrees, and eat them family style with your dining companions. yum!
author: S W.
